webTitle: Wheels: Alfa Romeo Sportwagon diesel

fields.headline: When size matters
fields.standfirst: Charlie English found the Alfa Romeo Sportwagon diesel a smooth, sharp mover. But it was the whistling turbo-charger that he loved most
fields.trailText: Charlie English found the Alfa Romeo Sportwagon diesel a smooth, sharp mover. But it was the whistling turbo-charger that he loved most
fields.body:
First, some context. I own a 1983 Mercedes 280TE estate. Something of a classic, I was told by the man who sold me it. It's big and heavy, and if you want to go round a corner, it's best to plan ahead. It has a turning circle like the Titanic's. If you want to stop, it's best to have sent a stamped, addressed envelope several days before. It is, as the man said, a beautiful old boat, and it will comfortably sit at 95mph while three people have a fight in the back about which CD you're going to pull from the capacious glovebox. So when I slid into the bucketed seats of Alfa Romeo's new sports estate and breathed in brand new car, it was something of a culture shock.

It's an attractive estate - more attractive than Alfa's 156 saloon on which it is based. It has the same creases across the sharp bonnet, a small spoiler built into the roof above the tailgate, the number plate daintily set to the side. Inside, it is on the compact side: many years of attention to car safety have compressed the interiors of cars so there are not the vast open spaces that exist in my Mercedes aircraft hanger. (This is the first Fiat Auto model to have a six-airbag option, I'm told - two front, two side and an optional two along the windows.) But it is not as small as it feels. I managed to fit a bicycle in the back without scratching too much of the paintwork.

The drive is sporty. The first corner, at a lowish speed in town, was a dreamy experience in which the Sportwagon just seemed to want to go faster. And it stops very sharply and smoothly indeed.

There's lots of nice detail inside the car too. The driving seat pumps up and down, and the steering wheel too. Airbags all round. The interior is made of the inoffensive grey plastic that every new car seems to have; the gauges are minimalist, classy, Italian. "The luggage floor," say Alfa, "is dual-sided and when turned over acts as a waterproof tray for storing ski boots or wet swimming costumes."

The doorknobs for the back are hidden in the window frames, which makes them invisible and allows a small moment of pleasure when back seat passengers are trying to work out how to get in. And there's a button that switches a digital read-out between odometer and outside air temperature, which seems entirely unnecessary but, hey, once you have it it seems really important to know exactly how many degrees C it is out there.

But the best bit is the little whistling noise. For several days, I thought I could hear police sirens in the distance. And then I realised what it was. You might not remember the scene in Mad Max where the young Aussie policeman is shown his new toy (a V8 Ford Falcon with very large super-charger). The police chief, I seem to recall, asks the mechanic to "Tell him about the blower!" And that, in a sad little way, describes the adolescent joy of having a car with a turbo-charger that kicks in and whistles at you while it's doing it.

The criticisms are not really mine. One friend who borrowed it said the diesel engine was noisy in traffic jams. And we both managed to ground it easily on speed bumps, which meant taking them a little gingerly. Another friend said that Alfas drive "light" - at high speeds with a full load on a bouncy motorway they are less stable. When weighed down with a full number of passengers it was certainly harder to handle. Alfa says it can optionally be fitted with a "sophisticated Boge-Nivomat self-levelling hydropneumatic rear suspension system", which adjusts the suspension to the load, apparently.

At first thought, a sports estate doesn't seem to make much sense. Who is it aimed at? The cheaper end of the "lifestyle estate market", according to Alfa. "Sportwagon customers will tend to lead busy, active lives." Maybe. I think it's aimed at compromise car owners like me who want to know that the motor has the capacity to transport a large number of old doors down to the dump or, say, a small coffin, or even to be able to sleep in the back. That security of size, but with it the fantasy of a speedy little number like a Z8 or MGF that goes round corners like a race car.

If I had £19,000 or so to spend on a car, then this would be very tempting. I didn't really want to give it back. In fact, I didn't. But then they sent a man round.

The lowdown

Alfa Romeo Sportwagon diesel

Price:
£19,285 (highest spec without leather interior)

Acceleration:
0-62 in 9.9 seconds

Top speed:
126mph

Consumption:
41.5 mpg (combined)

Where to go:
Italian Alps

What to put on the stereo:
Ride on Time by Black Box

Who drives it:
Blokes

webTitle: Protest in Prague Opinions on globalisation are shifting

fields.headline: Protest in Prague Opinions on globalisation are shifting
fields.trailText: Many predictions have been made of violence from the protesters gathering in Prague this week ahead of the autumn meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). But there is more on their websites about banner-making than about gas masks. Since the dramatic scenes in Seattle last November, there has been a tendency to pour scorn on the demonstrators' incoherent critique of globalisation.
fields.body:
Many predictions have been made of violence from the protesters gathering in Prague this week ahead of the autumn meetings of the World Bank and the International Monetary Fund (IMF). But there is more on their websites about banner-making than about gas masks. Since the dramatic scenes in Seattle last November, there has been a tendency to pour scorn on the demonstrators' incoherent critique of globalisation. But that misses the bigger point. Their demonstrations sent shockwaves through governments and they succeeded in focusing attention on issues such as the legitimacy of the IMF, and the clash between World Trade Organisation rules and UN environmental conventions. It is paying off. A dramatic shift is developing in the climate of discussion and policy-making on globalisation.

Evidence for this can be found in two reports published last week. The more important is the Bank's World Development Report. It acknowledges revolutionary concepts, such as the fact that economic growth does not automatically reduce poverty, and states that inequality is bad for growth. Most controversially, it recognises that poverty is not simply an economic problem but a polit ical one. Sadly, many aid agencies have belittled the Bank's shift, preferring condemnation to the slow, difficult process of reform.

One of the Bank's toughest critiques is of the world's trading system - it claims that $63bn a year is lost by poor countries due to agricultural protectionism - and trade is also the subject of a report published last week by the Performance and Innovation Unit (part of the Cabinet Office). Here, for the first time, the UK government is grappling with the issues identified by demonstrators and non-governmental organisations. For example, it acknowledges that there are serious environmental costs to trade liberalisation. This honesty surfaces only in the text; unfortunately, the recommendations can be broadly summarised as a smug business as usual. That trick will not wash in the white paper on globalisation being drawn up in the Department of International Development and due out on the first anniversary of Seattle. The pressure is mounting on the policy makers to produce convincing responses to the accusations which will be aired in Prague over the next fortnight that global capitalism is failing the vast bulk of the world's population.

webTitle: Oxfam calls for better debt management

fields.headline: Oxfam calls for better debt management
fields.standfirst:
Special report: debt relief
Jubilee 2000
fields.trailText: The World Bank and the IMF are "exaggerating" how much their flagship debt relief programme has reduced the loans burden on the world's poorest nations, a report by Oxfam claims today. The report shows that several countries are leaving the programme paying more to their creditors than before they entered it.
fields.body:
The World Bank and the IMF are "exaggerating" how much their flagship debt relief programme has reduced the loans burden on the world's poorest nations, a report by Oxfam claims today. The report shows that several countries are leaving the programme paying more to their creditors than before they entered it.

The aid agency is calling for radical reform of the heavily indebted poor countries initiative (HIPC), which it says has failed to deliver real benefits to some of the world's most impoverished nations.

Most countries will still be paying more to their western creditors than they do on health and education and some will actually see their interest payment rise on completion of the debt relief programme. Oxfam figures show that Tanzania, Zambia and Senegal will be paying more to the Bank and the IMF after debt relief than before, and that the annual budget savings for other countries will be "modest".

"It is economically ruinous and morally indefensible for Zambia to spend 40% of its budget paying back the rich world when chronic malnutrition of its children is on the rise and 73,000 die each year before the age of five," said Kevin Watkins, senior policy analyst at Oxfam, and the report's author. "The debt relief package urgently needs root and branch reform.It was de vised to reduce poverty but in some cases it will have limited benefits for the poor."

Oxfam says that the Bank and IMF claim that HIPC has wiped $28bn(£20bn) off poor country debts as "grossly exaggerated".

Western leaders will face pressure to offer a better deal on debt relief at this week's annual meetings of the Bank and IMF in Prague. The city is bracing itself for large protests with debt one of the concerns motivating the demonstrators.

webTitle: Yates postmortem test 'inconclusive'

fields.headline: Yates postmortem test 'inconclusive'
fields.trailText: The results of the postmortem on the body of Paula Yates, who was found dead at her home yesterday morning, were "inconclusive", Scotland Yard said today.
fields.body:
The results of the postmortem on the body of Paula Yates, who was found dead at her home yesterday morning, were "inconclusive", Scotland Yard said today.

A spokesman said they were now awaiting the results of further tests to establish how exactly the television presenter died.

The 40-year-old former wife of Sir Bob Geldof, partner of late INXS frontman Michael Hutchence and mother of four children, had been discovered in bed at her mews house in Notting Hill, west London, at about 10.15am yesterday.

A police spokesman said they were now awaiting the results of further tests to establish how exactly the television presenter died. Her body was found by a friend at her mews home in Notting Hill, west London.

Despite reports that Yates, 40, may have had a drugs overdose - there was said to have been a jar of prescribed pills, a vodka bottle and heroin beside her bed - there was no suicide note, leading to speculation that her death was accidental.

The friend had reportedly phoned the house and spoken to Yates's four-year-old daughter, Tiger Lily, who said she could not wake her mother.

webTitle: Government's response to oil crisis

fields.headline: Government's response to oil crisis
fields.standfirst:
The government is planning to rush through a new law which will force Britain's oil companies to maintain supplies. Brian Whitaker explains the reasons behind it
Special report: the petrol war
Special report: human rights in the UK
fields.trailText: The government is planning to rush through a new law which will force Britain's oil companies to maintain supplies. We explain the reasons behind it.
fields.body:
Why is the government taking this action?
Because petrol stations ran out of supplies when protesters complaining about high prices picketed oil depots. The picketing was largely peaceful but there were fears for tanker drivers' safety, and so deliveries stopped.

The protesters have called off their action and petrol supplies are returning to normal, but the demonstrators have threatened to resume their protests if the government does not take action on petrol prices within 60 days.

How will the new law work?
Oil companies will have a legal duty to maintain supplies. There were suspicions during the recent crisis that oil companies were not trying hard enough to deliver petrol to the filling stations. The new law will put them in the same position as other services which are considered essential, such as gas, electricity and water.

Will this action prevent another petrol crisis?
Not on its own. A lot of the tanker drivers are self-employed and would probably not be covered by the new law.

But the government plans other steps to deal with that. One is to make more use of army tankers to deliver petrol in any future emergency, and the number of soldiers trained to do this will be increased from 80 to several hundred. There will also be talks between the government and the oil companies to draw up an agreement about how to maintain deliveries if there are similar problems in future.

Is this really necessary?
The crisis showed how much we all depend on petrol, even if we don't drive a car. People could not get to work, food supplies to the shops were threatened, health services were disrupted, and some schools were closed. Even larger fuel protests in other European countries - especially France and Belgium - have shown how much disruption can be caused, and the British government wants to avoid "copycat" actions here.

Is it going to be controversial?
Water, gas and electricity are already covered by similar laws, but the question is how to define which services are essential. Should there, for instance, be laws to ensure that supplies of milk and bread - as well as petrol - are maintained? Any extension of the law in this area may be for the general good of society but it is bound to restrict civil liberties - for example, people's right not to work or the right not to sell things if they don't want to.

webTitle: QC calls Camelot's omission "grossly unfair"

fields.headline: QC calls Camelot's omission "grossly unfair"
fields.trailText: The Lottery Commission's decision to negotiate solely with Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery over the grant of a new licence was "grossly unfair", QC David Pannick told the High Court today.
fields.body:
The Lottery Commission's decision to negotiate solely with Sir Richard Branson's People's Lottery over the grant of a new licence was "grossly unfair", the High Court heard today.

David Pannick QC, for Camelot, told Mr Justice Richards that it was like getting to the end of the World Cup Final with the scores 0-0 and only one side being allowed to take penalties in the shoot-out.

Camelot, the current operators, was one of two bidders for a new, seven-year licence to operate the National Lottery from 1 October 2001.

Last month, the commission rejected both bids, but entered into a new process engaging in exclusive negotiations with the People's Lottery. It gave the Virgin tycoon a month to come up with a guaranteed £50 million contingency fund to back up his bid in the event of low revenues or unforeseen costs.

Mr Pannick said that Camelot's rival was given a chance to allay the commission's concerns, but Camelot had no such opportunity.

He added: "Our case is that this is an unfair procedure. It will not assist the legal argument to describe it as manifestly or grossly unfair - but that is what it is... We can find no precedent for such behaviour.

"It is, we suggest, as if at the end of the football World Cup final, when the score is 0-0 and the match is to be decided by a penalty shoot-out, the referee decides that only one team shall be allowed to take the penalties."

Mr Pannick said that the commission had declined to make available to Camelot "and more importantly to the court" the minutes of its contemporaneous decision to adopt this "bizarre" procedure.

He called this "a quite remarkable position, given the state of public law in the 21st century, for a public body to adopt." In the hearing, which is expected to last into tomorrow, Camelot is asking for the commission's decision to be quashed and for a declaration that it was unlawful.

It is also seeking an injunction restraining the commission from granting a new licence until Camelot has had a fair opportunity of seeking to allay concerns about the perceived defects of its bid.

Mr Pannick said that Camelot had operated the lottery with "conspicuous success" raising over £8.8bn for good causes. He said that the perceived defects in the Camelot bid related to the integrity of GTech, their supplier of gaming software and terminals.

Camelot believed they could allay the commission's concerns were they given a fair chance because they had agreed in principle with GTech that, from the start of the new licence period, Camelot would operate the Lottery independently. It would purchase all the relevant terminals and software from GTech and would take over the employment of all relevant UK based GTech staff.

"Even if we can't (allay their fears), we are still entitled to a good-faith attempt by the commission to listen to what we want to say... You can't shut out someone from the outset from the opportunity to put his case."

In defence of its decision, the commission had said that the deficiencies in the Camelot bid were not capable of being addressed within a month, while those of their competitor "probably" were.

Mr Pannick said that Camelot thought they had met the commission's concerns over GTech.

He claimed the company was "misled" that this was no longer an issue at the same time as the commission was "bending over backwards" to give positive assistance to the People's Lottery as to what they needed to do.

He said the commission's Dame Helena Shovelton had telephoned Sir Richard at his private Caribbean island during the summer to underline the seriousness of what the commission wanted from his bid.

Fairness required that Camelot should have been given similar assistance in July and early August and should now be given additional time to satisfy the commission.

webTitle: Charity channel launches in the UK

fields.headline: UK's first charity channel launches
fields.trailText: 1pm: Charities get the chance to screen videos of their work on the first UK charity channel, The Community Channel, writes Maggie Brown.
fields.body:
Today sees the launch of the Community Channel, which offers charities their first chance to screen videos of their work and appeal for members and funds.

Styling itself as the first "ethical shopping channel", the service offers items such as charity Christmas cards, CDs and goods from the developing world direct to customers. The Red Cross, for example, is marketing a first aid kit for travellers at £7.95, while Traidcraft has a set of wooden dominoes for £12.

The channel can be found on Sky Digital (number 655) between 1pm and 4pm each afternoon, and 24 hours a day on the internet.

More than 50 charities, large and small, are taking part during the first six months, including Oxfam, the National Trust, the Cats Protection League, Drake Music Project (with Jools Holland) and Headway.

Programming is produced by independent Mentorn Barraclough Carey and includes interviews with celebrity guests. The aim, says managing director Gerard Melling (a former editor of GMTV), is to make something enjoyable to watch, without the tone of either a permanent TV telethon or continual doom and gloom footage.

Smaller charities will be helped to make programming for the channel. But those on air will have to show they can handle enquiries from viewers - because it is available nationally, local charities are not deemed suitable for airtime.

The channel operates under a teleshopping licence, like shopping channel QVC, which should help it to become self-financing by taking ads, sponsorship or a cut from sales.

The project is pioneered by Media Trust chief executive Caroline Diehl, with chairman Michael Green of Carlton Communications, and has the backing of culture minister Chris Smith. It has received grants from the National Lotteries Charities Board, the government's Active Community Unit and the department for international development.

BSkyB, which has a social marketing wing that backs community projects, has given the channel free carriage for three years. ONdigital and cable are expected to follow at some point.

Mark Sharman, BSkyB director of broadcasting, says: "We take our responsibility to the community very seriously. This is also a perfect marriage for us: it shows what digital is all about."

webTitle: Talks resume between US actors' unions and ad industry to end dispute

fields.headline: US actors' unions resume talks with ad industry
fields.trailText: Actors' unions in the US have resumed full-scale talks with the advertising industry in a move that could see an end to the bitter five-month strike.
fields.body:
Actors' unions in the US have resumed full-scale talks with the advertising industry in a move that could see an end to the bitter five-month strike.

The Screen Actors' Guild and the American Federation of Television & Radio Artists said they were sending "full negotiating committees" to New York today to discuss a solution to the long-running dispute. Mediators have imposed a gagging order on both parties, preventing them from giving further details, but the fact that the unions are prepared to negotiate suggests advertisers may have softened their stance.

The dispute began when advertisers said they were planning to change the way they pay actors, proposing a single up-front fee. Until now, actors have been paid according to how often the ad airs.

A number of celebrity actors have added their support to the strike, boosting its profile and putting additional pressure on the advertising industry. George Clooney, Tom Hanks, Paul Newman and Susan Sarandon have all given their support, either financially or by giving speeches.

webTitle: 10m viewers tune in to watch Big Brother victor

fields.headline: Craig's Big Brother victory wins 10m viewers for Channel 4
fields.trailText: Craig's Big Brother victory gave Channel 4 its highest ever Friday night ratings last week, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Craig's Big Brother victory gave Channel 4 its highest ever Friday night ratings last week, when nearly 10m viewers tuned in to watch the loveable scouser collect his £70,000.

The show attracted 7.5m for its 8.30pm start, giving it a 31% share. But this rose to 9.9m when the winner was announced at 11.15pm, giving Channel 4 a huge 56% share of the viewing.

BBC1 and ITV both fell victim to Big Brother's success, with ITV's big Friday night film, Twister, attracting a disappointing 5.8m viewers. BBC1 scarcely managed to take 25% of the viewing on Friday evening, with even the ever-popular Parkinson peaking at 5.7m viewers (25%).

The end of Big Brother and the 3.4m inherited viewers who stayed with Channel 4 after the end of the show to watch South Park hit BBC1's Olympic coverage. Olympic Grandstand averaged just 2.6m viewers, giving it a 25% share, although it reached a peak of 3.5m at 11.45pm, as Big Brother ended.

The BBC's late-night Olympic coverage continued to suffer on Saturday and Sunday from scheduling difficulties due to the time difference with Sydney. But its daytime repeats proved much more popular. The opening ceremony, broadcast on BBC1 Friday morning, attracted a healthy 3.2m viewers to give the channel a 53% share. BBC1 broadcast Olympic Grandstand all day, averaging 2.6m viewers to give it a 34% share.

The success of the Saturday night schedules was BBC1's relaunched Casualty. The first in a new series of the long-running hospital drama attracted 9m viewers, giving the channel a 40% share. And 7.8m viewers stuck with BBC1 for Night of 1,000 Shows, a celebration of the 40th anniversary of BBC Television Centre presented by Michael Parkinson.

The appeal of Big Brother was finally waning by Saturday night, when Channel 4 broadcast a final all-night special dedicated to the show. Inside Big Brother attracted 2.8m viewers to give the channel a 13% share, still well up on what it would normally get on a Saturday evening.

Sunday saw the return of BBC1's Castaway to the schedules. Whether it was due to Big Brother fatigue or a failure to retain enthusiasm after a break from the airwaves, the show made a disappointing debut, attracting 5.6m viewers to give it a 23% share. ITV was Sunday's star performer, kicking off the evening with 8.4m viewers for the ever-popular Kids Say the Funniest Things at 7pm and racking up an impressive 13.5m for Who Wants to be a Millionaire? at 8pm. ITV retained its lead later in the evening with a new crime thriller, My Fragile Heart, which attracted 9.4m viewers to give it a 41% share.

webTitle: New GWR ad technology

fields.headline: GWR technology to offer closely targeted ads on the web
fields.trailText: GWR is to introduce ground-breaking technology that allows companies to insert closely targeted ads into its streamed broadcasts.
fields.body:
Radio group GWR is to introduce ground-breaking technology that allows companies to insert closely targeted ads into its streamed broadcasts.

The service will enable advertisers to target internet radio listeners according to their age, sex and location. Listeners are asked to reply to a number of questions when they first log on to the radio station.

GWR has linked up with US technology company Hiwire to provide a service that will be available for all streamed radio output from Classic FM and other GWR brands. Hiwire claims to be the only company that can target ads in a live stream.

The ads will be sold on GWR's internet service by the company's sales house, Opus, and 24/7 Media, which sells banner ads on GWR's website.

GWR's commercial director, Simon Ward, said: "Streaming technology and one-to-one broadcasting is an extremely expensive business, but by offering advertisers the opportunity to reach every listener with specific ads, we can take their ads into a new and far more economic dimension, while at the same time enhancing the experience for our listeners.

"At a time of media fragmentation, UK radio continues to demonstrate its adaptability, its flexibility and its ability to use new technology to break though global barriers."

webTitle: Sony UK  boss hired by Trinity Mirror Newspapers

fields.headline: Trinity Mirror Newspapers hires Sony UK boss
fields.trailText: 1.45pm The managing director of Sony UK, Joe Sinyor, is to join Trinity Mirror as chief executive, reports Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
The managing director of Sony UK, Joe Sinyor, is to join Trinity Mirror as chief executive, newspapers, the company has announced.

Sinyor, who has no previous newspaper management experience, will take responsibility for all Trinity Mirror's newspaper operations.

The move is designed to free up Trinity Mirror chief executive Philip Graf to concentrate on expanding Trinity Mirror's business through acquisitions in the regional press and new media launches.

Trinity Mirror has pulled out of negotiations for Regional Independent Media, the largest remaining independent regional newspaper group, but has said it is interested in individual parts of the RIM empire, and has sought permission from the DTI to acquire the group's Lancashire-based titles.

The appointment follows a management reshuffle last week, during which Roger Eastoe, who was in charge of national newspapers, and Mike Masters, group managing director, left the company.

Paul Sullivan, media analyst at Merryl Lynch, anticipated a cautious welcome from the City, saying that Sinyor is "well regarded".

webTitle: The dead list

fields.headline: The dead list
fields.standfirst: Pay your rent, pay your employees, spend less than you earn and come up with a good idea. That way your e-business may avoid an appearance in one of a rash of sites specialising in blowing the whistle on dead and dying dot.coms. By David Rowan
fields.trailText: A rash of sites specialise in blowing the whistle on dead and dying dot.coms. By David Rowan.
fields.body:
Failure has its price. For Philip Kaplan, that price hovered last week anywhere between tens of thousands of dollars and $10m. As founder and owner of dot.com deathwatch site FuckedCompany.com, a satire of the gung-ho business magazine Fast Company, Kaplan has discovered how to capitalise on the latest new-economy trend: chronicling the terminal decline of other websites.

Visitors to the site place bets on which companies they believe will be next to fire staff, restructure or ultimately close down, and points are awarded each time the bad news is confirmed. As the rules state, "a company is officially 'fucked' when they do something that signals - or attempts to correct - impending doom", with one point awarded for minor layoffs, and 100 for "an all-out corporate slaying". Beyond the game, however, it is the 300-400 daily "news tips" from readers that have attracted almost 6m page views each week, from more than 124,000 unique users, seeking news and rumours of the latest failed start-ups.

That is the sort of traffic most companies listed in the "deadpool" would have paid millions to acquire - which is why, last week, Kaplan decided to auction his site on eBay.

A $10m bid later proved a hoax, but Kaplan says his whimsical decision to sell - because he was "bored" running the one-man site in his spare time - is attracting some genuine offers from serious players. "I have a few offers ranging from $500k to $3m, and am discussing terms with all of them," he says. He admits that he has moved away from his original pledge on the site that "I don't make - and don't plan to make - any money from it" and now insists that "the future of the site is very important to me - not just the money".

Certainly there appears to be no shortage of candidates for inclusion in the site's message boards. The demise of boo.com, clickmango and APBnews.com may have made headlines this summer, but Kaplan's site, and a growing number of rivals, would wish to remind you that the list also includes Auctions.com, audiocafe.com, BBQ.com, beautyscene, carOrder.com, CookExpress.com, CraftShop.com, FooFoo.com, freewwweb, Gazelle.com, Hardware.com, Reel.com healthshop.com, living.com, Pandesic, Petstore.com, Pixelon, toysmart.com and Value America - followed by an ever-growing list of others.

You can study a fuller list on FuckedCompany's sister site, dotcomfailures.com (motto: "Kick 'em while they're down"), whose "dead list" claims to be definitive, and whose rumour boards were last week alleging that Oxygen and Urbanfetch may ultimately be joining them. Coincidentally, dotcomfailures.com was proud last week to lead its front page with news of its own closure, "three months and $2.6m (actually it's closer to $140) later..."

Ryan Nitz, the man behind dotcomfailures.com (and a friend of Kaplan), had a simple reason for closing the site: "I'm not having fun any more," he explains. "I want to contribute more positively to the industry. It's really easy to point out the weaknesses of others; learning from the mistakes of others and building a company are very difficult tasks." Now, he says, he wants "a more honest challenge", in which he will apply his knowledge of company failures to his own business "and hopefully will not make the same mistakes".

That, however, will not silence the rumour-mongers. They can still post their unverified claims on dotcomdoom.com, which claims to be "the largest portal on the downturn, demise and doom of dot.coms", but in fact turns out to offer a combination of web search results and news feeds supplied by Moreover.com. More worrying for the PR departments of hard-hit start-ups is Need to Know , the "weekly hi-tech sarcastic update for the UK", which regularly publicises the winners of its Falco award. A Falco - named after the late Austrian techno-rap singer whose greatest hit was Rock Me Amadeus - is given to those who correctly predict the demise of technology start-ups. Recent winners predicted the problems of the-bullet.com and recordtv.com, as well as a site called Flake.com, a portal for those interested in breakfast cereal. "I like breakfast cereal like the next guy," noted Need to Know's author, "but sites like these make me so angry - not to mention VCs 'venture capitalists'; who support crap like this." It currently predicts a future Falco to those who back Bango.net, "which owns what has to be the dumbest idea we've heard since Real Names. Real Names, you may recall, was the plan to replace domain names with . . . more names. Bango's ruse is to replace domain names with numbers 'for Wap phones'."

So how can a company avoid being F***ed - the cautious way US newspapers refer to the practice? "Easy question, easy answer," says Philip Kaplan. "Pay your rent, pay your employees, spend less than you earn, and - most importantly - come up with a good idea, and do it first. Just like any other business." Ryan Nitz also counsels caution over extravagance: "Trim the fat and be realistic," he says. "Experience is probably one of the best resources you can purchase in this industry."

They can also learn from the examples of leaked memos and press releases, archived on the sites, which could only ever hinder their companies' prospects. This one, for instance, which FuckedCompany.com calls "the best press release ever": "All of the directors and officers of US Digital Communications, Inc have resigned, effective immediately. Presently the company has no employees, officers, or directors. The corporation has no assets, no revenues, and no money to continue in business. In addition, the corporation does not have the capability to transact business in the future." Concise, if somewhat futile.

Others, however, question just how helpful the dot.com death-watchers are once the joke wears off. Nicholas Hall, whose site StartupFailures.com calls itself "the place for bouncing back", says they provide no lasting benefit simply by showing "that someone else is worse off than you". "Society has certainly created a space for the doom-mongers, but I don't believe they make a positive contribution to our society," he reflects from his base near San Francisco, where he is president of the Silicon Valley association of software entrepreneurs.

Hall's site - which resulted from his own three failed start-ups, in the web, drinks and financial-services industries - is building what he hopes will be a successful business out of supporting those who have failed. It offers job listings, "entrepreneur coaching" and discussions of lessons learned, as well as community support that battles the stigma of failure (as the site pro claims, "the only true failure is never trying"). "I believe in the spirit of the entrepreneur and want to do what I can to continue to foster that spirit," Hall says defiantly. He does not see FuckedCompany.com's current strategy as necessarily helpful. "To me, they are attempting to cash in on a hot property. I can't blame them for trying, but to put the site up for sale on eBay because they are bored..."

Kaplan, meanwhile, says he has no worries about the other competitors entering his space. "We're seeing the shakeout of day-late, dollar-short FuckedCompany.com copycats," he notes bullishly. "Ironically, FuckedCompany.com proves the point that there's only room for one. Original, well thought-out ideas will be rewarded and impostors won't last."

 David Rowan is editor of Guardian Unlimited

webTitle: Wireless Group losses rise

fields.headline: Wireless Group losses increase
fields.trailText: The Wireless Group, the commercial radio company run by former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie, has deepened its losses since floating on the Stock Exchange.
fields.body:
The Wireless Group, the commercial radio company run by former Sun editor Kelvin MacKenzie, has deepened its losses since floating on the Stock Exchange.

The owner of the TalkSport radio station reported first-half losses of £25.7m, against a loss of £10.1m during the same period last year. The group said the losses stemmed from this year's relaunch of the station and buying sports rights, despite raising £6m when it floated in May.

The group was boosted by the acquisition of The Radio Partnership and Independent Radio Group last year, with turnover rising from £4.2m to £13.8m. It has joined forces with publisher and broadcaster Emap, media group SMG, radio group GWR and mobile phone retailer Carphone Warehouse to form the Digital Radio Group, which will bid for regional digital radio licences.

Kelvin MacKenzie, Wireless Group chairman, said: "We continue to invest in the future of TalkSport and in the reorganisation of our local radio stations. As well as organically, our strategy is to grow by acquisitions.

"Looking forward, the development of our valuable position in the radio market will ensure that the Wireless Group is well positioned for the future."

The shares have been popular since their listing, rising from 190p to 266.5p.

webTitle: Sudden death shocks friends

fields.headline: Sudden death shocks friends
fields.standfirst:
Paula Yates dies.
Body found in London house.
fields.trailText: Scotland Yard was last night investigating the death of Paula Yates, the television celebrity, whose body was found at her home.
fields.body:
Scotland Yard was last night investigating the death of Paula Yates, the television celebrity, whose body was found at her home.

Police said Yates, the former wife of Bob Geldof and a mother of four children, had been discovered in bed at her mews house in west London at about 10.15am yesterday by a friend.

An ambulance crew was called, but it was thought that Yates, 40, had been dead for some time.

As a private ambulance drove the body away, Detective Inspector Mike Christensen said there had been no signs of violence in the house, but until the cause of death was known he was treating it as suspicious.

He added: "I'm not sure whether the children were there or not, but they are being looked after now."

In 1998 Yates attempted to take her own life, and she had a history of drug abuse for which she received treatment.

However last week it appeared that she was preparing to forgo the turbulent London lifestyle that sparked sometimes lurid tabloid headlines and retreat to a house she had bought near Robertsbridge, East Sussex.

Last night her eldest daughter, Fifi Trixibelle,17, went to the scene of her mother's death to lay yellow flowers. With Boomtown Rats singer Geldof, Yates had Fifi Trixi belle, Peaches, 10, and Pixie, seven. Her fourth daughter, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily, four, was fathered by INXS frontman Michael Hutchence.

Yates first found fame as a co-presenter on Channel 4's groundbreaking music show The Tube, and later on the channel's Big Breakfast.

Her troubled private life became tabloid fodder after she left Geldof for Hutchence. His suicide devastated Yates, as did the revelation that her real father was the TV presenter Hughie Green, and not Jess Yates, whose name she bore.

Issuing a statement on behalf of his family, Geldof appealed for privacy. "We are all so sad. The loss for all the children is insupportable.

"It doesn't require much imagination to understand the pain. Please do nothing to add to that. Leave them [the children] with their loss and Paula with her dignity."

Paula's mother, Hélène Thornton-Bosment, from whom she was estranged, said she was "devastated" after learning of her daughter's death.

"This has come as a terrible shock to everyone," Mrs Thornton-Bosment said from her home in the south of France.

Musician Jools Holland, Yates's co-host on The Tube, said he was "deeply saddened" by the loss of a dear friend. "All my thoughts go to the family at this extremely difficult time," he said.

Since Hutchence was found hanged in a hotel room in Sydney three years ago Yates had been suffering from depression, and was treated in private clinics on several occasions. In 1998 there were reports that she had tried to hang herself but had been saved by a friend.

Her attempts to rebuild her shattered life suffered a blow a month ago with the collapse of Aura magazine where she had been an agony aunt.

Neighbours in the cobbled mews street in Notting Hill where Yates had lived for the past year were shocked by news of her death. Sharon Bhalla, who runs the local post office with her husband Moni, said she had bought an interior design magazine in the shop on Saturday and had been joking with Tiger Lily and Mr Bhalla.

"She seemed quite happy," Ms Bhalla said.

Zahid Shafi, the owner of a nearby convenience store, said Yates had recently visited the shop up to seven times a day to buy miniature bottles of vodka. The final trip had been made the night before she died, he said.

Police said a postmortem examination would be carried out today to establish the cause of death.

webTitle: Mandela to boost Labour party morale on conference stage

fields.headline: Mandela to boost Labour party morale on conference stage
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Nelson Mandela is to provide Labour with an important pre-election boost when he takes centre stage at the party's annual conference in Brighton next week.
fields.body:
Nelson Mandela is to provide Labour with an important pre-election boost when he takes centre stage at the party's annual conference in Brighton next week.

The former South African president, who is admired throughout the Labour movement for his lifelong struggle against apartheid, will give his personal seal of approval to Tony Blair on the final day of the conference.

Mr Mandela will be followed on stage by the deputy prime minister, John Prescott, who will try to galvanise party supporters with a barnstorming speech at Labour's last conference before the general election.

The appearance of one of the world's most respected elder statesmen in Brighton will come as a welcome relief to Mr Blair as he struggles to regain his popularity after the collapse of Labour's opinion poll lead.

The Conservatives are likely to attack Labour for using such a respected figure in such a partisan way.

Mr Blair was strongly criticised when he claimed, in his speech to last year's Labour conference, that Mr Mandela had been imprisoned by the "forces of conservatism".

Mr Blair first met Mr Mandela when the statesman visited Britain in 1996.

"Nelson Mandela's welcome in the House of Commons was truly unforgettable. It made me want to cry," Mr Blair, who was leader of the opposition, said.

"The image it left with me was this one - Speaker Betty Boothroyd leading Mandela down the steps, a rather unlikely pair holding hands in a place and at a time of great solemnity."

Labour has strong links with the African National Congress. The former ANC leader Cyril Ramaphosa was appointed this year to act as one of two independent inspectors of IRA weapons dumps.

webTitle: Yates's post-mortem 'inconclusive'

fields.headline: Yates's post-mortem 'inconclusive'
fields.standfirst: Sudden death shocks friends
fields.trailText: 2.45pm update: Police have said they do not yet know what killed Paula Yates after a post-mortem examination proved inconclusive, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Police have said they do not yet know what killed Paula Yates after a post-mortem examination carried out today proved inconclusive.

A spokeswoman for Scotland Yard said further tests were being carried out. Yates was found dead in her home in Notting Hill on Sunday morning. According to media reports, a half-empty bottle of painkillers lay beside her body and traces of heroin and cannabis were found on her bedside table.

An inquest into Yates's death will be opened at Westminster coroner's court on Wednesday.

webTitle: BSkyB denies Warner contract jeopardised

fields.headline: BSkyB denies Warner contract in jeopardy
fields.trailText: BSkyB has hit back at claims that its contract with Warner Movies has been jeopardised by dwindling movie audience figures.
fields.body:
BSkyB has hit back at claims by industry newsletter New Media Markets that its contract with Warner Movies was in doubt as a result of dwindling audience figures for its movie channels.

A BSkyB spokesman denied the claims and said that the contract with Warner Movies would be re-negotiated next year. BSkyB is confident it will be renewed.

NMM reported that Warner Brothers was planning to withdraw its top films from Sky's movie channels and was considering launching a movie channel in the UK in association with other studios. webTitle: Lembit Opik MP: 'Feels like I've been here a week'

fields.headline: 'Feels like I've been here a week'
fields.standfirst: Lembit Opik, MP for Montgomeryshire
fields.trailText: Monday: It already feels like I've been here a week. This is due to sleep deprivation and the pressure of a diary with no safety margins.
fields.body:
Monday: It already feels like I've been here a week. This is due to sleep deprivation and the pressure of a diary with no safety margins.

In other words, if I'm late for one thing, I'm late for all. The good news is I've had a result on my cosmic hobby horse - the threat of asteroid impact. The government has published a report confirming what I've been saying for two years - that the life-destroying impacts happen if we're up next for extinction.

It's nice to get a win at conference time because it makes you feel wanted.

So, overall a good start - but four days to go on the political tightrope, and it's always windy enough by the sea to cause an upset.

webTitle: Chairman of Bates Worldwide to step down

fields.headline: Bungey to step down as chairman of Bates Worldwide
fields.trailText: 9.45am: Michael Bungey, chairman and chief executive of Bates Worldwide, is to step down as chairman in the next 12 months, writes Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
Michael Bungey, chairman and chief executive of Bates Worldwide, is to step down as chairman in the next 12 months to focus on his group role at Cordiant Communications.

Bungey's heir apparent is Jean de Yturbe, the French-born chairman of Bates Europe, who is expected to take on the role of chairman within a year. He will also take on responsibility for developing CCG United, a new initiative designed to persuade Bates' clients to use Cordiant agencies for their other marketing functions, such as public relations and design.

Bungey will remain chief executive at Bates.

Ian Smith, group president of Bates in New York, will become chairman and chief executive of CCG.XM, Cordiant's e-business unit. And Bill Whitehead, group president of Bates and chief executive of Bates North America, will be appointed to the new posts of president and chief operating officer of Bates, reporting directly to Bungey.

webTitle: Asteroids

fields.headline: Asteroids
fields.trailText: All you need to know about Near Earth Objects, and how they could seriously spoil your day.
fields.body:
1. A British task force set up by science minister Lord Sainsbury has urged the government to take the lead in setting up an asteroid-watching agency.

2. Scientists - some of them, at any rate - are worried that an asteroid or some other Near Earth Object, in the jargon of the astrometrics trade, may collide with Earth.

3. The effects of such a collision could be very nasty indeed.

4. Asteroids and their cousins, comets and meteors, have played a spectacular leading role in what the boffins insist on calling collisional evolution.

5. Colossal collisions have been blamed for all manner of calamities: the sudden extinction of the dinosaurs, Noah's flood, the destruction of Atlantis, and the election of Margaret Thatch... whoops! Sorry, just kidding.

6. Seriously, the arrival at enormous speed of a socking great lump of rock or iron could be terminal for us all. The only problem is that the risk is awfully difficult to calculate, and estimates of it keep varying.

7. Asteroids are the loose cannon of the cosmos. And there are an awful lot of them, notably between Jupiter and Mars.

8. Space gazers are now able to study the impact of asteroids elsewhere in the Solar System.

9. The recent impact of the entertainingly named Shoemaker-Levy 9 asteroid on Jupiter resulted in some spectacular images.

10. Most sensible folk find asteroids scary. Others insist they are sexy.

webTitle: EMI in Warner merger rescue bid

fields.headline: EMI in Warner merger rescue bid
fields.trailText: Music group EMI has its final chance to rescue the £14bn merger with Warner Music today as executives meet the EU competition commissioner.
fields.body:
Music group EMI has its final chance to rescue the £14bn merger with Warner Music today as executives meet the EU competition commissioner.

The UK company must convince Mario Monti that the link-up will not lead to the merged outfit dominating the market for downloading music from the internet. The commission is also concerned that the joint venture would lead to four large companies controlling record prices.

The final deadline for submitting concessions is tomorrow, but today's meeting is seen as vital to the outcome of the deal.

Analysts have backed market whispers that EMI could be snapped up by German media giant Bertelsmann or Spanish telecoms company Telefonica if the deal falls through.

Helen Snell, an analyst at ABN Amro, said: "Telefonica has bought a TV company in Endemol, so it is buying content. EMI would be a very logical move. If the deal was lost, someone will undoubtedly bid for the company."

The EMI and Warner Music venture is a difficult one to call, as it is hard to measure market share in sectors such as music publishing. The lack of definitive data, such as viewing figures for TV companies, has complicated the issue.

The merger of Warner Music's parent company, Time Warner, with internet company AOL has also damaged the venture's chances of success. The EU is sceptical about AOL's assertion that it will not take advantage of an EMI and Warner merger to control the market for music downloads over the internet.

EMI shares rose 3.5p to 564.5p in early trading.

webTitle: Blair ally kept silent on loan to minister

fields.headline: Blair ally kept silent on loan to minister
fields.standfirst: Special report: New Labour in power
fields.trailText: Tony Blair's close friend, Lord Falconer, failed to inform him about Peter Mandelson's £373,000 home loan, a new book discloses.
fields.body:
Tony Blair's close friend, Lord Falconer, failed to inform him about Peter Mandelson's £373,000 home loan, a new book discloses.

Months before Mr Mandelson suffered his downfall, the dome minister, Lord Falconer, was given vital intelligence about the loan from the Labour MP for Swindon North, Michael Wills, one of Gordon Brown's closest allies.

Lord Falconer promised to remain silent, and the prime minister had no idea about the loan until a few days before Mr Mandelson's resignation from the cabinet, which happened in December 1998.

Lord Falconer was told about the loan during a holiday in Malaga, in the summer of 1998, according to the book by the Observer columnist, Andrew Rawnsley.

"Wills passed on word of Mandelson's loan," Rawnsley writes in Servants of the People. "Sworn to confidence, and not thinking it his place to raise it with Blair, Falconer kept the secret to himself. So Falconer, that best of chums, knew. Brown long knew [about the loan].

"Extraordinarily, the one person who had been kept in a state of complete ignorance was the prime minister."

Rawnsley describes how the prime minister exploded with rage when he finally learned of the loan which was given to Mr Mandelson by the former Treasury minister, Geoffrey Robinson. His financial generosity allowed Mr Mandelson to buy a £475,000 house in one of the smartest streets of London's Notting Hill.

"Jesus Christ, Peter! What a misjudgment," Rawnsley quotes the prime minister as saying.

Rawnsley reports that the prime minister moved with ruthless efficiency against his political soulmate when the loan was finally disclosed in the Guardian in December 1998. After Mr Mandelson failed in his attempt to hang on as trade and industry secretary, the prime minister made clear in a phone conversation that he would have to go, to lessen the damage to the government.

"By the end of the conversation tears were trickling down Mandelson's sepulchral white cheeks," Rawnsley writes. "A dark-eyed [Alastair] Campbell, himself blubbing, gave Mandelson a hug."

The book also quotes Downing Street aides and ministers using colourful language at the height of the crisis. Mr Campbell accused Mr Mandelson of being a "stupid c***".

When Mr Campbell interrupted the prime minister, as he finalised a Commons statement on Iraq, to tell him about the loan, Mr Blair reportedly asked him "why the fuck" he was dropping such a bombshell. Mr Campbell is reported to have shot back: "Because it can't fucking wait."

Ministers attempted yesterday to dismiss the Rawnsley book, saying that it was raking over old territory. There was support for Lord Falconer because he was told about the Mandelson loan during a casual holiday conversation and felt bound by his commitment to remain silent.

However, Rawnsley makes clear that supporters of Mr Brown leaked details about the loan, a claim that will do little to improve relations between the Blair and Brown camps.

Rawnsley writes: "How complicit was Gordon Brown in the immolation of his fellow minister and founder of New Labour? [A] member of the innermost circle, who has known Brown for more than a decade, says: 'Gordon is absolutely capable of it'. Even if the chancellor did not pull the trigger, he knew it was being squeezed. Whether or not he gave the precise instructions to strike against Mandelson, Brown willed the act."

webTitle: Jon Henley in Paris on the strange workings of the French courts

fields.headline: Rough Justice
fields.standfirst: Jon Henley in Paris on the strange workings of the French courts, and the president's belly
fields.trailText: Jon Henley in Paris on the strange workings of the French courts, and the president's belly
fields.body:
"The sentence pronounced this day is of a nature to finally make him see sense," opined the president of the court. So now you know, José Bové: a little principled and good-natured vandalism at a McDonald's restaurant that's not even built yet constitutes a most heinous crime in France.

So heinous, in fact, that it carries a penalty of three months in the slammer. Put that in your pipe and smoke it, Mr Down-with-globalisation, up-with-peasants'-rights Bové. If you think you can get away with taking a swing at Ronald McDonald in the birthplace of human rights, you've got another think coming.

The verdict handed down in Millau last week, against the jovial, moustached sheep farmer from the Larzac plateau whose colourful campaign against la malbouffe - crap food - has turned him into France's unlikeliest folk hero and a worldwide figurehead for the anti-globalisation movement, was so outrageous that even the magistrates complained about it.

"It is disproportionate in regard both to the reality of the crime, which was wholly non-violent, and to the context of this collective and popular protest," their union said in an unusual joint statement with the French barristers' association. "It is absurd, it is scandalous, and we denounce it wholeheartedly."

The workings of French justice are indeed strange. This month, in case you had forgotten, also saw very large parts of the country brought to a complete standstill by a blockade that was in flagrant contravention of half a dozen articles in the criminal and civil codes.

Hundreds of British tourists were stranded outside the mouth of the Channel tunnel behind barricades that broke EU law. Airports ran out of fuel and domestic flights were diverted to unheard-of bits of Germany and Switzerland where no self-respecting Frenchmen would ever willingly show his face.

And did the police intervene? They did not. Will there be a single court case? Of course not. Bové's mistake was to have protested on too small a scale and not to have made enough third parties suffer. Had he paralysed France and trashed a few ministers' offices into the bargain, he would almost certainly have got off with a £20 fine.

But rather than do things properly, last summer, in the company of nine fellow members of his Confédération Paysanne, Bové unscrewed a few window frames, pulled down a few uprights, and daubed a few slogans at a half-built McDonald's outside the small southwestern town of Millau.

The stunt was a symbolic protest at sky-high American import duties on treasured rural French delicacies like Dijon mustard, foie gras and Roquefort cheese, which Bové produces when he's not busy being a media darling. McDonald's was the well-chosen target because it stands for the three things Bové and his movement say are ruining small farmers everywhere: unfair American trade tactics; industrially produced, nutrition-free food; and the homogenising, globalising might of the multinationals.

Looking back, the whole affair was bathed in the atmosphere of a country fair. The police, forewarned, stood by and smiled. The media, forearmed, were there in force and applauded. A crowd of locals laughed and clapped. The genial Mr Bové sucked on his pipe and grinned.

When he was arrested and imprisoned a few days later, hundreds of well-wishers from France to Florida paid his £10,500 bail. He was lunched by the prime minister and dined by the president. At his trial last June, some 15,000 renegade revellers descended on Millau for two days of music, feasting and anti-capitalist fun.

This was, in short, a high-profile case involving a hugely popular figure who did nothing very wrong. He has, moreover, a serious point, and the French - in the wake of mad cows and dioxine-tainted chickens - have taken him to their hearts to the extent that even right-wing news magazines such as Marianne proclaim, quite seriously, "José for president".

So what on earth seized the judge? So far the Green party, the Communist party, the CGT trade union federation and three cabinet ministers have expressed their outrage at his verdict. Bové himself has appealed, as have two fellow conspirators who only got suspended sentences but are set on going to prison if he does.

"This was a classic opportunity for French justice to escape the Napoleonic confines, to show that it understands one man cannot be at the same time a friend of the people and an enemy of the law," commented a legal expert, Alain Duhamel. "It didn't. A couple of thousand francs, a symbolic fine for a symbolic crime, would have been right. Three months in prison is sheer shortsighted stupidity."

Are you all right, Jacques?

Is the president unwell? Rumours swirled round Paris last week that the famously bon vivant French head of state may be suffering from some as-yet-undisclosed malady after he returned from his hols even plumper than usual, then appeared to lose his voice during a speech.

"The presidential belly has raised questions about possible cortisone treatment," reported the responsible Le Monde, "and accounts of him frequently losing his voice have led to theories that he may have contracted throat cancer."

The health of the nation's leader is, of course, a topic of unusual interest in France. Two of Jacques Chirac's predecessors have tried to hide from the French public the fact that they were suffering from terminal illnesses during long periods of their terms at the Elysée Palace.

In 1996, François Mitterrand died of a prostate cancer that was diagnosed during the first of his two seven-year stints in office, but he somehow managed to conceal that for more than a decade by issuing downright lies through his chief medical officer.

And when, some 20 years earlier, Georges Pompidou suddenly started putting on lots of weight, rumours that his plumpness was related to medical treatment were persistently denied until the day he died of lymph node cancer in 1974.

Amid claims by another magazine (though quite how it came by the figure is anyone's guess) that he had gained 9lb since last seen in public, Chirac's aides have insisted that he just ate and drank rather more than usual during his controversial three-week holiday at the £2,000-a-night Royal Palm hotel in Mauritius.

"You know what he's like," said his daughter and spin doctor, Claude Chirac. "He does like his food. And he's not getting any younger. Plus he's had this voice problem for ages; it's an emotional thing. But he has been instructed to go on a diet."

The fact that his closest aides are suddenly citing Chirac's age - he will be 68 in November - as a plausible excuse for his paunch shows, however, just how desperate they are to dispel this particular rumour.

Until now the president, whose gourmet tastes are so pronounced that he once sent a state chef on a week-long trip to Italy to learn how to make a favourite dish of calf's liver, has played down his advancing years in the hope that his energetic bonhomie will persuade voters to give him a second term. If he's prepared to stress how old he is, he's clearly fighting fit.

 France is holding a referendum on the 24th of this month to decide whether or not to cut the presidential term from seven years to five. Apart from the fact that this would marginally increase the chances of the ageing Mr Chirac being re-elected, this is very boring news and has been received as such by the majority of the population who show no intention of voting.

What's less boring is that 250 of France's mayors, who are responsible for organising the poll, are refusing to play ball unless the government meets their very local demands, which range from stopping the extension of a rubbish dump to changing the route of a projected motorway. "In our country, you cannot make yourself heard using legal methods," said the mayor of Gap, Pierre Bernard-Reymond. He should know what he's talking about: he's a former cabinet minister.

Until now the president, whose gourmet tastes are so pronounced that he once sent a state chef on a week-long trip to Italy to learn how to make a favourite dish of calf's liver, has played down his advancing years in the hope that his energetic bonhomie will persuade voters to give him a second term. If he's prepared to stress how old he is, he's clearly fighting fit.  France is holding a referendum on the 24th of this month to decide whether or not to cut the presidential term from seven years to five. Apart from the fact that this would marginally increase the chances of the ageing Mr Chirac being re-elected, this is very boring news and has been received as such by the majority of the population who show no intention of voting. What's less boring is that 250 of France's mayors, who are responsible for organising the poll, are refusing to play ball unless the government meets their very local demands, which range from stopping the extension of a rubbish dump to changing the route of a projected motorway. "In our country, you cannot make yourself heard using legal methods," said the mayor of Gap, Pierre Bernard-Reymond. He should know what he's talking about: he's a former cabinet minister.

webTitle: Kennedy scorns Hague's 'headcase agenda'

fields.headline: Kennedy scorns Hague's 'headcase agenda'
fields.standfirst:
Special report: Charles Kennedy
Special report: Tories in opposition
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy yesterday launched his campaign to woo moderate Conservative voters when he denounced William Hague for promoting a "headcase agenda" that merely appeals to prejudice.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy yesterday launched his campaign to woo moderate Conservative voters when he denounced William Hague for promoting a "headcase agenda" that merely appeals to prejudice.

Buoyed by a weekend opinion poll which put the Liberal Democrats on 21% - their best rating since 1995 - the party's leader believes he can repeat this year's spectacular byelection win at Romsey across southern England by sticking to his liberal instincts on key issues such as tax and Europe.

As Liberal Democrat activists gathered in Bournemouth for their annual conference, Mr Kennedy's attack on the Tory leadership was notably more acerbic than his criticism of Tony Blair and his ministers for timidity and illiberalism since 1997.

"Disillusionment with the government is self-evident, but what we really must start confronting is the increasingly headcase agenda of William Hague," the Liberal Democrat leader told a pre-conference fringe meeting on a day when the government's trouble with petrol supplies pushed the Tories ahead of Labour in an opinion poll.

Mr Kennedy called that a mere "blip" and said it was amazing the lead was not bigger. But Mr Hague had ignored a leader's duty to seek consensus beyond his own party on issues such as asylum, crime and school discipline. Instead he was "bending to every passing crowd", Mr Kennedy protested.

The calculation that moderate Tories are open to Liberal Democrat wooing is a gamble since Kennedy strategists also plan to use this week to make the case for higher taxes to fund better public services.

Yesterday Mr Kennedy said he "does not give a damn" if journalists say his pledge to raise income tax to 50% on £100,000 a year salaries puts him to the left of Labour. He was doing it, he told reporters, in the interests of social justice, so that health, education and pensions could be improved.

Mr Kennedy will also embrace today's call in Bournemouth for the legalisation of gay marriage - "civil partnership" as the motion calls it. That, too, may alienate some Tories, although south coast resorts such as Bournemouth are increasingly keen on "pink pound" tourism. "I am in favour of total equality before the law," he said yesterday.

In an statement to the conference today on the fuel crisis he will offer a cap on petrol taxes - less than the cuts demanded by last week's pickets - in return for more of the revenue involved being spent on public transport and environmental improvements.

That, too, may be a gamble with current public impatience. But Mr Kennedy said yesterday that Tory voters are as worried as anyone else about the costs of university education for their children and care for their elderly parents. "They know you can't have something for nothing and we will get credit for being honest," he said.

In skirmishes with party activists and the media in Bournemouth yesterday, he brushed aside calls for the party to quit its joint consultative committee with Labour - Paddy Ashdown's brainchild - on the grounds that not even Lord Jenkins of Hillhead now believes Mr Blair will push through electoral reform for Westminister along the lines proposed by the Jenkins royal commission.

Mr Kennedy realises that he will not get referendums, this side of the election, on electoral reform or joining the euro. He says he believes in concentrating on "what is attainable, rather than what is not".

Pressed on the euro issue, Mr Kennedy told activists during two question and answer sessions that Mr Blair had told him privately that he could take on a Eurosceptic media or a Eurosceptic public. He quoted the prime minister as adding: "But I can't win a referendum with a Eurosceptic press and a Eurosceptic public."

Mr Kennedy's answer to that was to urge the government to start winning over public opinion, as press barons such as Conrad Black and Rupert Murdoch will not budge.

Bright sunshine and the prospect of little internal backbiting enhanced Mr Kennedy's optimism that he will get through his second conference as leader unscathed. "The mood is upbeat and positive," he told delegates.

In private session, the conference had earlier held a debate on plans to elect members of the party executive and policy making body by one member/one vote ballots, not by a vote of the conference.

webTitle: Bound and Gagged by Alan Travis: the net

fields.headline: Patrolling the internet
fields.standfirst:
The British government is preparing a legal framework to control what is available on the web. In an exclusive extract from his new book Bound and Gagged, the Guardian's home affairs editor Alan Travis argues that the trend is towards censorship rather than a libertarian approach.
Buy Bound and Gagged at BOL
Read extract one: The Lady Chatterley's Lover trial
Read extract two: The obscene publications squad
Read extract three: Film censorship
fields.trailText: The British government is preparing a legal framework to control what is available on the web. In an exclusive extract from his new book Bound and Gagged, the Guardian's home affairs editor Alan Travis argues that the trend is towards censorship rather than a libertarian approach.
fields.body:
Britain is on the verge of a new censorship debate, this time over how to regulate the content of the web.

A communications white paper will be published this autumn which will set the legal framework for delivery of net to every home in Britain within the next four years through the domestic digital television as well as the home computer.

Tony Blair has already said he worries about the kind of information that his three 'very computer-literate' children, Euan, Nicky and Kathryn, can find on the net.

"We try to keep a careful watch on what our children are getting access to on the internet. There are organisations that give advice to people, but it's very difficult if the parents aren't around watching what is going on. There are dangers. In the end I think it is more a matter for parents than for governments. We can do what we can, but it is down to parents," Blair has said.

For a politician this represents a very liberal stance compared with America and Australia where attempts to impose state regulation of the net have criminalised not only porn sites but also those which talk about safe sex and abortion as they curb offensive as well as obscene sites.

The Home Office insists that it is possible to enforce the current obscenity laws and ensure that "what is illegal offline is illegal online". So far ministers have been content to leave it to the British internet industry to develop its own self-regulation through the Internet Watch Foundation - a body similar to the British Board of Film Classification.

The IWF is at the centre of a government-backed effort to make sure that what is illegal is not available through the main servers, such as AOL, Demon, BT internet and the others, and that includes race hate material as well as hardcore porn.

Those who back the development of the rating and filtering systems that are used argue that for the first time it will give each family - rather than the state - the power to decide what kind of material should enter their home. But critics fear that the "wish of the lazy parent to allow unsupervised access to their children will reduce adult browsing to the level of suitability of a five year old." So far American and Australian politicians have not been able to resist the temptation. Will British ministers be any different?

webTitle: Ivory Coast's junta leader fights off attack

fields.headline: Ivory Coast's junta leader fights off attack
fields.trailText: Machine-gun fire echoed through the streets near the home of Ivory Coast's junta leader today, amid growing tensions in the military over pay disputes and deep political and ethnic divisions.
fields.body:
Machine-gun fire echoed through the streets near the home of Ivory Coast's junta leader today, amid growing tensions in the military over pay disputes and deep political and ethnic divisions.

But shortly after dawn the shooting stopped and civilians began venturing into the streets.

In a state radio broadcast, the information minister, Henri Cesar Sama, said that the private home of General Robert Guei, near the centre of the west African republic's capital, Abidjan, came under fire by "armed men, who were driven back by loyalist forces". Other officials said the attackers wore civilian clothing.

Sporadic shooting was also heard early today in other neighbourhoods around Abidjan. "The counter-attack was fatal, swift and hard," Mr Sama said, accusing "opportunists" of trying to destabilise the Ivory Coast.

Reinforcements were sent to Gen Guei's home to help defend it, officials said. Heavily armed soldiers in armored personnel carriers set up barricades outside the residence. Mr Sama insisted Gen Guei was safe and in control.

One person - apparently a soldier - was killed and four others injured in the fighting, one official said. The casualties could not be independently confirmed.

Speaking on condition of anonymity, a senior military official said the attackers had fled, after expressing anger at Gen Guei for declaring his candidacy in upcoming presidential elections.

Dissent has been growing among Ivorian soldiers, who were promised large bonuses in exchange for supporting the Christmas Eve coup that toppled the government of former president Henri Konan Bedie and brought Gen Guei to power. The bonuses have only been partially paid and different amounts were given to different units, increasing ill-feeling among the security forces.

Tensions have flared recently over the question of whether Alassane Dramane Ouattara, a popular opposition leader, will be allowed to run in the elections set for October 22.

The issue came into question after a new constitution was adopted following a referendum in early August. A last-minute amendment stipulates that both parents of presidential candidates be "of Ivorian origin" - a change widely believed to be aimed at excluding Mr Ouattara.

Mr Ouattara says both his parents were Ivorian. His opponents insist they were from Burkina Faso. Mr Ouattara is a former prime minister and International Monetary Fund official who has been a popular advocate for Ivory Coast's marginalised northern Muslims and large immigrant community.

An official with Mr Ouattara's party, the Rally of the Republicans, accused the military regime of issuing veiled threats against his party, and said he was worried that the government was using growing instability in Ivory Coast as a "pretext" to arrest the opposition leader.

There have been two military mutinies since the Christmas Eve coup, as the junta's initial burst of popularity waned. In early July, mutinous soldiers demanded housing bonuses worth £6,000 but eventually agreed to a sum of £1,000. Only a fraction of that amount has been paid.

Southern Ivorians, mainly Christian, have grown resentful of northern ethnic groups, mostly Muslim, increasing numbers of whom have seeking jobs and homes in the agriculturally-rich south.
