webTitle: How I took on Glenn McGrath - and won

fields.headline: How I took on Glenn McGrath - and won
fields.standfirst: Every Monday we go behind the scenes to get the lowdown on one of the county performances of the week. In the last of our series, we talk to Northamptonshire's reserve keeper, Toby Bailey, who took on Glenn McGrath, desperate to help Worcestershire to promotion from the second division of the County Championship - and came out on top
fields.trailText: Tobin Michael Barnaby Bailey - Toby for short - is Northamptonshire's No.2 wicketkeeper. Last week he got a rare chance to step in for the rested David Ripley, in the Championship match at Worcester. Against a fired-up Glenn McGrath he hit 96* - his highest score, passing the 38 he made against Oxford Universities earlier this year in a game Northants lost. Bailey takes up the story
fields.body:
Tobin Michael Barnaby Bailey - Toby for short - is Northamptonshire's No.2 wicketkeeper. Last week he got a rare chance to step in for the rested David Ripley, in the Championship match at Worcester. Against a fired-up Glenn McGrath he hit 96* - his highest score, passing the 38 he made against Oxford Universities earlier this year in a game Northants lost. Bailey takes up the story

"I had a sneaky suspicion that I might be playing in the match because we had already won [the second division of the County Championship] and we had a big [National League] game against Gloucestershire on the Sunday. I had my suspicions that Bob [Carter] wanted to rest Rips [David Ripley]. Plus I'd been keeping very well in the second team and been getting a few scores.

"I didn't really feel nervous going into the team. I've played a few times this season and everybody is very friendly. There was a different atmosphere this time round, more of a party atmosphere. We were a bit confident - I suppose you are when you've won the second division of the County Championship.

"We lost early wickets to a combination of Worcester bowling and the wicket, which was a green seamer. If you've got Glenn McGrath bowling at even 75% he will bowl sides out. I had never played him before but of course you know all about him because you see him on TV. I've faced quicker than him but he is dangerous because he gets so much bounce because of his height. He doesn't bowl any bad balls either.

"He bowled quite a lot when I was batting. He was their trump card really and they hammered him into the ground. Worcestershire had to win to be promoted. When I first went in the ball was doing quite a lot, and myself and Tony Penberthy were just trying to survive really. We rode our luck, perhaps until we both got to about 30, then as the ball got older it became easier. Then the tailenders managed to help me get through and batted really well.

"My favourite moment was when Glenn McGrath had a few words with me and then tried to bowl me a bouncer and I hooked him in front of square for four. Then he set me up for the hook shot again and bowled me two four balls which I hit through the covers for four. That produced one long stare. I had played and missed a few times early on but this was just one of those days when everything came off.

"The only time I really thought about getting a hundred was when I was on 96. Darren Cousins was at the other end and I just thought, please hold on for another over so I can get my 100. I wasn't really disappointed at the time when he got out, but later when I thought about it, I was. It would have been my maiden century in first-class cricket. But it was more important for the side to get runs.

"There was a little bit of celebrating when I got in but then they knocked me down. You know what cricketers are like - just because you've got some runs don't think you can blah blah blah.

"I didn't make any mistakes behind the stumps and caught three good catches which was good, because you really want to show people what you can do. I've been keeping well all season, but nobody really gets to see it when you don't play on the bigger stage.

I'd like to play for the first team next year but it is going to be very hard. David Ripley, the Northants wicketkeeper, is captain next year - so I've got my work cut out. I'll try to get runs in the second team: maybe I can get in as a specialist batsman. The Worcestershire second-team keeper [David Pipe] is playing as a batsman so there is no reason I can't do it. Would I consider changing counties? No."

Toby Bailey was talking to Tanya Aldred. To read last week's My Day in the Sun, in which Mark Butcher talks us through his 191 for Surrey against Durham, click here

webTitle: BT confirms talks with AT&T to strengthen links

fields.headline: BT confirms talks to strengthen links with AT&T
fields.trailText: BT confirmed that it is in talks with US telecoms company AT&T about strengthening the links between their business services divisions. By Dan Milmo.
fields.body:
BT failed to set the City alight after confirming that it is in talks with US telecoms company AT&T about strengthening the links between their business services divisions.

The company ended speculation about the nature of the negotiations when it released a statement saying it was seeking to broaden its relationship with AT&T in business services. The companies already work together in the Concert venture, designed for multinational business customers.

"These conversations are continuing and may or may not lead to any change in the existing alliance arrangements," said BT.

The vague announcement failed to affect BT's flat share price, however, which rose only 8p to 807.5p. BT is valued at around 1250p by most analysts after its less attractive assets are stripped out. The company will reveal which divisions are to be spun-off at the end of the year.

Nigel Hawkins, telecoms analyst at Wiliams de Broe, said: "It's rather like John Major, when he said 'nothing is ruled in and nothing is ruled out.' It's a holding statement."

BT is under pressure to float its newly-created mobile division, BT Wireless, but the market could become crowded, with similar plans underway at rivals Telefonica and Deutsche Telekom. The company's room for manoeuvre is restricted by debts of £28bn, with finance director Robert Brace committed to raising £10bn by the end of next year.

webTitle: Ulster TV posts first-half profit rise

fields.headline: Ulster TV 'open to offers' from ITV rivals
fields.trailText: Northern Irish broadcaster Ulster TV posted a rise in first-half profits and declared it is open-minded towards offers from rivals Granada Media or Carlton Communications.
fields.body:
Northern Irish broadcaster Ulster TV posted a rise in first-half profits and declared it is open-minded towards offers from rivals Granada Media or Carlton Communications.

Managing director John McCann said the company would consider any suitable offers.

Ulster is one of the few remaining independent ITV broadcasters, following the wave of consolidation that has swept the sector this year.

Mr McCann said: "We have some very committed shareholders here, but whether they will openly succumb to an offer from Granada or Carlton remains to be seen. There will be a single ITV sooner or later, but right now our future is in the hands of the shareholders."

Granada has close links with Ulster TV after proposing to buy a 45% stake in Irish broadcaster TV3 last week. Canadian media group CanWest Global communications owns 45% of TV3 and 30% of Ulster TV, with Granada and CanWest planning to combine their shareholdings in a joint venture company if the deal is approved by regulators.

Ulster TV's sales house, TSMS, was snapped up by Granada as part of the £1.75bn acquisition of United News & Media's television assets this year. The company is negotiating new airtime sales arrangements with Granada and Carlton.

webTitle: And now the news from Croft

fields.headline: And now the news from Croft
fields.standfirst:
Today the Guardian begins printing a separate edition for the north, its former home. Martin Wainwright welcomes it

Special report: north-south divide
Quiz: Are you a true northerner?
fields.trailText: From today a significant detail appears in the Guardian in north-west England and Yorkshire - the five letters "north" on the masthead, where the word Manchester used to be.
fields.body:
From today a significant detail appears in the Guardian in north-west England and Yorkshire - the five letters "north" on the masthead, where the word Manchester used to be.

The change marks the commitment of more resources, staff and serious attention to the paper's old home - the north-west of both its founder, John Edward Taylor, and its greatest editor, CP Scott; and the Yorkshire of Jeremiah Garnett, Taylor's partner and the paper's first publisher and printer.

Differences will be modest to start with, but they will have a resonance outside the north; partly because of the prospects for other English regions and partly for the effect on the metropolitan mind. When Ken Livingstone finally moves into Lord Foster's glass testicle by Tower Bridge, he must not forget to hang up modern London's coat of arms: an inverted telescope crossed with a telephone receiver (or modem).

The first of these is a simple symbol of the old, old capital vice of seeing everything beyond the end of the Tube lines as dim and provincial; the second is more significant as an icon of how progress has played us a nasty, centralising trick. The very instruments designed to liberate, to make it irrelevant who worked where, to abolish the office and even, according to the wildest prophets, the city have had the opposite effect.

Modern outposts are limited to the strained conventions of telephone or emailspeak - essentially the problem of getting human warmth along a wire. They have none of the advantages of being physically at the centre of things, while forfeiting the past sense of independence which came from being out of instant reach. God forbid that such a thing should have happened, but if a feisty London underling of CP Scott had felt he knew the capital better than Mancunians did (for in those days, at least at the Guardian, the balance of power was the other way), he could act accordingly. Wrath would take time, and time would surely change the editor's famously fair mind.

Tony Blair has just had a similar, salutary lesson. Goodness knows what distortions of the phone, webmail and central government bureaucracy were kidding him about the national mood on fuel; but the crunch came appropriately here up north. When the prime minister couldn't even get to John Prescott's favourite Chinese restaurant because of the wrath of immobilised Hull, he at last called an emergency cabinet meeting. And this is a man, like his potential successor William Hague, who is supposed to represent a constituency in the north.

Actually, the congruence of Sedgefield and Richmond is just the place where national commentators might usefully be at the next general election; the wisdom in the post office, pub and pews of Croft, where the leaders' constituencies meet, will surely be particularly pure. Less glamorously, it can only be valuable for a London-heavy media to have a woman or man on the spot in the battered ex-coalfields or the sheep-farming fells. At the minimum, they write less about the toil and drama of getting here from Euston or King's Cross.

That is not to belittle the value of an outside eye, a device used famously by the Guardian from Arthur Ransome in Russia to Nick Davies in Sheffield's schools. But the yen to have authoritative voices with a regional base has echoes in every institution which has serious dealings outside London. Nothing revolutionary may come of the Yorkshire constitutional convention in York next month, but it is part of an unmistakable mood - at its most cautious, requesting more power and staff for the regional government offices; at its most exhilarating, demanding referenda on elected (or otherwise democratic) regional assemblies.

The other virtue of the regions which chimes with Guardian values is the different perspective and the willingness not to conform which comes with life at one remove from the centre of both valuable fashion and silly fad. There were serious weaknesses when this paper was actually based in Manchester, but that was an outstanding benefit. It is not a purely northern virtue (west country readers will be pleased to know that CP Scott was born in Bath), but one vividly associated in the nation's mind with gritty Methodists, plain speakers and those who won't do owt for nowt.

There was a sense of homecoming, encouraged by northern pleasure (an interesting emotion properly laced with scepticism) when hints about Guardian North first emerged. Three qualities marked the Guardian of John Edward Taylor and were made internationally famous by Scott: independence, accuracy and vigilance for the welfare of Manchester. The last is now generously and widely shared, but it is still here.

Guardian North is the Guardian, not a hybrid version, and it cannot carry long columns about cotton or the price of tops and noils on the worsted market. But it hopes to give the national news a northern tone and the north a fair hearing by the nation.

webTitle: Full text of Charles Kennedy's speech

fields.headline: 'Place a cap on fuel tax'
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy's, emergency statement on fuel to the party conference, Bournemouth.
fields.body:
"Sometimes - just sometimes there are defining moments for a country and its character. Perhaps - just perhaps Britain came across one of those moments last week. A sense of perspective is called for in all of this.

Ours is a stable country. Ours is a sensible country. And ours is a fundamentally decent country. Stability - sense - decency. These are not assets lightly to be squandered. A society which is liberal democratic has to operate - it cannot function otherwise on a sense of mutual consent.

Last week mutual consent showed signs of breaking down. If it had it would have broken all of us. It almost did. But it didn't. Sense - sanity - decency prevailed.

Put to one side the issue at stake. Put to the forefront the principle involved. A society which is liberal democratic cannot have public policy determined upon the basis of who has got the loudest voice - or who can brings things to a halt. However just, however well behaved, however well meaning.

The petrol protesters - to their credit - knew that. They conducted themselves accordingly. The issue now is that the government must conduct itself accordingly. Democracy demands trust. It demands that sense of mutual understanding. And - it's a two way street. You've got to give - as much as you take.

The government is taking a lot. It's not giving nearly as much. No wonder public confidence collapses.

We say two things. First - fuel tax policy has to be fair. If it's not it won't work. Second - let's be up front about the environmental agenda. And let's be clear about what we would do.

We want a fair deal on fuel. We call on the government:

1. To place a cap on fuel taxes (in real terms) for five years so that the government does not profit from future increases in fuel prices.

2. To use the VAT windfall that it has received from the higher than expected fuel prices to ease the burden on the travelling public.

3. To ensure that oil companies recognise their social responsibilities, both in respect of pricing and security of supply. If they fail to do so, we will take measures to tax their excess profits.

4. To support people in rural communities who rely on fuel through, for example, rate relief on rural fuel stations and increased investment in community public transport.

Those are the principles that we want the government to accept. That is a fair deal on fuel. The events of the past week have also highlighted a more profound consideration. It's time to pause and reflect.

Why do citizens think that they're more likely - more able - to influence the course of public policy by direct action, rather than by conventional party politics? Why do less and less people bother to vote? Why do so few folk even bother to join political parties? You've got to ask questions before you answer them. I've been asking these questions for quite some time now.

This party - and this party conference has got to start providing answers. And it is - and it will.

People won't be spoken to as they've been spoken to in the past. "

webTitle: Keynes, you should be alive this hour

fields.headline: Keynes, you should be alive this hour
fields.trailText: John Maynard Keynes, one of the founding fathers of the World Bank and the IMF, once toasted economists as "trustees, not of civilisation, but of the possibilities of civilisation."
fields.body:
John Maynard Keynes, one of the founding fathers of the World Bank and the IMF, once toasted economists as "trustees, not of civilisation, but of the possibilities of civilisation."

As the bank and the fund begin their protest-ridden annual meeting in Prague, it is worth asking whether today's economists are living up to Keynes' dictum. We have seen that the idea that planned economies provide an economic utopia where civilisation can flourish is nonsense. Nevertheless, the Thatcher claim that liberalised financial markets are always efficient and are mankind's only hope for economic and social progress has also seen to be wanting.

Many have been searching for a "third way" occupying the middle ground in the place of the polar views of planning vs laissez-faire. This "third way" hunt has become the conventional wisdom for Britain's "New Labour" and Germany's "New Social Democrats". Having apparently seen the writing on the wall, Gordon Brown is encouraging some contingency economic thinking. His Royal Economic Society lecture earlier this year and the fact that the Treasury has started to hold private seminars titled "Keynes in the 21st century" indicates that this Labour government's third way includes a search for resurrecting Keynes' civilising economic principles and policies.

Unfortunately, Keynes' argument for remedying the serious flaws of our entrepreneurial economy without destroying the spirit of enterprise or the promotion of a civilized society is not well understood by the Bank of England or the Treasury.

If Keynes was alive today and the chancellor invited him to address one of the Treasury's private seminars, Keynes would stress the following points.

 The "outstanding faults" of an entrepreneurial society are its failure to provide sustained full employment and its arbitrary and inequitable distribution of income and wealth.

 The failure to provide sustainable full employment is not due to supply-side market imperfections such as monopolies or rigid wages. Policies designed to increase wage-price and exchange rate flexibility while liberalising financial markets may well exacerbate unemployment.

 Government's responsibility is to "exercise a guiding influence" on private spending decisions to ensure that there is never a persistent lack of effective demand. Government operating budgets should be balanced. If private spending fails to produce full employment (especially if entrepreneurial exuberance fades), government should run a capital account deficit to employ resources to produce, with the cooperation of private initiative, additional productive facilities.

 Unemployed workers and excessive idle capacity is a "public scandal of wasted resources". The ultimate cause of such a scandal is nested in the human weakness of speculation and an obsession with liquidity. A necessary condition for solving the unemployment problem involves damping destabilising financial speculation to assure orderly financial markets and providing cheaply all the liquidity that entrepreneurs can use.

 Liquidity is a double-edged sword. The good cutting edge is that by providing an orderly market where financial assets can be readily resold encourages savers to provide funding to entrepreneurial investments. Without liquidity, the risk of funding investments as a minority owner would be intolerable. The "bad" edge of the sword is that if a strong bearish view develops, the resulting demand for liquidity impedes the production of new investments even when real resources are available to be employed.

In November, Lord (Robert) Skidelsky's third volume of his biography of Keynes, Fighting For Britain, will be published. I advise the chancellor to read Skidelsky's biography to see how these five principles were used by Keynes to develop policies that promoted the possibilities of civilization for postwar Britain and the global community.

Paul Davidson is Holly chair of excellence in political economy at the University of Tennessee

webTitle: Alderton takes Granada news and current affairs role

fields.headline: Granada hires new current affairs and news editor
fields.trailText: 12.15pm: Mark Alderton has replaced John Pullman as editor, news and current affairs for the Granada region on ITV, writes Jessica Hodgson.
fields.body:
Mark Alderton has replaced John Pullman as editor, news and current affairs for the Granada region on ITV, taking responsibility for the regional news programme Granada Tonight.

Alderton will also oversee Crimefile, the Sunday Supplement and the Late Debate with Lucy Meacock.

Alderton moves from Granada Lifestyle, where he is head of programming for MUTV, the Manchester United Football Club channel. He has previously worked on the Granada regional newsdesk.

Pullman joined ITN at the beginning of the summer to edit the lunchtime news bulletin.

Last week Granada announced it was to split its factual programming departments, following the departure of Charles Tremayne, who has joined Granada's New York factual venture.

Current affairs and features will be headed by former Tonight with Trevor McDonald editor Jeff Anderson, while science, documentaries and history will be covered by Bill Jones.

Granada is still seeking an editor for Tonight with Trevor McDonald.

webTitle: Mother may have passed CJD to baby

fields.headline: Mother may have passed CJD to baby
fields.standfirst: Special report: what's wrong with our food?
fields.trailText: A baby may have contracted variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob (vCJD) disease from her mother while in the womb, according to doctors who have examined the 11-month-old girl.
fields.body:
A baby may have contracted variant Creutzfeldt-Jakob (vCJD) disease from her mother while in the womb, according to doctors who have examined the 11-month-old girl.

The child, whose mother died of the debilitating brain disease in May, is brain damaged and suffers from convulsions . Doctors have not identified any clear causal ailment.

Only an autopsy can conclusively verify a case of vCJD, but if confirmed it would be the first evidence that the disease can be passed to unborn children through the placenta and will strengthen fears that the disease can be transmitted through blood.

Last week researchers at the Institute for Animal Health produced evidence that BSE can be transferred to other species via blood transfusion. Sheep injected with BSE-infected blood developed a variant of the disease.

The child's grandmother, who is also her legal guardian, said that doctors treating the child suspect that vCJD prions had been passed to the baby in the womb.

"They don't know if it's gone into incubation. If so it could be years before we finally confirm the disease," she said.

Doctors say the child is growing at half the normal rate for a girl of her age and has poor sight and stiff limbs. Her appendix has been examined for evidence of vCJD but the tests were inconclusive. The child, who comes from Warwickshire and cannot be named for legal reasons, is being treated at a London hospital.

Richard Lacey, a professor of medical microbiology at Leeds University, said he believed it was inevitable that mothers infected with the disease would pass it on to their children. "The only thing that is uncertain is the scale on which it is happening," he said.

In 1996 the Ministry of Agriculture, Fisheries and Food confirmed that BSE could be passed from pregnant cows to unborn offspring, and the same has been observed in sheep, rats and mice.

The Department of Health moved to allay fears surrounding the case, stressing that vCJD cases are only identifiable postmortem. "There is no evidence as yet from any where in the world that vCJD can be passed from mother to child," said a spokesman.

Nineteen people have died from vCJD this year, making it the worst year since the outbreak began in May 1995. Four people died last month and eight people are suspected of having the disease. Seventy-four people in total have died from the disease.

Most vCJD victims are presumed to have been infected by cheap cuts of beef or mechanically recovered meat typ ically used in beefburgers before 1989, when parts of the animal thought most hazardous to human health were banned.

The government BSE inquiry team is due to report at the end of the month and is expected to criticise government officials and senior ministers for not acting quickly enough to ensure rules were not flouted. The probable link between BSE-infected beef and probable vCJD deaths and cheap cuts of beef was first established in 1996, seven years after the first BSE outbreak.

Frances Hall, the secretary of the Human BSE Foundation, whose son Peter died from vCJD in 1996, said the latest development would be of great concern to families of children born to other women who have died of the disease.

"The families have always been frightened about the possibility of it passing to unborn children. There are a number of babies to women who have died but those children are still healthy," she said.

webTitle: Radio Times to launch online film site

fields.headline: Radio Times to launch dedicated film site
fields.trailText: 11am: Radio Times, the TV listings magazine from BBC Worldwide, is boosting its online offering with a new site devoted to film, writes Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Radio Times, the TV listings magazine from BBC Worldwide, is giving a significant boost to its online offering with a new site devoted to film.

The website, which is called Radio Times Film and launches next month, will complement the Radio Times Guide to Films book, published on October 26. Barry Norman and Jonathan Ross have been signed up to write exclusive weekly columns, and more e-commerce is to be integrated into the site.

Duncan Swain, the site's producer, said: "The site is an excellent complementary service to the printed Radio Times Guide to Films, and a product in its own right that we're continuing to develop, as further products, services and retailers come online. Separately, BBC Worldwide has signed a partnership deal with interactive programmes specialist Two Way TV to develop A Question of Sport, Antiques Roadshow and Ask the Family into interactive gameshows. Two way TV plans to launch the shows on NTL next spring.

webTitle: Rivals.net hiring

fields.headline: Rivals.net poaches News International chief
fields.trailText: Rivals.net has lured Chris Reed from News International to be its first marketing director, says Amy Vickers.
fields.body:
Rivals.net, the online sports network in which media group Chrysalis has a controlling stake, has lured Chris Reed from News International to be its first marketing director.

Reed, formerly marketing and promotions manager at the Times and Sunday Times, will take over responsibility for the site's marketing and brand-building strategy.

Rivals.net, a collection of 300 independent fan websites covering football, cricket, rugby, Formula 1, rally and skateboarding, plans to launch in Europe this year. A £500,000 marketing push is earmarked for the UK and Reed understood to be briefing media and advertising agencies.

Before News International, Reed was marketing and promotions manager at H Bauer Publishing. Prior to that, he was a director of Emap Radio.

Rivals.net was last week bought by Chrysalis, which extended its stake in the outfit from 25% to 90.1%.

webTitle: Conservatives gain in reshuffle at the Vatican

fields.headline: Conservatives gain in reshuffle at the Vatican
fields.trailText: The Pope reshuffled the Vatican hierarchy at the weekend, and commentators said the result favoured rightwingers who are lobbying to install a conservative successor.
fields.body:
The Pope reshuffled the Vatican hierarchy at the weekend, and commentators said the result favoured rightwingers who are lobbying to install a conservative successor.

Giovanni Battista Re, 66, a career Vatican diplomat who served as deputy secretary of state, was appointed head of the congregation of bishops, a powerful post likely to result in his elevation to cardinal.

He replaced Lucas Moreira Neves, 75, a Brazilian who had been widely touted as the next pope before he resigned due to ill health. His departure has reduced the chance that the next pope will be from Latin America.

Italian newspapers said the Re appointment was one of a number of signs that the right's influence was increasing as the health of the Pope, 80, steadily fails.

The post to be held by Monsignor Re, an Italian, carries weight in conclaves, when cardinals meet in the Sistine chapel to choose a new Pope. The holder also helps to shape the future by influencing the appointment of bishops.

Taking over from him as deputy secretary of state is Archbishop Leonardo Sandri, an Argentine who has served as the Vatican's representative in Venezuela and Mexico.

Another sign of an emboldened conservative faction came last week when Cardinal Giacomo Biffi called on Italy's civil authorities to admit as immigrants only Roman Catholics, to preserve the national identity.

He said: "Italy is not a deserted land with no history or traditions that can be populated at random."

Protests from leftwing politicians and some others in the church - who said the comments were rather at odds with the Pope's attempts to reach out to other religions - did not deter the Vatican from giving its backing.

Cardinal Angelo Sodano, the Vatican secretary of state, said the comments were "wise, very wise," and deserved to be "understood, not twisted".

L'Avvenire, the organ of the church in Italy, also defended Cardinal Biffi.

webTitle: Rail crash survivors demand safer system

fields.headline: Rail crash survivors demand safer system
fields.trailText: Survivors and families of victims of the Southall and Ladbroke Grove train disasters today called for the urgent introduction of safety measures to prevent future rail tragedies - and for the scrapping of a plan to install a cheaper alternative.
fields.body:
Survivors and families of victims of the Southall and Ladbroke Grove train disasters today called for the urgent introduction of safety measures to prevent future rail tragedies - and for the scrapping of a plan to install a cheaper alternative.

Representatives of the Southall and Ladbroke Grove solicitors group demanded the installation of the Automatic Train Protection systems (ATPs), widely used across Europe. They also called on the government and railway industry to abandon "absolutely crazy" moves to install the cheaper Train Protection Warning System (TPWS).

Louise Christian, the solicitor leading the group, told a news conference it would be "outrageous" if Britain did not opt for ATPs. She compared the difference between TPWS - which relies on an old-fashioned magnet system - and ATPs to the technological inferiority of a manual typewriter to a modern computer.

She said: "The fear is that if TPWS is installed, the railway industry, having made that huge investment, will then seek to delay incurring the additional cost to install European Automatic Train Protection.

"Instead of a first-rate system in a few years, Britain will be saddled for many years with a second-rate system which will not protect against the highest risk," Mrs Christian said.

Seven people died and 147 were injured in the rail crash three years ago in Southall, west London. One of the survivors, Carol Bell, warned: "When you hand over your money at the ticket office you also hand over your life."

The news conference was held before a joint inquiry into issues of safety opens today before Lord Cullen and Professor John Uff.

The inquiry at Central Hall, Westminster, central London, has been ordered to consider three specific topics on railway safety: the future application of ATPs, train protection and warning systems, and prevention measures for signals passed at danger (SPADs). The inquiry will heard submissions from all concerned parties, including Railtrack and the Association of Train Operating Companies. Lord Cullen and Prof Uff will first hear evidence tomorrow.

Last week Lord Cullen concluded the first part of a separate inquiry into the Paddington rail disaster last October. Thirty-one people died when a Thames Train turbo heading out of the west London terminus station jumped a red signal and collided head-on with a Great Western express. The train was not fitted with an anti-braking system that may have prevented the disaster.

webTitle: Kennedy calls for cap on fuel taxes

fields.headline: Kennedy calls for cap on fuel taxes
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, used the opening day of his party's conference in Bournemouth to outline a four-stage strategy for putting an end to the long-running dispute over fuel taxation.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrat leader, Charles Kennedy, used the opening day of his party's conference in Bournemouth to outline a four-stage strategy for putting an end to the long-running dispute over fuel taxation.

Using the vehicle of what he termed "an emergency statement" at the beginning on the week-long conference, Mr Kennedy told delegates that last week's petrol crisis had been "a defining moment" for Britain.

He went on to call on the government to cap fuel taxes for five years so as not to profit from future increases in fuel prices.

He also urged ministers to take on board a Liberal Democrat pledge to:

 Use the VAT windfall from higher-than-expected fuel prices to ease the burden on the travelling public,

 Ensure oil companies recognise their "social responsibilities" in respect of pricing and security of supply; if not, to take measures to tax their excess profits and,

 Support rural petrol stations through rate relief for garages in far-flung locations and increased investment in community public transport.

Mr Kennedy stressed the activities of the petrol protesters had highlighted deeper concerns that direct action was seen as a better way of getting a message across than conventional party politics.

He argued that however well meaning, public policy could not be determined on who "has the loudest voice or who can bring things to a halt".

He said: "Sometimes, just sometimes, there are defining moments for a country and just perhaps, Britain came across one of those moments last week

"Ours is a stable country, a sensible country and these are not assets lightly to be squandered.

"A sense of sanity and democracy prevailed, but society and policy cannot be based on who has the loudest voice or who can bring things to a halt however just, however well-behaved, however well-meaning those voices are."

webTitle: Paris price war for the cheap seats

fields.headline: Paris price war for the cheap seats
fields.trailText: French film distributors will plunge into bitter conflict later this month over rival subscription schemes offering unlimited access to cinemas.
fields.body:
French film distributors will plunge into bitter conflict later this month over rival subscription schemes offering unlimited access to cinemas.

Already more than 100,000 French film fans have subscribed to a card established six months ago by the country's leading multiplex chain which allows cinemagoers to see as many films at UGC cinemas as they want for only 98 francs (£9) a month.

Independent cinemas claim that the card represents unfair competition and is driving them out of business.

Now, in an attempt to fight back against UGC's box-office success, the Gaumont circuit, the independent MK2 chain, and several small Parisian cinemas have joined forces.

On September 27 they will launch their own subscription card, called Le Pass, also costing 98 francs a month, and giving unlimited access to their cinemas in the Ile de France region.

Gaumont and the independents took this step after urging the government in vain in March to outlaw the UGC card.

Marin Karmitz, head of MK2, said they decided to take joint action after the office of fair trading rejected his call for UGC's card to be banned.

The Gaumont chairman, Nicolas Seydoux, added: "We have had to overcome our reluctance and must take action or risk going the way of the dinosaurs."

Jean Henochsberg, who runs two art houses in the Latin Quarter of Paris, which will take part in the Le Pass scheme, said his cinemas had suffered a 10% fall in ticket sales since the UGC card was launched. He claimed to have no choice but to fight back. "I can't pay my bills any more. And the authorities have done nothing to help."

Pathé, the third French distribution giant after UGC and Gaumont, may also join the Le Pass scheme later this year.

UGC currently claims about 40% of Paris box-office takings, Gaumont 30% and MK2 10%. Pathé is based mainly in the provinces.

UGC's subscription scheme has provoked a passionate de bate among film fans on multiplex giant's website. One correspondent wrote: "Real cinema lovers will count the cost of this card which will kill the little cinemas. They will also kill that which makes cinema an art: its diversity. Where will one be able to see old films then?"

Another complained that there were so many subtitled Hollywood films on at his local UGC multiplex since the subscription card was introduced that he was getting terrible headaches and eye strain. Perhaps UGC might consider more dubbed films or, just maybe, showing more French pictures in their multiplexes, he suggested.

Others have praised UGC for tailoring the card to their filmic obsessions, one saying tshe was delighted that she would be able to see the same film dozens of times a month thanks to the UGC card.

Melanie, 69, from Lyon, was typical of the scheme's enthusiasts "Thanks to this wonderful card, I go to the cinema three or four times a week and I've given up my subscription to cable TV," she wrote.

Opponents of UGC's scheme argue that the multiplex giant is trying to maximise profits by filling its cinemas with blank-eyed philistines all digesting Hollywood blockbuster pap.

And the current top 10 films in French cinemas gives some support to this view: only two films (Sade, starring Daniel Auteuil and based on Serge Bramly's novel The Terror of the Bedroom, and Harry, un Ami Qui vous Veut du Bien, a comedy by Dominik Moll) are French.

The rest, although they include such accomplished films as the Coen brothers' O Brother where Art Thou? and Stephen Frears' adaptation of Nick Hornby's novel High Fidelity, are American.

According to Le Monde, the battle of the subscription cards will be the "cinematic soap opera of the autumn".

But that spectacle will be of little consolation to the independent cinemas who are unable to join Le Pass.

Their profit margins have already been hit by UGC and are likely to suffer even more during the autumn as the price war intensifies.

webTitle: M&S chief executive quits as clothes sales fall

fields.headline: M&S chief executive quits as clothes sales fall
fields.trailText: The chief executive of Marks & Spencer, Peter Salsbury, today resigned from the high street retailer.
fields.body:
The chief executive of Marks & Spencer, Peter Salsbury, today resigned from the high street retailer.

His role will be taken over by the chairman, Luc Vandevelde.

The move, widely expected in the City, came as M&S posted a trading statement showing clothing sales down by 1.4 per cent in the 24 weeks to 16 September.

Mr Salsbury's resignation had been expected ever since Friday when M&S poached Roger Homes, a key executive from Woolworths-to-B&Q group Kingfisher, on to its board.

Mr Holmes, 40, former chief executive of Kingfisher's electricals division, is expected to be appointed as head of UK retailing.

City analysts have predicted that Mr Holmes, who had also been touted as the heir apparent to Kingfisher boss Sir Geoff Mulcahy, will eventually take up the M&S chief executive post.

On Friday, shares in M&S slipped 5.75p to end at 210.75p, on the continuing uncertainty at the retailer.

M&S is trying to turn around its business and in July, Belgian-born retailer, Mr Vandevelde warned trading would "remain tough for the foreseeable future".

It is re-launching its stores and, in August, caught the headlines when it unveiled a television advert showing a size 16 woman stripping off.

The fall in clothing sales compares with a 0.3 percent increase in the 15 weeks to July 15, the last time M&S made a trading statement.

Food sales, on a like-for-like basis, and stripping out the effect of new store openings, were up by 0.8 per cent, compared with 1.3 percent for the 15 weeks to July.

M&S said that the fuel crisis had worsened the situation, reducing sales by £21 million. Its decision to make deeper price cuts in its summer sale than last year cost the retailer £23m.

The company also spent £15m on marketing and £13m on refurbishing 22 new concept M&S stores that are due to open in October and November.

Kingfisher last week unveiled plans to split in two, open 700 new or re-formatted stores and create 20,000 jobs.

The group will de-merge its Comet and B&Q chains from its Woolworths and Superdrug stores, creating two separately quoted companies.

The move will also see a large expansion in the Woolworths and Superdrug outlets with new formats of both stores rolled out around the UK.

It was further being speculated today that Kingfisher will sell off its 35 per cent stake in French Internet service provider LibertySurf, in a move that could net it £600m.

webTitle: The big turn-off

fields.headline: The big turn-off
fields.standfirst: Viewers will soon be able to zap the ads. What will the agencies do then, asks  Paul Bainsfair.
fields.trailText: Viewers will soon be able to zap the ads. What will the agencies do then, asks Paul Bainsfair.
fields.body:
A few weeks ago it was impossible to miss all the hype surrounding Victoria Beckham's tussle with Sophie Bextor-Ellis of Spiller to reach the top of the charts. Spiller made it, but after a week at the top they were crushed by Madonna's new single Music. Ms Ciccone had her first number one 18 years ago and she's still in charge. How does she do it? She constantly reinvents herself and that's a lesson that advertising agencies are going to have to learn.

Despite the state-of-the-art offices and all the smart, creative brains, the basic approach to advertising hasn't changed for 50 years. It hasn't changed because it has continued to be a successful industry paid high fees to drive big brands onwards and upwards, and if it ain't broke...

But technology is driving consumers to new platforms and new media channels and the competition for eyeballs is going to get so intense that new ways of applying brand-building ideas will be essential. Agencies have been aware for some time of the need to change but, aside from gearing up to deal with their client's e-commerce needs, they still operate along old lines, with all the big guns applying themselves to developing conventional "interruptive" advertising. The 30-second commercial and the double-page spread are still kings.

What's really got them talking in the Ivy is the development by TiVo and Replay of set-top boxes that not only allow viewers to compile their own special-interest programming, but also enable them to edit out the advertising. That means audiences will be far smaller per programme, making a nonsense of hugely expensive production - why spend £1.5m on a British Airways ad that only a few thousand will watch. Oh, and if you give consumers the choice, they won't watch the ads: in home trials, 88% zapped the commercials.

If ad breaks can be edited out, the programmes will need to contain the ads, or more likely the brands, so that they cannot be ignored. The way forward is for agencies to apply their creativity to develop ideas that do not depend on piggy-backing other forms of entertainment - in short, the ideas will need to be entertaining in their own right. It will almost certainly lead to a return to advertisers becoming programme-makers, and a new generation of soap operas. TBWA has already responded to this challenge by pioneering viral marketing on the internet. It has helped to launch a Nissan sedan in the US by sending 12 students on a coast-to-coast drive with digital camcorders linked to the web. And in June, we helped Nike hijack every country's TV coverage of Euro 2000, an ad created by Wieden+Kennedy, by painting an image of Edgar Davids on Rotterdam's tallest building.

These are examples of the new kind of ideas that clients will be demanding. The agencies that can adapt to this changing world will, like Madonna, continue to call the shots in the creative marketplace. If they don't, they're going to look as relevant as Alvin Stardust.

fields.bodyText: A few weeks ago it was impossible to miss all the hype surrounding Victoria Beckham's tussle with Sophie Bextor-Ellis of Spiller to reach the top of the charts. Spiller made it, but after a week at the top they were crushed by Madonna's new single Music. Ms Ciccone had her first number one 18 years ago and she's still in charge. How does she do it? She constantly reinvents herself and that's a lesson that advertising agencies are going to have to learn. Despite the state-of-the-art offices and all the smart, creative brains, the basic approach to advertising hasn't changed for 50 years. It hasn't changed because it has continued to be a successful industry paid high fees to drive big brands onwards and upwards, and if it ain't broke... But technology is driving consumers to new platforms and new media channels and the competition for eyeballs is going to get so intense that new ways of applying brand-building ideas will be essential. Agencies have been aware for some time of the need to change but, aside from gearing up to deal with their client's e-commerce needs, they still operate along old lines, with all the big guns applying themselves to developing conventional "interruptive" advertising. The 30-second commercial and the double-page spread are still kings. What's really got them talking in the Ivy is the development by TiVo and Replay of set-top boxes that not only allow viewers to compile their own special-interest programming, but also enable them to edit out the advertising. That means audiences will be far smaller per programme, making a nonsense of hugely expensive production - why spend £1.5m on a British Airways ad that only a few thousand will watch. Oh, and if you give consumers the choice, they won't watch the ads: in home trials, 88% zapped the commercials. If ad breaks can be edited out, the programmes will need to contain the ads, or more likely the brands, so that they cannot be ignored. The way forward is for agencies to apply their creativity to develop ideas that do not depend on piggy-backing other forms of entertainment - in short, the ideas will need to be entertaining in their own right. It will almost certainly lead to a return to advertisers becoming programme-makers, and a new generation of soap operas. webTitle: The wonks may get their day

fields.headline: The wonks may get their day
fields.trailText: The workings of Washington policy wonks leave most normal people unmoved. By Jane Martinson.
fields.body:
The workings of Washington policy wonks leave most normal people unmoved. But the goings on at two US government agencies over the coming weeks are set to have profound implications for the future development of online media services.

Most Brits, when asked what the FTC and the FCC were, would hazard a guess based on an association with football. Neither of these two US government agencies - the federal trade commission and the federal communications commission respectively - has done much to raise its profile outside the confines of the US business world.

That could be about to change. By the end of next month, the two - which oversee fair trade in America as well as the communications industry - are expected to rule on whether the proposed merger between America Online and Time Warner should go ahead and, if so, under what conditions.

At issue is how much power a behemoth that combines the world's largest internet service provider with one of its biggest media companies should have. The proposed AOL Time Warner, announced more than nine months ago, would have access to more than 24m consumers on the web, as well as the readers or viewers of best-selling products such as Time magazine, CNN and Warner Brothers films. Time Warner is also the second-largest cable television company in the US.

After a decade of explosive and largely untrammelled growth, the decision over AOL Time Warner is expected to herald a new era of greater regulation of the internet industry. Partly because of this, the decision is also going to affect the shape of the industry and future mergers.

The scope of the regulatory review is broad and encompasses the development of interactive television, instant messaging and the convergence between the media, telecommunications and technology industries.

The issue which could have the biggest impact, however, is that of open access. Internet services to date have thrived on delivery over telephone wires to personal computers. The future, according to an industry trying to get there, will depend on delivery over broadband or high-speed access delivered via cable connections, satellite links and wireless services as well as souped-up telephone lines.

A large part of the proposed merger was predicated on AOL being able to pump its internet services over the Time Warner cable network. An even larger part of the various complaints against it is that AOL Time Warner would be able to control all access to the web over the cable connection.

Time Warner's dominance of the cable television industry has become a particular issue in the US, but open access touches on how we all use the web, at what speed and at what cost. Regulators in Brussels, who have their own problems with the proposed merger, are watching developments closely. Competition watchdogs at the European Commission are also expected to rule on the merger by the end of this month.

Disney, an unlikely champion of the little guy and fierce rival of the new company, has described it as a sort of Microsoft of the internet age. As the world's largest software company crushed the development of rival technologies, it argues, so would AOL Time Warner.

Jamie Love, director of the Centre for Technology, a consumer campaign group, believes that the world's regulators should block the merger altogether. Campaign groups were particularly unhappy that the deal unites a company that had previously been the greatest advocate of truly open access with its biggest opponent in the cable industry.

AOL once launched an unsuccessful legal case to force cable companies not to discriminate against its services. In its turn, AOL has argued that its existing pledges on continuing to let others use AOL Time Warner already "go beyond anyone in the industry". But then again, the merger goes beyond what others in the industry are doing too.

Last week, the FCC, which overlooks the US communications industry, was due to launch a formal inquiry into the use of the cable television network to access the internet. One of the five commissioners asked for a delay on Thursday, however, citing the concurrent review of the AOL/Time Warner merger.

The broader inquiry was prompted by conflicting US court cases over how to treat cable companies. Last week's decision, however, indicates how far the issues raised by one merger are expected to affect the entire industry. As one source close to the commission put it: "We felt that now is the time to do it, rather than after the biggest merger in history ties two-thirds of Americans to just two companies."

US regulators are not expected to block the merger altogether. But their ability to win concessions from AOL Time Warner could define the future of the industry. The wonks may yet have their day.

webTitle: New media: Leo Gestetner, chief operating officer of shopsmart.com

fields.headline: Need to know
fields.standfirst: Interview: Leo Gestetner
fields.trailText: Leo Gestetner, chief operating officer of Shopsmart.com.
fields.body:
Favourite sites?
I'd say it depends what I'm looking for. If it's general info, then I often use Yahoo!. Otherwise I find moreover.com is very good for news. And winfiles.com and tucows.com are both excellent software sites. To be honest, one of the sites I probably use the most is shopsmart.com, because I do a lot of shopping online.

Last online purchase?
A Palm Vx. The price differences were quite substantial, but I won't tell you what price I got it for.

Most recent technological faux-pas?
To be honest, I don't think I've really had one. It would be a bit worrying if I had.

Main news sources on the net?
My main one is actually lovelacemedia which I get emailed to me every day. Also I find new media age's site (nma.co.uk) is very good for news. And if I want general information, times.co.uk is probably the main news source I go to.

Most persistent spam emailer?
I delete most of the spam as soon as I get it, so I wouldn't really know.

Time spent on web?
Surprise, surprise, most of the day.

Next boo.com/clickmango?
I'd say anybody who's trying to raise money but doesn't have strong revenue streams and a strong business mode. I really wouldn't name a company though. It wouldn't be fair.

Least useful site/s on web?
Sites with no interaction or no real use. Retailers who don't actually sell anything online.

Least user-friendly site?
I find quite a lot of the smaller travel sites are particularly un-user-friendly. You have to go through loads of search options and are finally presented with a home page and a phone number to contact, which is rather frustrating. The worst are the finance sites, especially the banking ones. Although very useful, they are very badly designed and not thought out with the customer in mind.

What screensaver do you use?
Don't use a screensaver.

Most irritating thing about the web?
Got to be sites with heavy graphics that are designed by people with high-speed internet lines who don't think about people at home or on slow connections.

Do you bother with old media?
Not really during the week. I mainly read the emailed newsletters, but on Sundays I often go out and buy the paper. On the way to work I often listen to News Direct.

 Leo Gestetner is chief operating officer of Shopsmart.com.

webTitle: StepStone signs NTL deal

fields.headline: StepStone signs NTL interactive TV deal
fields.trailText: StepStone has signed a deal with NTL to make it the first online recruitment service on interactive television in the UK, reports Claire Cozens.
fields.body:
StepStone has signed a content deal with NTL to make it the first online recruitment service on interactive television in the UK.

The new service will be available to NTL customers by the end of the year. They will be able to access the service via digital cable and NTL's new internet service, Ntlworld.

Giles Clarke, chief executive of StepStone, said: "This exciting new service underlines our continuing commitment to delivering our service to a larger customer base. We have consistently developed our channels for delivering these services since we launched in the UK last year, offering consumers a route to our portal via some of the leading internet service providers and portals in the UK - and WAP."

NTL director of content John Hondros commented: "StepStone is fast becoming a leading online recruitment service and can offer a wide range of jobs to NTL's interactive customer base. Job opportunities and advice can be accessed in the privacy of subscriber homes - without the boss looking over their shoulder."

StepStone has distribution agreements with Yahoo! Europe, Lycos, MSN, Excite, Wannado and Freeserve.

webTitle: New Media Diary

fields.headline: New Media Diary
fields.body:
 At last, the Advertising Standards Authority is clamping down on dot.com advertisers and the way in which they just love to confuse consumers. Or at least the watchdog has slapped the hands of scurrilous ISPs that bandy around the word "free" like it's going out of fashion. Now, if only the ASA would turn its attention to other confusing (and annoying) dot.com ads such as Letsbuyit.com and Kelkoo.com, the world would be a better place. We live in hope.

 Domain name battles wage on.

TV show Eurotrash found itself on the wrong side of a cybersquatting case recently when it lost its battle for eurotrash.com. The name remained in the hands of a Silicon Alley IT consultancy of the same name. On being told it had triumphed, Eurotrash.com ceo Jan Duffy-King proclaimed: "It's a great victory for us against the bully tactics of Rapido, a large television production company who thought they could just push us over using their unlimited legal and financial resources." Ya boo sucks.

 Award for most opportunistic press release of the week goes to Pirate Communications for their "imaginative unleaded promotion" for technology clients Intronets. Describing itself as a "big hearted internet company", Intronets is siphoning off petrol from its company cars to give to five lucky new customers pulled out of a hat. Managing director cum cad Andrew Wicking explains: "We thought what better way to attract new business and help potential customers than by offering some much wanted petrol. The downside however is that I may be walking home." So there you have it, dot.com humour.

 Calling all designers out there, is there such a thing as design theft? As with music, clearly there is only a finite number of designs a website can have, but sometimes it's blatantly obvious when a site code and design is copied. Take a look at allyoursoaps.com: which newspaper website do you think it's trying to rip off? Asked about design theft, Rick Ellis of allyoursoaps.com replied, rather innocently, "You're the first person who has mentioned any resemblance to another site. I had someone else put the site design together for me, so it's certainly possible they weren't quite as original as they claimed to be." But then again, Ellis claims to have had the site up and running for more than a year, so could it be possible that the theft was the other way round?

 Prog rock band Marillion has taken a leaf out of Stephen King's book and raised money via the internet to fund its next album after it couldn't find a record label to provide the cash. Undeterred by this apparent lack of faith, Marillion decided to email its 30,000 fan base asking for money. How much did it raise? Get this - a whopping £50,000.

 Amy Vickers is new media editor of mediatheguardian.com

Amy.vickers@theguardian.com

webTitle: Today's media stories from the papers

fields.headline: Today's media stories from the papers
fields.trailText: Nearly all the papers lead with the death of TV presenter Paula Yates, with many references to her struggles with drugs. The tabloids have lost one of their favourite celebrities, as shown by the many pages dedicated to the ups and down of her rollercaoster life. The Big Brother auction gets surprisingly little coverage, despite the insane amounts of money being offered by the bidders. All the papers continue to squeeze the last drop of news out of the petrol crisis.
fields.body:
Nearly all the papers lead with the death of TV presenter Paula Yates, with many references to her struggles with drugs. The tabloids have lost one of their favourite celebrities, as shown by the many pages dedicated to the ups and down of her rollercaoster life. The Big Brother auction gets surprisingly little coverage, despite the insane amounts of money being offered by the bidders. All the papers continue to squeeze the last drop of news out of the petrol crisis.

The Guardian
The latest twist in the saga of Napster, which allows music to be downloaded form the net, sees Radiohead's new album, Kid A, available on the web a month before it hits the shops. (p.5).
Stephen Hetherington, chief executive of the Lowry arts centre in Manchester, said state subsidies for arts centres can lead to controls similar to the old soviet culture ministries. (p.8).
Channel 4 has been slapped on the wrist by the Independent Television Commission after the Trigger Happy TV show screened a spoof interview with ex-Rolling Stone Bill Wyman without the ex-star's permission. (p.11).
Madeleine Bunting gets annoyed with the latest deodorant billboard adverts, which are racking up hundreds of complaints of "daft and offensive", asking "why does boring deodorant have to be eroticised?" (p.17).

Media Guardian
Roy Greenslade looks at the national press coverage of the petrol crisis, saying Blair was outmanoeuvred as the newspapers spun the story their way before his spinners had the chance to do their job (p.2&3).
Broadcasters were rubbing their hands with glee at the fuel shortages, as Sky News ratings shot up by 300% at some points and the BBC and ITV news broadcasts notched up ratings at least 50% up on their usual figures. (p.4).
Maggie Brown says the appointment of Lorraine Heggessey as controller of BBC1 shows that women are storming the best jobs in television. Peter Salmon, the man she replaced, has his work cut out as the head honcho of BBC Sport. (p.5).
Adidas are running a series of stealth adverts on the BBC by sponsoring short films for the Sydney Olympics, which have been shown on Grandstand. (p. 6&7).
Trevor Beattie says that advertising agencies could be in trouble when new-fangled digital set-top TV boxes allow viewers to edit out ad breaks from their programmes. (p.7).
Scotland's latest daily newspaper, business a.m, is launching into a badly crowded marketplace with 21 publications, which could see the merger of deadly rivals the Scotsman and the Herald. (p.8&9).
Jane O'Hara, managing director of radio audience ratings company Rajar, attacks Kelvin Mackenzie's argument that the method for gathering listening figures is old fashioned and inaccurate. (p.10)

The Independent
In a touching act of fraternity with all anorak lovers, the Science Museum in London is using props and characters from Star Trek to explain rocket propulsion and space exploration. (p.5).
BT is defying calls for it to issue a statement about alleged merger talks with its American rival AT&T. (p.14).

The Daily Telegraph
A set of first edition Harry Potter books signed by author JK Rowling is being offered for £23,500 at an antique book fair. (p.3).
Pearson, the owner of the Financial Times, is to invest £10m in a 20% stake in business.com, a US-based financial information website.

Financial Times
The BBC has joined digital games channel Two Way TV to launch an interactive version of Mastermind. (p.4).
Cable operator Telewest communications has entered a joint venture with Scottish computer games company Vis to develop games for interactive digital television and broadband cable services. (p.28).

The Times
Three million people watched cyclist Jason Queally win Britain's first gold medal at the Sydney Olympics, double the number who would normally be watching at mid-morning on a Saturday. (p.3).
Forecourt Television, the company bringing television advertising to petrol stations, expects to be valued at more than £35m when it floats on the stock market next month. (p.22).

The Daily Mail
Grant Bovey, the flake-chomping husband of celebrity lightweight Anthea Turner, is facing legal action after his North Star Multi Media company collapsed with debts said to be around £75,000. (p.2).
More revelations from Tom Bower's book: Richard Branson, the millionaire self-publicity machine, burst into tears when EMI records bought his Virgin music label for £560m in 1992. But did not give staff a penny. (p.33).

Daily Express
Roy Copsey, the only gay participant in the BBC's Castaway 2000 show, has attacked the fellow inhabitants who forced him to flee two months ago. Shouldn't he be thanking them? (p.15).
Cult BBC weatherman, John Kettley, quit his job at the corporation amid rumours that he had been insulted by comments about his bald patch. He has since been persuaded to return, though he is looking for part-time work elsewhere. (p.17).
A film crew working for Channel 4 captured footage of two members of a British expedition falling to their deaths from the Eiger mountain in Switzerland. (p.21).
Sky Sports presenter Kirsty Gallacher has signed up for a new Sky One show, called Kirsty's Home Videos. The not so ground- breaking show is a "riskier version of You've Been Framed." (p.27).
Philip McQuillan, an unknown Dublin musician, has been chosen to play John Lennon in a new film about the murdered Beatles legend. (p.33).
The Independent Television Commission has backed a complaint from the widow of Carry On star Sid James over an LWT drama about his affair with Barbara Windsor. (p.37).
Big Brother star Darren Ramsey has reportedly been offered a six-figure sum to advertise Chicken Tonight following the tenderness he showed towards Marjorie the hen. His love of poultry might cause him to cry fowl play, however. (p.36).

The Mirror
The Campaign for Real Ale Good Beer Guide says country pubs are being killed off because people would rather stay at home watching TV. (p.17).
Big Brother winner Craig Phillips says he will do everything in his power to raise the £250,000 his friend Joanne needs for a heart and lung transplant. The gold-hearted scouser has already raised £100,000. (p.22&23).

And Finally...
Daily Star
Comedian and TV actor Alan Davies has snapped up the Big Brother diary room chair by bidding £30,000.01 in an auction. Nasty Nick's bed,duvet and pillow received a bewildering bid of £2,000. Why not just burn the money? (p.7).

(p.4). Maggie Brown says the appointment of Lorraine Heggessey as controller of BBC1 shows that women are storming the best jobs in television. Peter Salmon, the man she replaced, has his work cut out as the head honcho of BBC Sport. (p.5). Adidas are running a series of stealth adverts on the BBC by sponsoring short films for the Sydney Olympics, which have been shown on Grandstand. (p. 6&7). Trevor Beattie says that advertising agencies could be in trouble when new-fangled digital set-top TV boxes allow viewers to edit out ad breaks from their programmes. (p.7). Scotland's latest daily newspaper, business a.m, is launching into a badly crowded marketplace with 21 publications, which could see the merger of deadly rivals the Scotsman and the Herald. (p.8&9). Jane O'Hara, managing director of radio audience ratings company Rajar, attacks Kelvin Mackenzie's argument that the method for gathering listening figures is old fashioned and inaccurate. (p.10) The Independent In a touching act of fraternity with all anorak lovers, the Science Museum in London is using props and characters from Star Trek to explain rocket propulsion and space exploration. (p.5). BT is defying calls for it to issue a statement about alleged merger talks with its American rival AT&T. (p.14). The Daily Telegraph A set of first edition Harry Potter books signed by author JK Rowling is being offered for £23,500 at an antique book fair. (p.3). Pearson, the owner of the Financial Times, is to invest £10m in a 20% stake in business.com, a US-based financial information website. Financial Times The BBC has joined digital games channel Two Way TV to launch an interactive version of Mastermind. (p.4). Cable operator Telewest communications has entered a joint venture with Scottish computer games company Vis to develop games for interactive digital television and broadband cable services. (p.28). The Times Three million people watched cyclist Jason Queally win Britain's first gold medal at the Sydney Olympics, double the number who would normally be watching at mid-morning on a Saturday. (p.3). Forecourt Television, the company bringing television advertising to petrol stations, expects to be valued at more than £35m when it floats on the stock market next month. (p.22). webTitle: Similarities betweeen the campaigns of BT and NTL

fields.headline: Communication breakdown?
fields.standfirst: Coincidence or just clever marketing to the same audience? Amy Vickers outlines the similarities between the campaigns of BT and NTL.
fields.trailText: Coincidence or just clever marketing to the same audience? Amy Vickers outlines the similarities between the campaigns of BT and NTL.
fields.body:
While BT has always won critical acclaim for its marketing strategies, a number of recent marketing initiatives has raised a few eyebrows and prompted the odd smirk over at arch-rival NTL.

Likewise, BT has noticed a number of overlaps in both their [BT and NTL] advertising campaigns, but puts it down to "great minds thinking alike".

On no fewer than three occasions has NTL sat back and thought it had been the inspiration behind BT's brand marketing. The first was the most obvious - the similarities in the names NTLWorld and BT Openworld - but as far as unveiling the brands to the public is concerned, NTL was first to reveal its brand in March with BT unveiling its own more than a month later.

Two advertising campaigns in particular bear an uncanny resemblance to each other. The NTLWorld ads that supported the launch of the service back in May (the ones with the giant goalposts) and the BT ad 'Our Net business is bigger than you think' that also featured a huge football net. But in this instance, the BT ad actually made it to TV screens before the NTLWorld ad.

The timing of the Millionaire promotion is not quite as clear cut as both were announced around mid-March. BT Internet did, however, make it to market first with its 'Net a million' campaign while NTLWorld's sponsorship of Who Wants to be a Millionaire? didn't break until a month later.

Katrina Lowes, head of advertising at BT, said the synergies had been a complete coincidence and put it down to the fact that they are targeting the same consumers and had the same challenges to overcome. "We're now starting to approach the internet in a different way and targeting different parts of the mass market so hopefully there'll be fewer coincidences," she added.

Malcolm Padley, spokesman for NTL, said NTL attributed the similarities to the stars being in alignment on several occasions. "We think it's all a bit of fun really. We're not throwing any stones, just noticing a few coincidences," he said.

Both are heavyweight spenders - last year NTL spent almost £12m on advertising in the UK, and this year is expected to spend almost £40m, while BT spent around £84m, according to ACNielsen MMS.

Lowes said she had also noticed a number of other coincidences with mobile operators' advertising campaigns, in particular a Vodafone ad that put across the same 'value for money' message. She added that convergence had meant that more companies were now operating in the same markets as BT.

In the case of the 'Net business is bigger than you think' ad, which was screened in March, filming actually began in January. Lowes said that in a worst case scenario, she would pull a campaign halfway though filming if a competitor's campaign broke carrying a similar message.

The problem, perhaps, is that it is rare to come across a truly new creative idea, given that so much of what is around has its roots in the past, and practically everything is regurgitated every few years. Lowes says that while increased competition means that there is now more pressure than ever to come up with a fresh idea, it's an exciting time to be in.

webTitle: Will AM do the business?

fields.headline: Will AM do the business?
fields.standfirst: Business, not showbusiness, has produced this year's two great circulation leaps. As a new financial newspaper prepares to launch in Scotland,  David Teather examines the boom in City news.
fields.trailText: Business, not showbusiness, has produced this year's two great circulation leaps. As a new financial newspaper prepares to launch in Scotland, David Teather examines the boom in City news
fields.body:
Two of the most conspicuous newspaper success stories of recent years have built circulation not through titillation but from the sober concern of business news. In the past year, the FT's circulation has gone into overdrive, adding around 73,000 copies to bring its total daily figure to 459,000 - an increase of almost 19%. Sunday Business is 14% higher than a year ago, with summer sales levelling off at 60,000. The company maintains that advertising revenues are rocketing.

The impending launch of Business AM in Scotland has generated much debate about the need for another financial paper in a limited market. But the climate could hardly be better. The newspaper's existence is a product of the extraordinary explosion of interest in all things financial that has spawned not only new papers, but online services, TV channels, magazines and beefed-up attention in mainstream media.

The Guardian, which traditionally had an ambivalent relationship with the Square Mile, added pages to its financial section last year, while Greg Dyke made business coverage a priority at the BBC. The media's heightened interest in finance reflects the growing awareness that real power is shifting from politicians to big business. What Rupert Murdoch or Wal-Mart are up to can have as profound an effect on our lives as many political decisions.

During the BMW/Rover affair, it quickly became clear who was in control despite Westminster handwringing. Newspaper editors have been forced to reassess the traditional view that politics is the priority on the news agenda.

The genesis of public involvement in share ownership was the large-scale privatisation of the Thatcher era. In the 90s, that was cemented by the windfalls from demutualising building societies and insurers. According to the department of social security, a third of Britons now own shares.

Interest has also been raised by widespread home ownership, providing many with a sizeable lump sum of capital for the first time - another Thatcher legacy. Cash in the bank and a private pension invested in the stock market produces a vested interest in the economy and sharpens your interest in the financial pages.

Jeff Randall, editor of Sunday Business, says the creeping changes in attitude set the scene for the launch of the paper two and a half years ago. "We unearthed a market most people didn't believe existed because they misjudged the massive social shift in Britain towards interest in business and ownership of shares," he says. "Even my minicab driver has shares in BT, Norwich Union and the Woolwich."

The internet goldrush has brought a younger, sexier type of businessman or woman into the frame - think Martha Lane Fox rather than the middle-aged balding pinstripe of old. John Penman, Business AM editor, and a former political editor of the Scotsman, says: "At conference at the Scotsman, the business editor used to come in and nobody would understand what he was talking about - it was like a masonic code. But that's not right because business affects everyone. Where TV shows like Working Lunch have got it right is by making the subject accessible. In Sweden, share ownership is up to 65% of the population and they refer to business as the new rock'n'roll."

Financial information can now be sourced from a seemingly endless stream of online services such as Thestreet.co.uk, Interactive Investor International and Breakingviews.com. The internet is also playing an increasing part as an easy medium for buying or sell ing shares. For many, going into a stockbrokers would be akin to going into a bookies or a sex shop - a little off-putting. The other recent success has been the influx of US business magazines including Forbes Global and Business Week which have been steadily building circulation. Deregulation of the financial services industry has also created a vast advertising base to support new titles whether they are well read or not.

If any doubts were left that finance had gone mainstream, they were dashed by the Sun and Mirror which earlier this year staged an extraordinary battle on their front pages attacking each other's City sections. The Mirror's City Slickers played a notable part in encouraging a punt on the stock market and their downfall of investing in their own tips also proved another point: business can provide some ripping yarns.
