webTitle: Media: Scottish newspapers

fields.headline: Title fight
fields.standfirst: A new contender is poised to enter the bloody battleground of Scottish daily newspapers. But  Tim Luckhurst  wonders whether Scotland, even with its first parliament in 300 years, has enough going on to sustain 22 papers.
fields.trailText: A new contender is poised to enter the bloody battleground of Scottish daily newspapers. But Tim Luckhurst wonders whether Scotland, even with its first parliament in 300 years, has enough going on to sustain 22 papers
fields.body:
At first glance, Scotland needs a new newspaper about as badly as it needs tartan and shortbread. Including the Scottish editions of London titles, this small country of fewer than 5.5m souls already has 21 daily publications. And the existing titles are not commercially complacent. A circulation war is already raging. When the Bonnier family's Business AM hits the news-stands for the first time on Wednesday morning, it will find itself, like the Prussians at Waterloo, fighting on a battlefield already strewn with macabre debris.

Two years ago, Scottish journalism was complacent and smug. Devolution was coming. Everyone was certain that the good times were about to roll. They didn't. Whether Scots anticipated better than their newspapers the political mediocrity they were about to confront is a moot point. The facts are simple. The existence of a Scottish national parliament has not sold a single additional copy. Indeed, until the Scotsman launched its new format and new price in May, the only beneficiaries of modest churn in an otherwise declining market were London broadsheets and blue tops - particularly the Daily Mail. And they ignore Holyrood as much as they can.

Andrew Neil, publisher of the Scotsman, can take credit for throwing the first stone. He recognised that the paper's commitment to Edinburgh politics was failing to attract readers. Whether the Neil revolution can deliver long-term success remains to be seen. There is a growing perception in Scotland that the Scotsman and the Herald are engaged in a feud which can only end in disaster.

Can Business AM succeed? Richard Neville, deputy editor of the newpaper and former deputy editor of the Scotsman, is confident that it can. The Bonnier team questions the claim that Scotland has too many newspapers. "Scotland has 21 daily titles. Countries of comparable size have many more. Sweden has 100, Switzerland 95 and Belgium 29. Our target community is made up of 620,000 working A/Bs and C1s earning more than £21,000. We think 10% of that community is a realistic settled market for Business AM," Neville explains.

He and colleagues are adamant that their newspaper is a "market-expansion product". In layman's terms that means it is aimed at people who do not currently buy newspapers. But Neil perceives Business AM as a direct challenge to the Scotsman. He has launched a huge new business section in a bid to suffocate the Bonnier title at birth. The Herald is also giving more prominence to its business coverage. Neville says they are wasting paper and energy. "Two-thirds of Scotsman and Herald readers are not interested in business and finance," he claims. "Sixty per cent of our target market do not read an English or Scottish broadsheet. There is a media gap. If you want to reach all A/B readers with newspaper advertising, you can buy space in every English and Scottish title and still only reach 20% of those in Scotland."

The Bonnier strategy is to provide something those missing readers cannot get. It knows its newspaper will be a second buy for others - it will not even attempt to cover sport - but the Swedish company is confident that its target readers can afford to buy two newspapers and will not hesitate to grab a product which offers them real excellence.

The excellence, not the market research, will be the defining issue. Scottish newspapers have many limitations. First, they are locals not nationals. For all the protestations of national status from the Scotsman and the Herald, they are both city-state products. In that sense they are little different from the Aberdeen Press and Journal or the Dundee Courier.

More important than the geographically isolated nature of their core circulations is the obvious cheapness of the indigenous titles. The editor of the Scottish edition of the Daily Mail has a larger budget than my predecessor and I individually had at the Scotsman (I have discovered since leaving). Small circulations have driven the Scottish broadsheets to attempt to compete with their London rivals on the basis of editorial spends of less than half. And salary costs do not compensate for the difference; Scottish journalists are now earning close to London salaries.

The results, until recently, were newspapers which did well on domestic (Scottish) news, poorly on the rest of the UK, abysmally on features, and which hardly tried on foreign, business, commentary or analysis. The Barclay brothers (owners of the Scotsman) deserve thanks for trying to change that. In the past four years the Scotsman has had editorial investment to allow it to match perhaps 70% of what the London dailies do. Unfortunately the promotion required to deliver a readership commensurate with the investment has only taken effect since the newspaper began shedding quality staff. The Scotsman is now well financed but desperately short of talent. Andrew Neil is a great journalist and an inspired iconoclast. He will never win a prize for personnel management.

And the obvious combination of expansion and turmoil at the Scotsman has not gone unnoticed in Glasgow. The Herald has appointed a new editor and deputy. There is already evidence of change and an expectation that more will follow. SMG, owner of the Herald, Scottish Television, Grampian TV and Ginger Media, is a profitable minnow in the ITV world and clearly vulnerable to a bid by Carlton or Granada. In the long term, a takeover looks likely, but SMG's chief executive, Andrew Flanagan, shows no signs of lying down and waiting to be bought. He is good at maximising the return for his shareholders and that means maximising the value of his assets. Flanagan is not about to allow the Herald to be destroyed by the Scotsman. Investment and improvements are happening at the Glasgow title too.

That is the problem. As Business AM launches, the existing Scottish qualities are strangling each other. Herald circulation has tumbled in the past decade (from 130,000 to no more than 95,000 today). The Scotsman's assault has inflicted more damage, but at huge cost to the Barclay brothers. They have spent millions, lost two editors in a year, are widely expected to lose a third before Christmas and have shed almost 50% of the Scotsman team since April.

Neil describes this as a cathartic disposal of old carthorses. He is always pugnacious - but he is wrong. The people who have left the paper are the very talent that was hired by the Barclays' editorial investment.

Where will it end? A theory is gaining currency in Scotland. Business AM will achieve enough to survive because it has the backing to do so and the talent to deliver excellence to a narrowly defined niche market. In doing so it will further nibble at the already fragile circulations of the Herald and the Scotsman. At this point a Scottish champion will emerge to unite the two historic titles and create a powerful and influential Scottish title.

The theory is not new. It is the logic of the Scottish market. But there are new factors apart from Business AM. SMG is in play and would sell the Herald if that made remaining assets more valuable as a target in the great ITV consolidation, or if the sale helped SMG expand its own television holdings (for example by buying HTV).

Then there are the Barclay brothers. Traders with their track record do not simply slumber while their newspaper is rendered unprofitable and massively unpopular. The crisis will come when the Scotsman returns to a commercially realistic price - which eventually it must - or when the famously private David and Frederick Barclay recognise that the air of permanent crisis at the paper is harming more than Andrew Neil's reputation. Neil might be neither ashamed nor unhappy if he won an award as the "most controversial man in Scotland" but his employers are unlikely to celebrate when the hostility rebounds on them. In a country as small as Scotland it eventually will.

 Tim Luckhurst is a former editor of the Scotsman

SMG is in play and would sell the Herald if that made remaining assets more valuable as a target in the great ITV consolidation, or if the sale helped SMG expand its own television holdings (for example by buying HTV). Then there are the Barclay brothers. Traders with their track record do not simply slumber while their newspaper is rendered unprofitable and massively unpopular. The crisis will come when the Scotsman returns to a commercially realistic price - which eventually it must - or when the famously private David and Frederick Barclay recognise that the air of permanent crisis at the paper is harming more than Andrew Neil's reputation. Neil might be neither ashamed nor unhappy if he won an award as the "most controversial man in Scotland" but his employers are unlikely to celebrate when the hostility rebounds on them. In a country as small as Scotland it eventually will.  Tim Luckhurst is a former editor of the Scotsman

webTitle: The fuel story in pictures

fields.headline: The fuel story in pictures
fields.trailText: In a bewilderingly topsy-turvy week - when the Daily Mail showed sympathy for picketers and the usually supine Mirror snarled at New Labour - the easiest task for the tabloids was deciding whom to cast pictorially as villains. By Friday, when two of them had put up prices, oil company bosses belatedly became public enemy number one, with the Mirror devoting a spread to mugshots of the guilty quintet and even the Mail (not normally known for its attacks on capitalists pursuing profit) depicting Esso's chief exiting No 10 after a "carpeting".
fields.body:
In a bewilderingly topsy-turvy week - when the Daily Mail showed sympathy for picketers and the usually supine Mirror snarled at New Labour - the easiest task for the tabloids was deciding whom to cast pictorially as villains. By Friday, when two of them had put up prices, oil company bosses belatedly became public enemy number one, with the Mirror devoting a spread to mugshots of the guilty quintet and even the Mail (not normally known for its attacks on capitalists pursuing profit) depicting Esso's chief exiting No 10 after a "carpeting".

Competing for the arch-villain role was John Prescott, seen fuming and fidgeting when cross-examined on GMTV in Thursday's Sun - which devoted most of a page the following day to his battered, exhausted face - and "taking to his heels" after the disastrous TV interview in the Mirror. Photographed smirking smugly in Friday's Mail, but only as part of an assemblage of crisis images, Gordon Brown got off surprisingly lightly; he figured, however, in the front page photomontage of Wednesday's Mirror, portraying Blair, Brown and Prescott as a troika of inept, impotent fools, their heads atop empty petrol pumps.

Equally easy was casting the public as long-suffering heroes and heroines, stoically struggling to work despite queues, jams and shortages: nurses filling up at garages were much in evidence, closely followed by commuters using fossil fuel-free forms of transport such as unicycles, rollerblades and even a sedan chair.

Trickier was knowing how to present two key images: the pickets and - bearing in mind that all the London tabloids urged their readers to vote for him - Tony Blair. The shots of a grim Blair at his crisis press conferences were virtually identical, but what did they express: determination and decisive leadership, or frustrated recognition of having been caught on the hop? Perhaps regretting having given the government the image it wanted of tankers at last on the move on Wednesday, unlike the mutinous Mirror, the Sun used the PM's face on its front page on both Thursday ("Blair Crisis Deepens") and Friday ("60 Days to Sort it Tony"). No paper, however, dared to give him the Prescott treatment: the Mirror came closest on Tuesday with the week's strongest front-page image - also used uncredited by the Sun on an inside page - showing his Jaguar speeding insouciantly past a petrol station queue.

As for the pickets, although the Mail's editorial line condemned civil disobedience, its photographers had clearly been instructed to shoot them favourably: in a Wednesday article by Glenda Cooper, for example, words ("A Very British Blockade: They talked of summer holidays, Radio 4 and why they feel New Labour has betrayed them") and cheery yet resolute faces combined to convey an unequivocal message - these are our sort of people. The same approach was evident in the photo of a protesting mother and son accompanying leader-page rumblings ("A Very Middle Class Revolt") by Simon Heffer; and it reached its apogee in Thursday's extraordinary front page. Suspiciously convenient - was it a single fortuitous shot, or "staged", or two shots spliced together? - this showed a smiling father carrying a fist-waving young son on his shoulders, next to placards reading "Support British Agriculture" and (markedly smaller) "Justice For UK Hauliers".

This was a rightwing version of socialist realism, its pose ironically familiar from many a poster appealing for solidarity with such foes of the Mail as striking miners. Significantly, though, the paper portrayed the alliance of farmers, hauliers and motorists in the most heroic light precisely at the moment when it was telling them to stop: above the image, the vatic voice of "Daily Mail Comment" urged an end to blockades "while you still hold the moral high ground".

Every tabloid picture of last week's crisis told an ideological story, with expression, caption and surrounding text combining to leave the reader in no doubt how to view the person depicted. In the broadsheets, in con trast, photos were secondary and illustrative, and every effort was made to purge them of political messages, largely by favouring inanimate scenes of chaos - convoys, parked tankers, petrol-less garages, empty supermarket shelves - with no tell-tale faces from whose expressions the paper's stance could be inferred. This policy was taken to extremes in the Telegraph, which turned its fuel crisis pages into a dehumanised visual wasteland and, when it could bring itself to photograph picketers, bafflingly preferred to view them from the rear. No broadsheet showed Blair's Jag passing the petrol queue.

Challenged by tabloids turning their front pages into anti-government posters to come up with something equally striking, the broadsheets offered neutral images - a map (Independent), the feet of a man filling jerry cans (Times), a petrol pump's last drop (Guardian). When the latter was nicked by the Mirror the following day, it had inevitably acquired a message, with Piers Morgan strangely finding himself singing from the same hymn sheet as the Mail's Paul Dacre in telling the blockaders "Enough is Enough".

This is not to say that comment was studiously restricted to text in the quality press, of course, as the art of the political cartoon (virtually extinct in the tabloids) is still flourishing in the broadsheets. And it was in these cartoons that the only negative images of the picketers were to be found. The Independent's Dave Brown portrayed a crazed haulier holding a petrol pump/gun to the head of a tied-up planet Earth ("Cut the price . . . or I won't be able to blow his brains out"). A Peter Brookes cartoon in the Times showed the lorry of a sinister, thuggish trucker dwarfing a petrified bunny with the face of Tony Blair. And Steve Bell in Thursday's Guardian produced the most hostile image of all, depicting a scowling bunch of picketers as "Fat Blokes United in Disgruntlement". Identified by the Daily Mail as decent middle-class folk who naturally took the Mail, they here became surly, red-top-reading morons.

webTitle: Poisoned chalice, anybody?

fields.headline: Poisoned chalice, anybody?
fields.standfirst: It's been a turbulent week at the top of the BBC. Peter Salmon is off to sport and Lorraine Heggessey is now the first female controller of BBC1.  Maggie Brown  reports.
fields.trailText: It's been a turbulent week at the top of the BBC. Peter Salmon is off to sport and Lorraine Heggessey is now the first female controller of BBC1. Maggie Brown reports
fields.body:
What are the implications of the great BBC reshuffle? Two things: that Greg Dyke has a controller remarkably similar to himself in personality and that women are storming the best jobs in television. But improving BBC1 is going to take time and patience. Between two to four years, says a cautious Mark Thompson, director of TV and Dyke's right-hand man: "This is like planning for D-Day, piece by piece. We're not going to rush things, and run out of steam, like ITV." Michael Jackson at Channel 4, he points out, has taken three years to get it buzzing.

The joke about the diminutive Lorraine Heggessey, new controller of BBC1, is that she's one of the few executives Greg Dyke can look down on. The serious point is that she won the most coveted creative job in TV by impressing him enough to trust her with it. Peter Salmon, the outgoing BBC1 controller, says: "I'm not bitter at all, I loved every minute of it, if someone offered it to me again, I'd do it again." He describes Heggessey as "very similar to Dyke in temperament, full of energy, a ball of fire. He's instinctual about people. He recognised in her a good picker [of hit programmes]. Greg and Mark [Thompson] have taken her to their hearts. And with backers like that..." - he trails off, but the implication is that with trust you can do anything.

She has been on the rise for the past eight years, ending up as deputy to Matthew Bannister in the production wing formed by the now discredited broadcast/production split, and seized her chance during this year's reorganisation, relentlessly burning the midnight oil devising Dyke-friendly plans.

Critics see this as shameless buttering up and self-promotion, but like Dyke, she knows her worth and, like him, she makes things happen. Her credits range from Animal Hospital and The Human Body to revitalising BBC's children's output. Popular factual programmes will be prominent in her BBC1, with much more drama.

She can seem a mite careless as well as decisive. In the reorganisation which saw her emerge as joint head of learning and factual, one of the BBC's most talented documentary executives, Paul Hamann, was ruthlessly left jobless. And while she championed the breakthrough children's drama Microsoap, in collaboration with Disney, there was no second series.

Heggessey describes herself as "a very positive person". She bustles with infectious energy and humour - just like Dyke. But she is also restless. "All programmes on BBC1 have to be popular. They have to be good and popular," she says. "The question is, are you in touch with what the viewing public wants to watch?" Dyke's advisers tried to temper his Edinburgh promise that moving the news to 10pm will attract more viewers, but Heggessey's pledge to "try very hard to reverse the ratings decline" shows they are in agreement on strategy.

 Heggessey's appointment cements the advancement of women. With Jane Root at BBC2, both main channels will be female-run. In the past year, two women have also become national controllers in Wales (Menna Richards) and Northern Ireland (Anna Carragher). Richards is resolutely shaking up a fusty, male-dominated BBC Wales and planning its creative fightback, while Carragher has been handed one of the most politically sensitive of BBC jobs. But then so has Helen Boaden, controller of Radio 4, who is operating smoothly under the helpful eye of patron Jenny Abramsky, director of BBC Radio and another fizzy Dyke-style manager.

Carragher explains: "I think we're seeing the fruits of changes which began 10 to 15 years ago when women started to be promoted, and were helped to become more ambitious. We've become a bit more aggressive, too." The great setback of 1996, when Birt's heavy-handed management reorganisation notoriously kept women away from the top broadcasting posts, was only temporary. And Dyke has also made a multi-cultural BBC his aim. Carragher adds: "I hope to God we'll have Asian and black controllers next."

 It would be wrong to see Peter Salmon's move to director of BBC Sport as a sidelining. There's going to be a joint venture commercial sports network using the BBC's archive portfolio - either with NTL or, if that fails, Flextech/ Telewest - which he'll launch. And a long overdue shake-up for the way the BBC covers sport. Salmon may be the salvation for sports programmes.

While cynics say the job isn't all it's cracked up to be, with the Premier League/FA Cup deals sewn up, the truth is different. There's a huge opportunity for fresh thinking. BBC Sport has drifted for two years, demoralised by the old production/broadcasting split, dividing responsibility between a miscast Mike Miller, hired by Alan Yentob from Channel 4, and Bob Shennan, now controller of Radio 5 Live, who had a radio background.

With the grumps at Grandstand and Match of the Day to deal with, Salmon has the chance to make a difference. A BBC executive committee member says: "Sport needs fresh blood and ideas. They're inward looking, dyed-in-the wool."

Salmon is flying to the Olympics to study the coverage. He's interested in NBC's approach to winning huge audiences, which links sporting achievements to the human interest stories behind them. He also points to Channel 4's cricket triumph. BBC TV sport has failed to match the clever graphics and instant analysis of its rivals. As the top executive adds: "They got left behind, they dubbed Sky coverage gimmicky, but now it's the norm."

webTitle: Media: Radio ratings

fields.headline: Dear diary, still
fields.standfirst: The ratings systems for radio audiences is an absurd charade, said Kelvin MacKenzie. Not so, replies  Jane O'Hara
fields.trailText: The ratings systems for radio audiences is an absurd charade, said Kelvin MacKenzie. Not so, replies Jane O'Hara
fields.body:
Collection of data on radio audiences via diaries is old fashioned and inaccurate, according to Kelvin MacKenzie (Media Guardian, September 4), who went on to say that collection should move quickly to a digital meter-driven system. Unfortunately, some of the information he was supplied with was incorrect. So, before addressing the issues, I'll clarify the background.

Rajar, which puts together the ratings for Britain's radio stations, is owned 50:50 by the BBC and Commercial Radio Companies Association. More than 130,000 people a year complete a listening diary, producing data for over 260 radio stations, making Rajar the largest, most complex media survey outside the US.

The first Rajar paper looking at meters was produced for its board in October 1996. Before this, and subsequently, both Rajar and our research contractor, Ipsos-RSL, have continued to monitor meter developments worldwide. Indeed Ipsos-RSL visited the Swiss-based Radiocontrol (SRG SSR) in May 1996 and again in May 1997 when it presented the early version of its Radiocontrol meter. Thus MacKenzie was misled when he was told that "TalkSport's inquiry was the first sign of interest from the radio industry in the UK".

I fear he has also been misled over the BBC's withdrawal of some services from the meter test in Manchester by the American audience research company, Arbitron. This test covered radio and TV. BBC1 and BBC2 remained in the test, but BBC Radio withdrew because of faulty encoding equipment from Arbitron. The decision to take the encoding equipment out of the broadcast chain was made after complaints from listeners and not before the BBC had switched to back-up equipment, which also appeared faulty. Following the BBC's tests of the equipment, Arbitron has, to its credit, stepped up its quality control.

In fact, the Manchester test has supplied useful information. Although the overall listening level is obviously wrong following the BBC's understandable withdrawal, it has been possible to compare metered audience data versus diary data for commercial stations.

Looking at the bigger picture, MacKenzie said radio research is "based on the widely discredited diary system" and that meters are "accurate". There is no evidence (yet) to support the latter point and it has been proved using coincidental research that the diary methodology provides the closest estimate of radio reach and listening hours. Discredited? Hardly. But that is not to say that there won't be a place for new technology. As MacKenzie rightly says, meters can offer many advantages, including near instant data.

But before switching from diaries, the radio industry must be sure that meters can identify the correct station ID, can include all stations irrespective of frequency and work in all locations. And the cost must be reasonable: moving to meters now would increase costs by many multiples of the current (£4m per year) research cost. Since the radio industry pays for the research, this could be one reason why MacKenzie shouldn't be "astounded that the radio industry is not up in arms seeking a change".

Less obvious issues include meter practicality for users. Kelvin mentioned "an old dear" filling in a diary. We know "old dears" do fill them in, just as young men and mums fill them in - 3,000 every week in fact. It is less certain at this stage if everybody will be prepared to, say, wear a meter. A meter for radio has to be worn because we can't meter the set, as in television. It could be that men are more likely than women to strap on Arbitron's pager-like meter or the Radiocontrol "watch", creating sampling problems. Also, we need to be sure how people use the meters: will they activate them the minute they wake? Will they leave them in the bedroom while they have a shower?

These are just some of the issues we have been addressing. There are still so many questions that it is no surprise that meter-based radio research has not yet been implemented in any major market. It may be that the UK becomes the first such market to go live with meters, but not before, and only if, the Rajar board is certain the radio industry will benefit.

 Jane O'Hara is managing director of Rajar

webTitle: Crisis, what crisis?

fields.headline: Crisis, what crisis?
fields.standfirst: A week is a long time in politics and newspapers - especially when the nation is in turmoil.  Roy Greenslade reveals how press and government were slow to catch on to the fuel crisis, and how the papers made up for lost time.
fields.trailText: A week is a long time in politics and newspapers - especially when the nation is in turmoil. Roy Greenslade reveals how press and government were slow to catch on to the fuel crisis, and how the papers made up for lost time
fields.body:
The petrol crisis crept up on both press and government. What appeared at first to be a little local difficulty well to the north of London suddenly erupted into a nationwide event. But Fleet Street was more alert than Downing Street. Ahead of the pack was the Daily Mail with its prescient front page at the tail end of the French fuel protest: "When will OUR petrol run dry?" The Mail's report that weekend referred to the imminent dangers of ignoring the protests. It had said the same during its ill-fated "Dump the Pump" campaign, so the government evidently ignored the warning.

While prime minister Tony Blair dealt with the dramas in Sierra Leone, the papers were drawn to the perils facing Sierra man. Perhaps the clearest sign of the coming emergency, and the policy line of the rightwing press, was the Sunday Telegraph's headline eight days ago: "Petrol panic as Labour refuses to act." At least that paper recognised the importance of the story: it was the only Sunday title to accord it proper prominence.

Most reports the following day forecast that, with 200 petrol stations already dry, there were problems ahead. But there was still a vague sense of uncertainty among editors. Comment was somewhat muted because, surely, oil companies would not fail to get supplies past a raggle-taggle picket of tractors and lorries. The turning point came on Tuesday when the Sun ("Great petrol revolt 2000"), Mirror ("I'm all right Jag"), Daily Mail ("Running on empty") and Daily Telegraph ("Panic as the pumps run dry") found common cause.

"It is difficult not to sympathise with the protesters," commented the Telegraph, scourge of miners' pickets, castigator of poll tax marchers, detractor of all extra-parliamentary, undemocratic action. Telegraph columnist Janet Daley's viewpoint was also revealing: "If the chancellor still has to rob you at the petrol pump to finance improvements in education and health, then he is an appallingly bad financial manager. So honk, honk, honk - for as long as it takes." Daley has not been noted previously for encouraging militant action by horny-handed men of toil, but she accurately reflected what was to become the majority press reaction.

The Mail, while disapproving of "the civil disobedience now convulsing this country", urged Blair to try "conciliation rather than confrontation". I seem to recall the Mail giving a somewhat different piece of advice to Margaret Thatcher when she was facing out Arthur Scargill's pickets. The Sun, which inches closer week by week to its old Tory beliefs, urged Blair to placate the protesters by cutting the tax on fuel. Its columnist Richard Littlejohn offered unqualified support to the farmers and hauliers, urging more direct action. Hardly surprising, perhaps, but what did we read in a Sun article celebrating "All-time great British revolts"? At the end of a list which praised popular uprisings - including Wat Tyler's revolt and Cromwell's rebellion - came the poll tax riots. I don't seem to recall the Sun backing that uprising at the time.

The first genuine indication of the depth of newspaper opposition to Blair was illustrated by the Labour-supporting Mirror's front page on Tuesday, showing Blair's car passing a packed garage forecourt, which questioned the wisdom of his refusal to compromise. The Independent was also sniffy about governmental "woolliness", urging chancellor Gordon Brown to speak out. But there were exceptions: the Guardian and the Daily Express said Brown must not be coerced.

The Times managed to blame everyone: the oil companies for the surge in prices; the "motley blockade" of "sitting pickets"; and the government's "risible political response". In a more balanced assessment, the paper's City editor Patience Wheatcroft argued that Big Oil was allowing the chancellor to take the heat, yet he was "right to stand firm".

OK, let's turn off the engine for just a moment to conserve the political petrol. Journalists will rightly argue that there is another way to consider press coverage: assessing it as a technical exercise. Which papers presented the most accurate and comprehensive information in the most understandable form?

Over the course of the week, the Mail won the battle of quantity, devoting more space to the story than any other paper. The Financial Times offered the least. At times like this it is obvious why the FT will remain a secondary purchase and never supplant its rivals. Some of its articles were excellent (such as Roula Khalaf on the problems of the Middle East's oil-producing nations and Brian Groom's dispassionate account of the plight of farmers and hauliers) but it just didn't provide a proper service to its readers.

A qualitative appraisal, which is necessarily subjective, awards high marks to the Independent for its Tuesday front page graphic (so good that it appeared daily thereafter); to the Times for its even-handed reporting; to the Guardian for its clarity and expansive coverage; to the Sun and the Mirror for their visual projection, though the Mirror's graphics were not up to scratch. Without being critical of what did appear, it is impossible to overlook the fact that two papers with stretched resources - the Independent and the Daily Express - obviously struggled to compete.

Several papers used allegorical pictures with masterly skill - pumps with stickers, empty petrol stations, a drip at the end of a pump nozzle. In strictly presentational terms, most papers did quite well. But once we look at the content it is impossible to avoid making value judgments about the fairness of reporting, comment and headline-writing, which, of course, have politics at their core. After its initial hiccup, the Independent's leaders were sensible and balanced. Similarly, the Times was notable for its impartiality. Its Thursday leader was typical, asking searching questions about the pusillanimous behaviour of the tanker drivers and their oil company employers while contending that the government should have put Big Oil under greater pressure.

Even-handedness was in shorter supply than unleaded petrol among the tabloids. The Daily Mail led the charge on Wednesday with 11 pages on the crisis, but it was Lynda Lee-Potter's column which caught the eye. "Truck drivers as a race are the old-fashioned kind of British working class," she argued. "They aren't anarchists, troublemakers or fascists" but "decent working men who only want a reasonable deal". The Sun's Littlejohn, even by his vitriolic standards, was vicious on Thursday, but it was the Mirror's Tony Parsons who showed the new mood: "It took the Tories almost 20 years to become a bunch of smug, self-righteous, out-of-touch morons who turned your stomach... New Labour managed it in more like 20 months." The Sun accused ministers of telling "7 great lies" in a bid to dodge responsibility. The first, it alleged, was a false claim that hospitals were in crisis. It also stressed that newspapers were not encouraging the blockades: "This is a genuine people's protest."

Genuine in what sense, though? There can be little doubt that many of the people on the picket lines, particularly farmers and some of the hauliers, have suffered hardship due to petrol price rises. Then again, many miners outside the Saltley coke works in 1984 were justifiably aggrieved about their future livelihoods. What papers always wish to deny is the influence they have in building - or eroding - public support for demonstrators. If editors had treated the picketing farmers to the onslaught with which they greeted the miners, what would have happened then to the people's protest?

It is easy to gather support among the population for a campaign based on the slogan "pay less tax". The papers were pushing at an open door. Their cosy interviews with the self-appointed picket leaders, casting them as hard-done-by heroes, were calculated to win sympathy. The Mail told the story of a self-employed trucker, detailing his budget in stark terms to reveal the paucity of his income. Nothing wrong with that, of course, but the Mail would never think of offering such a compassionate hearing to a striking trade unionist.

Just as significant was what these papers didn't do. A trade union leader bringing the country to a halt would be subjected to the most intense investigation by rightwing tabloids in order to uncover even a hint of hypocrisy. Where did he last go on holiday? How much did he spend on his daughter's wedding? What do his friends and relatives think about him? Has he had an extra-marital affair? Every attempt would be made to undermine that person's credibility in order to bring him into public disrepute.

In fact, there were areas for inquiry which were not followed up. One example was revealed in a fascinating Guardian article by Leanda de Lisle, who said she regularly received faxes from a group called the Farmers and Hauliers Alliance. What "sinister anarchist body" was this? The reason for the papers' enthusiastic backing of the fuel protesters was twofold. First, among the rightwing papers there is a belief that - in the absence of an effective Tory party - they are now the only hope of opposition to a Labour government they despise.

Among the nominally pro-Blair papers, such as the Mirror and Sun, the situation is more complicated. Desperate to avoid being seen as kneejerk government supporters, they are also aware of the need to remain populist. And there is no more populist cause than the simplistic one of cutting taxes.

None of that should divert us from one obvious point: Blair reacted too late to the emergency. Newspapers spun the story their way before his spinners had the chance to do their job. This influenced broadcasters too, with TV and radio news quickly adopting the press agenda. The prime minister, of all people, knows the importance of the media in such situations. This time he lost the plot. Next time he may lose his job, as the polls in yesterday's Sunday Times and News of the World illustrated. Even the normally loyal Sunday Mirror called on Blair to cut fuel tax, another indication that newspapers are determined to obtain some kind of victory over the government on behalf of a public which they have marched to the top of the hill.

webTitle: Sex, drugs and rock'n'roll stars: the lethal cocktail that ended in tragedy

fields.headline: Sex, drugs and rock'n'roll stars: the lethal cocktail that ended in tragedy
fields.trailText: After two decades spent living in the public eye, the final act of Paula Yates had no audience. It was a tragic end to what was to the outside world a glamorous, if turbulent, life of sex, drugs and rock'n'roll stars.
fields.body:
After two decades spent living in the public eye, the final act of Paula Yates had no audience. It was a tragic end to what was to the outside world a glamorous, if turbulent, life of sex, drugs and rock'n'roll stars.

Since 1982, pretty much everything she did had attracted headlines, often at her own behest. But the media maelstrom around Yates grew so much more intense after a chat in bed with the rock star Michael Hutchence.

She had interviewed the Australian frontman of the band INXS for Channel 4's Big Breakfast programme, made by a production company owned by her husband, Bob Geldof. With their legs entwined, the mutual attraction that would consume and destroy her marriage to Geldof was obvious to those watching.

Yates became famous as the front woman of the Tube, the groundbreaking Channel 4 music programme. She was hired for the job by Andrea Wonfor, the show's executive producer: "Everything changed after she met Michael Hutchence. She threw everything away and found nothing left after he died."

In 1982 Yates, then 22, burst on to television screens. With her blonde hair and low-cut, tight dresses, she came across as a wild child. The reality, says Ms Wonfor, was very different.

Restrained

Compared to the later stories of drugs and drink, her time at the Tube was relatively restrained as she soon became pregnant with her first child: "For the whole five years of the Tube, Paula was the bloody boring one. She'd go to bed at 9.30pm, when everyone else was in the bar, and be back up at 6.30am to take Fifi for a swim," Ms Wonfor remembers.

Yates began dating Geldof, the frontman of the band the Boomtown Rats, in 1977. She was determined to have him and stuck so close to him that other band members called her "the limpet".

Paula and Bob were one of the most fashionable couples of the 1980s, but their paths to the outside world were diverging. She, to some, appeared narcissistic and shallow, happy only in the world of celebrity and rock stars. He went off to fight famine in Africa and became "Saint Bob" after masterminding Band Aid.

Their marriage was dogged by persistent rumours of Geldof's infidelity and from their public utterances Geldof and Yates had different expectations about their relationship, and about the role of passion. "To live your life in a state of passion would be tedious because everything is distorted. It is extremely dull and limiting. Sexual passion burns out," Geldof once said.

Seven months before she left Geldof, Yates told an interviewer she thought of herself as a "steaming Jezebel given half an opportunity. Why can't I be? Why can I only be this great lactating person?".

Asked if she was storing up an emotional time bomb, she replied: "It probably is, and I say to Bob it will be terrible. It will be like the Exorcist."

By February 1995 she had found her source of passion and left Geldof for Michael Hutchence. But she would pay a terrible price for bagging what she called "God's gift to women" and a man who possessed the "Taj Mahal of crotches".

Geldof was determined not to surrender custody of their three daughters, Fifi Trixibelle, Peaches and Pixie, and the bitterness of the split sapped the joy she found with Hutchence, whom she had fallen for deeply. "She did really love Michael, she was mad about him," said a friend last night. But it was Hutchence who introduced Yates to a drink- and drug-fuelled lifestyle: "That's when the spiral of decline started," the friend said.

The break-up with Geldof was acrimonious and detailed by the tabloids, with Yates's connivance. She went to the house they had shared in Chelsea and after shouting abuse at him, threw a rock through a window. Friends were authorised to leak details of the bitter wrangle and Yates's financial straits as her debts at one stage reached £100,000.

In May 1996 the divorce was granted, and Geldof later won temporary custody of the children after a sweet tube containing opium was found at the home of Yates and Hutchence. They claimed it was planted.

If the fallout from her relationship with Geldof left Yates emotionally drained, the bizarre death of Michael Hutchence as good as broke her. The singer was found hanging in a Sydney hotel room in November 1997, having consumed vodka, beer, champagne, cocaine, Prozac and other prescription drugs. Yates could never accept it was suicide. The couple had a daughter, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily, who is now four years old. She described his death as like being "flung to the dogs", and tried to find comfort in Tiger Lily.

Yates branded Geldof "a killer" after it emerged Hutchence had hanged himself with a leather belt hours after pleading with the former Boomtown Rat over the custody of Yates's daughters with Geldof.

Yates later told an interviewer: "When Michael died I was tipped over the edge. I was beyond grief. I went completely mad.

"Now I'm starting, relatively, to think straight again. I live one day at a time, one hour at a time. What makes it all worthwhile is my children."

Rapid decline

Yates had to deal with more torment when it emerged that the man she thought was her father, the former Stars on Sunday star Jess Yates, was not. Her mother had had a relationship with the TV presenter Hughie Green and DNA tests showed that he was her real father.

Her decline became more and more rapid. She was admitted to a psychiatric hospital with depression and in June 1998 lost custody of her three daughters from her relationship with Geldof and, though to the outside world apparently effervescent, tried to end it all. A friend found her and she was admitted to a clinic.

Even there Yates found no stability. She began an affair with a heroin addict, which attracted more lurid tabloid headlines. The stories provoked Hutchence's family in Australia into proceedings to gain custody of Tiger Lily from Yates. When Yates ended the relationship, Hutchence's family dropped the lawsuit.

Yates was again in the headlines when she had a relationship with the rock star Finlay Quaye. And in 1999 it was reported that she had collapsed while her daughters with Geldof were staying with her, and that police had to take the children away.

Ms Wonfor, with whom Yates and her children stayed last year, said: "There was a culmination of the madness that overtook her with Michael's death and the change of her father. She is quite a fragile creature. She probably never grew up and maybe that was to do with her difficult childhood; she needed an arm around her a lot."

After the death of Hutchence, Yates was angered by news that Tiger Lily would only get £2m from the singer's will and became locked in a dispute with his estate.

An attempt at a television comeback flopped and earlier this year she won libel damages from the Mail on Sunday newspaper over claims she had deliberately and "deceitfully" become pregnant with Hutchence to try and ensnare him in a permanent relationship.

She found no let-up at the Notting Hill home she moved to last year, where she was pursued by a stalker.

Paula Yates made an art of getting what she desired: Geldof, fame, children and Hutchence. But ultimately, she could not get what she wanted: peace of mind.

1959 Paula Yates born to former Bluebell Girl Heller Toren. Her father is thought to be TV presenter Jess Yates

1976 Moves to London and meets Boomtown Rats singer Bob Geldof. His friends dub her "the limpet"

1978 Poses naked for Penthouse and publishes Rock Stars in Their Underpants, hailed by Andy Warhol as "the greatest work of art in the last decade"

1982 Co-hosts C4 music show The Tube with Jools Holland. Runs until 1987

1984 Writes and presents the TV series Baby, Baby on C4 after her first daughter Fifi Trixibelle is born

1986 Marries Geldof in Las Vegas

1990 After the birth of her second daughter Peaches, writes a book on motherhood

1992 Starts celebrity interviews - often conducted on a bed - for C4's The Big Breakfast.

1995 Leaves Geldof for INXS singer Michael Hutchence. She calls him "God's gift to women"

May 1996 After divorce, Yates goes back to her matrimonial house in Chelsea, while Geldof moves into Hutchence's home nearby

September 1996 A childcarer finds opium at Yates's home. Yates is arrested but not charged

October 1996 Geldof wins custody of the children, but later agrees to share the responsibility

May 1997 Hughie Green is revealed to be Yates's father

November 1997 Hutchence commits suicide in Sydney

April 1998 A depressed Yates is admitted to psychiatric hospital

June 1998 Yates loses custody of Fifi, Peaches and Pixie. She tries to hang herself

September 1998 Former lover, Kingsley O'Keke, claims she sleeps with Hutchence's ashes

March 1999 Yates presents An Evening With Jerry Springer, which flops

His friends dub her "the limpet" 1978 Poses naked for Penthouse and publishes Rock Stars in Their Underpants, hailed by Andy Warhol as "the greatest work of art in the last decade" 1982 Co-hosts C4 music show The Tube with Jools Holland. Runs until 1987 1984 Writes and presents the TV series Baby, Baby on C4 after her first daughter Fifi Trixibelle is born 1986 Marries Geldof in Las Vegas 1990 After the birth of her second daughter Peaches, writes a book on motherhood 1992 Starts celebrity interviews - often conducted on a bed - for C4's The Big Breakfast. 1995 Leaves Geldof for INXS singer Michael Hutchence. She calls him "God's gift to women" May 1996 After divorce, Yates goes back to her matrimonial house in Chelsea, while Geldof moves into Hutchence's home nearby September 1996 A childcarer finds opium at Yates's home. Yates is arrested but not charged October 1996 Geldof wins custody of the children, but later agrees to share the responsibility May 1997 Hughie Green is revealed to be Yates's father November 1997 Hutchence commits suicide in Sydney April 1998 A depressed Yates is admitted to psychiatric hospital June 1998 Yates loses custody of Fifi, Peaches and Pixie. webTitle: Keep it clean

fields.headline: Keep it clean
fields.standfirst: Advertisers have gone back to the bad old days of using sex to sell and exploiting women as images of desire.
fields.trailText: Advertisers have gone back to the bad old days of using sex to sell and exploiting women as images of desire, writes Madeleine Bunting.
fields.body:
There's an ad on billboards at the moment of a luscious, tousled-haired, half-dressed woman. Her lips are full, her eyes smouldering and a glimpse of naked midriff and knee suggest that all she's wearing is a loosely buttoned shirt. "Visible quickie" is the label; "Invisible deodorant" is the catchline.

The ad manages that rare feat of being both daft and offensive. Daft, because who gives a damn about sweating in the midst of passion? (If you disagree, visit a sex therapist.) Offensive because a) this huge image charged with sex is beaming down on kids, grannies and all, b) this woman is being defined by the sexual experience she offers - she is a "quickie" and c) the judgment of her sexual availability is being thrown to the viewer: if she looks a visible quickie to you, there is no need to check, just go for it.

The use of sex is in your face, and a revival of 70s-style advertising when women were draped all over cars. As a similarly nonplussed former advertising executive said, "It's like we've learnt nothing in the last 20 years. It's the laziest, least intelligent kind of advertising." It's nice to hear another adman putting the boot in, because one of the most frustrating things about this ad is that part of its purpose is to shock (denied, of course, by the manufacturers' spokeswoman).

Benetton led the way in using shock: you make the ad an event so people write columns like this and you get more bang for your buck. Those who protest are corralled with Mary Whitehouse and the product's position is strengthened in its target market as youthful, hip, taboo-breaking. Even if the ad is not targeted at you, your outrage is exploited. The last time I complained about an ad, I inadvertently contributed to the strapline of the follow-up campaign which ran something along the lines of, "Last time we ran this ad, women complained. No men." The protest is grist to the mill. Hard luck, you have no comeback over whatever some bunch of marketing execs decide to impose on your eyeballs.

But there's a curious phenomenon here. Another ad in the same invisible deodorant campaign is of a young woman in a classic top-shelf pose, bum in the air, to illustrate her visible panty line. This is a new kind of raunchiness in advertising directed exclusively at women. The same thing is true in a different campaign for hair colour. A woman peeks down her bikini bottom to remind herself of her true hair colour. While this ad is mischievous, it isn't particularly offensive yet it has clocked up the most complaints to the Advertising Standards Authority of any so far this year - 175. Whereas we are used to sex being used to sell to men, this is a new departure, using it to sell to women. (The Renault campaign, "Size matters", is another example.)

Given that all these ads will have been extensively researched with their target market of young women, they indicate a real shift in women's boundaries of what is acceptable in the ladette age - and it upsets people who don't like ladies to be crude. There's a subtle distinction here. Junking the sexist constraints on female humour is one thing (a good one). It is quite another to make a pernicious bid to pass off as sexually liberated (as the invisible deodorant campaign claims to be) what are really images of male desire. That would amount to women desiring what they think men desire. It's a classic form of oppression.

And don't forget, all this fuss is only about a blasted deodorant.Why does boring deodorant have to be eroticised? Do women (as opposed to men) have an erotic relationship with their car? Are there no limits to the products sex is used to advertise? Will hot-water bottles, cocoa and slippers be next? Or could advertising go the way of modern art: the shock factor results in diminishing returns. Instead of sex making deodorant desirable, it makes sex about as desirable as deodorant.

Unfortunately, there's no evidence so far that that is the case. Like it or not, advertising works. The "personal care" market - toothpaste, shampoo, soap, deodorant - has increased by £700m to an annual total of £4.7bn in the past five years. We're not getting any dirtier, but clever marketing has convinced us to part with all those extra millions of pounds. And it's no longer just women; men spend £65m more annually than they did five years ago.

One of the ways they pulled off this coup was weaning us off a 100-year habit of buying bars of soap. Lever Brothers announced recently that they were no longer going to manufacture bars of Lux and Lifebuoy; they have lost out to the liquid-soap dispenser and the shower gel, dropping from a 40% share of the market to 20% in just five years. According to a Lever Brothers spokesman, the humble bar is not as hygienic. The other way to look at it is that a bar lasts for months and is far cheaper, while most liquid soap (the same combination of caustic soda, oil, fat and synthetic smells) goes swiftly down the plughole at twice the price. Meanwhile, another niche market emerges - for "designer soaps". The bar is manoeuvred into the luxury position (huge mark-up) in the market, complete with seaweed, wheatgerm oil and aloe vera.

Our obsession with cleanliness is no trivial matter. It's a metaphor for Everything. Brad Pitt in the cult film Fight Club was a fraudulent soap salesman. His soap was handcrafted and tied with rough twine, but he made it from human fat stolen from the local crematorium. A comparable corruption underpins the personal-care industry, which manufactures millions of gallons of petrochemicals for us to pour down our drains in a bid for shiny hair and smooth skin.

We city dwellers feel comforted by an ersatz relationship with nature as we smear ourselves in tea-tree oil and mud packs. This is a utilitarian relationship with nature, in which it becomes a treasure chest of consumer goodies. It's also a fake relationship with ourselves: frustrated female appetites are consoled with olfactory stimulation: bananas, strawberries, raspberries in the soap or bath oil. We delude ourselves that we are looking after ourselves, lying in our bath perfumed with lavender essential oil surrounded by scented candles, when we'd do our skin far more good if we gave up coffee, alcohol and the rat race.

Finally, the cult of personal cleanliness is an ersatz religion. Our bathrooms ape a Catholic church - all smells and candles. These rituals of purification are comparable with those of devout Muslims, Jews or Hindus. The label on one lump of vegetable oil makes the point explicitly: "a soft floral bouquet of pink and yellow flowers leads you down the path to nirvana". Soap salvation. The "cleanliness is next to godliness" Puritans would have approved. All that's missing is the ritual sacrifice - the fatted calf.

But is it? Perhaps we are the sacrifice: stewing in our baths in those brief pauses between frenzied earning and spending money on things we'd never dreamt of - like invisible deodorant. That then needs washing off - the admen have got us every time.

webTitle: GP says TV shows 'a pain' for copycat gardeners

fields.headline: GP says TV shows 'a pain' for copycat gardeners
fields.trailText: Gardening shows on television should carry health warnings about over-exertion, a GP said yesterday.
fields.body:
Gardening shows on television should carry health warnings about over-exertion, a GP said yesterday.

Peter Skew, who has expertise in musculoskeletal medicine, said that programmes such as the BBC's Ground Force were contributing to a huge increase in the number of people with back pain.

The shows, in which often teams transformed gardens in a few days, were prompting people to attempt similar feats. He suggested that the shows should warn viewers of the risk.

A survey for Manarini Pharmaceuticals found that 56% of people over the age of 35 had suffered back pain from gardening, of whom 57% had been led to attempt improvements by the TV shows.

Dr Skew said: "The problem is people rush out to do the same thing themselves. They carry heavy sacks to and from the garden centre, don't give themselves enough time, and over-exert themselves by trying to get everything done in a few hours over the weekend. They risk serious damage to their backs, as well as their shoulders, wrists and other parts of their bodies."

People should start any work by going gently, he urged.

More than 11m working days are lost each year through back pain. This costs employers £5 bn.

webTitle: C4 rapped by ITC over spoof interview with rock star

fields.headline: C4 rapped by ITC over spoof interview with rock star
fields.trailText: Channel 4 is criticised today for screening a spoof interview with ex-Rolling Stone Bill Wyman without the star's permission.
fields.body:
Channel 4 is criticised today for screening a spoof interview with ex-Rolling Stone Bill Wyman without the star's permission.

The musician complained to the Independent Television Commission after he was duped into appearing in the chat sequence, used for the Candid Camera-style Trigger Happy TV show.

The ITC upheld the complaint and said the station had broken programme rules "by its failure to secure permission for the set-up interview".

Wyman was not named in the TV regulator's report after he asked not to be identified, but he has previously given an interview to Q magazine discussing his treatment.

He told Q: "I never was told it was a practical joke. I did the interview in the street and this guy was hanging around, as fans and curious people do.

"The interviewer just went mad and beat him up - it was quite vicious. When I found out it was a set-up - probably two or three weeks later - we complained bitterly and asked them not to use it. But we were unable to stop it."

The TV regulator's code allows "covert" interviews to be shown only where the subject gives permission or if there is an important public interest issue.

Channel 4 argued that Wyman seemed happy about his involvement at the time of the interview and the light-hearted show was not unfair to him so the station should be able to use the footage at its own discretion. But the ITC said permission should have been obtained and there was no discretion involved.

Complaints were also up held against ITV for screening early morning editions of the Jerry Springer Show during school holidays.

The programmes went out at 9.25am and a total of 69 viewers were upset by six editions of the show featuring aggressive guests or sexual discussions.

The ITC upheld further complaints against ITV for an on-air description of the drama Cor Blimey, which was inspired by the relationship between the actress Barbara Windsor and the late Sid James, her co-star in some of the Carry On films. James's wife and family had objected to the making of the show but were told by ITV it would be stressed the programme was a "drama", not a documentary.

However, just before it was screened the show was described as "the amazing but true story of life with the Carry Ons", which upset the James family. The ITC concluded it was introduced "in such a way as to confuse viewers as to the nature of the programme"

Thirteen complaints of lack of taste and decency against Keith Chegwin's all-nude Channel 5 gameshow, The Naked Jungle, were rejected, the ITC saying it was well after the watershed, and its content was "clearly signposted in advance". Channel 5 had argued it was trying to escape the view of public nudity "as something sordid which will frighten the horses".

Viewers also complained the series Stark Naked, tieing in with a naturists celebration, should not have featured nudity before 9pm. The ITC said there was no absolute bar if it was "defensible in context".
Press Association

webTitle: Media diary

fields.headline: Media diary
fields.body:
 Roger Eastoe, who suddenly resigned as group managing director of Trinity Mirror on Thursday, seemed to know the day before, at the emergency meeting of national newspaper circulation managers, that his time was up. Asked by those present to get his boss, Trinity chief executive Philip Graf, to use his New Labour connections to ease distributors' petrol problems, Eastoe replied: "Can't someone else do it?" Perhaps he was scared Graf would talk him into changing his mind.

 Good to see Telegraph legal eagle Joshua Rozenberg enthusing in the paper's media section about how much happier he is in papers than he was at the BBC. And his new chums are clearly just as thrilled as he is: warmly welcoming him by twice misspelling his name.

 Here's an idea for a Big Brother sequel - get a group of columnists with sizeable egos and intriguing romantic back- stories, send them away together, and watch them turn into Nick, Mel and Craig. There's already been a pilot: Deborah Orr (Indy) and husband Will Self (Sindy) holidayed recently with India Knight (Sunday Times) and partner Andrew O'Hagan (Telegraph), and things went so badly the two couples parted halfway through. No doubt we'll soon learn why from India's column. And Deborah's. And Will's "interview" and "TV review" soliloquies.

 It's not hard to see why Panorama's acting editors Clive Edwards and Karen O'Connor are keen to please their masters - both are up for the editor's post, vacant since Horrocks was kicked upstairs earlier this year. BBC bosses are keen to attract an outsider, but This Week and Here and Now veteran Paul Woolwich has turned them down. "They couldn't afford me now," he says.

 By far the most interesting name in the Panorama frame is the Nine O'Clock News special correspondent Gavin Hewitt. It would be a bold move to appoint such an experienced reporter to edit the ailing show - which almost certainly means it won't happen. "That would mean promoting someone who knows what they're doing, and we couldn't have that," says a jaded insider.

 News that the champagne corks were popping at Granada towers on the departure of drama chiefs Simon Lewis and Sue Hogg infuriated the pair. Lewis stormed into the office of programme director Grant Mansfield, brandishing a copy of last week's Media Guardian, demanding to know the source of the treachery. A weary Mansfield sighed that he really didn't have the time to point out just how many people in the building were pleased to see the back of them.

 Award for shameless hypocrisy of the week goes to the Daily Mail, which straplined its write-up of a Diana aide's kiss-and tell with the heading: "Royals dismayed by cynical attempt to cash in on Princess." That would be an entirely different kind of cynicism to that splashed all over pages 1, 2, and 3, with a spread on Prince William's 16th birthday on pages 24 and 25.

 BBC chairman Christopher Bland is limbering up for the battle to launch a handful of new channels. Not only has he joined a gym near Broadcasting House, he is now reduced to shunning liquid lunches in the boardroom in favour of vegetarian smoothies from the local deli.

webTitle: 'I wish she had been better loved'

fields.headline: 'I wish she had been better loved'
fields.standfirst:
Muriel Gray recalls the energy and wit of her role mode
MediaGuardian.co.uk
fields.trailText: The first time I met Paula Yates I knew it was my duty to turn up my nose.
fields.body:
The first time I met Paula Yates I knew it was my duty to turn up my nose.

It wasn't cool in the early eighties, the era of Julie Burchill and Tony Parsons, pouting ridiculously in leather jackets, to wear frilly cut-off ball gowns, kitten heels, or admit to fancying pop stars.

She was the impossibly glamorous star presenter of Channel 4's music show The Tube and I was among a crowd of urchins, employed unnecessarily, to give the thing a dubious street credibility.

It took about a day to fall for her, worshipping her silently and somewhat guiltily, like a new school pupil adoring the gorgeous head girl. Because, contrary to the years of vindictive, cowardly bile that has poured from the British press, attacking her as though she were a Nazi war criminal instead of a TV presenter, Paula Yates was an extraordinary woman.

But then Paula committed the media's greatest sin so early in her career it was almost impossible to recover.

At a time when television's version of womanhood was either brainy and plain, or pretty and dumb, she broke the mould, by being precisely what she wanted to be.

Frighteningly clever, outstandingly witty, intuitive and original, she was a free thinker, and her shoes matched her handbag.

webTitle: Media: Petrol crisis

fields.headline: Tankloads of viewers
fields.standfirst: The petrol crisis was a godsend for news broadcasters. The rolling news channels got some of their best ever audience figures and ratings for BBC1 and ITV bulletins soared. But there could be a backlash, warns  Claire Cozens.
fields.trailText: The petrol crisis was a godsend for news broadcasters. The rolling news channels got some of their best ever audience figures and ratings for BBC1 and ITV bulletins soared. But there could be a backlash, warns Claire Cozens
fields.body:
The fuel crisis may have cost Britain's businesses millions of pounds and brought the country to a virtual standstill, but the broadcasters are rubbing their hands together with glee after a week of record ratings. The British public's love of a crisis sent viewing figures for the rolling news channels rocketing to levels not seen since the Kosovo war, while BBC and ITV's news broadcasts notched up ratings at least 50% up on their usual figures.

It was just the sort of story the British love and, at a time when news audience figures are under siege, this has been the week to prove the cynics wrong. As one senior ITV network source said, "It proves that the British do want to watch news broadcasts, but only when there's real news. Basically people are very happy to watch the news when it affects their pocket, their family or our boys abroad."

The rolling news channels all notched up some of their best-ever ratings last week, with Sky News proving the star performer. The channel saw its daily share of viewing in multi-channel homes reach 2.98% on Wednesday at the peak of the crisis, 300% up on the channel's usual viewing figures and its highest audience share since the Kosovo war. Sky News reached a peak share of 6.54% between 3pm and 4pm on Wednesday, although by Thursday it was back down to 2.6%. Sky Digital viewers have also been able to access a dedicated fuel crisis channel on Sky News Active, the broadcaster's digital interactive news service.

Its nearest rival was BBC News 24, which attracted a record number of viewers. An all-time high of 400,000 people tuned in on Tuesday and Wednesday afternoons just before the Six O'Clock News. This was 54% up on the previous high of 260,000, which followed the Concorde crash, and also occurred just before 6pm. The average rating for the channel is around 20,000 viewers.

ITN's new rolling news channel fared less well, garnering just 0.19% of all multi-channel homes on Tuesday and 0.32% on Wednesday, at the height of the crisis. However, ITN disputes these figures on the grounds that they do not include viewership in cable homes, an important platform for the broadcaster. Barb confirms the error.

"You can argue about who did better, but the one demonstrable fact is that rolling news channels are driven by good news stories," says Roger Mosey, head of television news at the BBC. "If you compare it with newspaper circulations, which go up only fractionally at times like this whereas we've put on 50% or more, you see how much of a difference it makes."

According to Nick Pollard, head of Sky News, the fuel crisis was the biggest domestic story so far this year and possibly the biggest since the Omagh bombing. "In many ways, this has been the perfect story for rolling news," he says. "We've not only covered the story; we've developed ways of giving lots of micro-information as well. People are interested in the developing story, but they also want to know what the implications are for them. We started a crisis information update on Tuesday, and BBC and ITV followed 24 hours later, which was quite satisfying. On Tuesday, we introduced the rolling tickertape, which is the perfect vehicle for detailed information which you can keep repeating."

The rolling news channels' ratings were impressive overall, but in times of crisis people turn to what they know - BBC and ITV. Steve Anderson, head of news and current affairs at ITV, says, "When a story breaks that touches the lives of everyone, affecting schools, hospitals and emergency services, people will tune in. Information is at a premium and a lot of people want it. The broadcasters have responded very well. It shows that when there's a big story, people want to come to ITV and BBC1 for their news."

BBC1's Nine O'Clock News attracted roughly 8m viewers on Tuesday, Wednesday and Thursday, around a third of the total TV market and well up on usual viewing figures. By Tuesday, BBC1 and ITV, having witnessed the success of the likes of Sky News, were interrupting the schedules to bring special news reports on the crisis.

On Wednesday, ITV broke into the schedules to continue its lunchtime news all afternoon until the children's programmes began. Its ratings figures went up 50% to around 2m viewers, beating BBC1's lunchtime news.

Then on Thursday, BBC1 followed suit, taking an hour-long feed of News 24 from midday - only the second time it has done so - and averaged 1.8m (34% share) in the first half-hour, beating the end of ITV's This Morning. So whereas ITV Lunchtime News had beaten BBC1 on Wednesday, by Thursday things were reversed.

The hunger for the latest petrol news helped Tonight With Trevor McDonald to begin its autumn run on Wednesday with an impressive ratings win over Big Brother, after ITV decided to devote the entire show to the crisis. The programme attracted 6.7m viewers, giving it a 37% share, while 4.6m (21%) tuned in to Big Brother on Channel 4.

The petrol crisis schadenfreude continued on the BBC, where the Nine O'Clock News attracted 8.5m viewers, an even better performance than on Tuesday night. And BBC1 held on to its late-evening lead by broadcasting a special "Britain Running Dry" report at 9.30pm in place of the scheduled 999. Nearly 8m people stayed tuned in to the channel for more on the fuel crisis.

But for the BBC, this week's triumphs could turn out to be a mixed blessing. When the broadcaster moves its mid-evening news from 9pm to 10pm it will be hard-pressed to achieve viewing figures of anything like the 8m it achieved last week. And when it comes to comparing year-on-year figures, there could be some red faces at the corporation, which has insisted it will maintain viewer levels.

"These figures for the Nine O'Clock News may well come back to haunt them," says ITV's Anderson. "The BBC has been getting ratings around the 8m mark and it will be impossible for them to match that at 10pm. There are simply more people watching television at 9pm than at 10pm. They will be enjoying this week, but it may well prove an embarrassment to them this time next year."

webTitle: Union questions police role in fuel protests

fields.headline: Union questions police role in fuel protests
fields.trailText: The main transport union today called for a full public inquiry into the fuel blockades to examine the roles of police and oil companies in the crisis.
fields.body:
The main transport union today called for a full public inquiry into the fuel blockades to examine the roles of police and oil companies in the crisis.

The Transport and General Workers' Union, which represents tanker drivers, is drawing up a dossier that it will send to the prime minister raising a number of complaints about the level of security at refineries at the height of the demonstrations last week.

It also condemns police for "failing" to ensure safety on the roads surrounding the protests.

General secretary Bill Morris said that an inquiry would be better than any "knee-jerk" response by ministers to implement new laws that could stop workers taking legitimate industrial action.

The union said that its own investigations into the blockades had raised a number of questions, including:

 Why were protesters able to park their vehicles in the private car park of a refinery overnight, later joining the blockade?

 Why were there no security checks at some oil refineries and depots?

 Why were members of the public given access to top security areas?

 Why were drivers not given police escorts when many said that they would continue working normally if safety was guaranteed?

 Why did police take no action against protesters shouting threats to drivers?

Mr Morris said: "This preliminary report raises a number of unanswered questions. The role of the police, the oil companies and the protesters all need to be investigated if we are to avoid blockades of this sort in the future.

"My members are keen to know why the police failed to use their considerable public order powers to restore safety to the roads."

The union said that it wanted to know why oil companies failed to take out injunctions over the blockades and why police failed to challenge "mass invasions" of motorcyclists and taxi drivers.

"There should be a public inquiry into these events rather than a knee-jerk response," he said.

"The government should investigate why the existing legislation was not effective before they rush to implement new laws that would impinge on the rights of union members to take legitimate lawful action."

Mr Morris stopped short of accusing police and oil companies of colluding with the protesters, although many union officials privately believe that this happened. The TGWU said that its drivers were questioning the "inaction" of oil companies to stop the protests last week.

According to the union, the oil terminal at Fawley near Southampton was allowing protesters to park vehicles, including tractors, overnight last week.

Members of the public were seen having a picnic at a depot at Immingham near Grimsby before joining another demonstration.

The union's national officer for the fuel industry, Danny Bryan, said that property that had previously been out of bounds to members of the public was opened up to protesters, placing tanker drivers in jeopardy.
