The 25 companies formed after privatisation have competed strongly and pay levels have doubled from an average basic wage of £15,000 a year to around £30,000. Several companies have faced driver problems after making too many of them redundant at a time of rapid expansion. Connex, one of the worst performing companies on the rail network, is bidding to have its franchise to run commuter services from Surrey and Sussex into London renewed. The SSRA is due to announce its decision this autumn. The rail companies are not the only ones facing a driver shortage. Too few bus drivers in London has lead to the recruitment of French drivers.

webTitle: David cut from Da Vinci stone

fields.headline: David cut from Da Vinci stone
fields.trailText: Michelangelo's David, the jewel of Renaissance sculpture, was carved from a block of marble botched by Leonardo da Vinci, according to uncovered documents.
fields.body:
Michelangelo's David, the jewel of Renaissance sculpture, was carved from a block of marble botched by Leonardo da Vinci, according to uncovered documents.

It is thought Da Vinci tried to carve a massive statue of Hercules but failed and abandoned the block, which was given to the younger artist.

Art historians have puzzled for centuries over who had been given first crack at the marble.

A book of his charcoal sketches suggests he was originally commissioned to fill the space in front of Florence's Accademia gallery, said Carlo Pedretti, director of the Armand Hammer centre at the University of California.

After a century in the hands of a French collector, the book was reportedly bought by a Swiss collector for £1.3m at a recent Sotheby's auction.

Florence's cathedral works committee is believed to have commissioned the Hercules around 1498 but for unknown reasons Da Vinci never completed it, probably because of a mistake.

The 5m 17cm David, so alert it seems almost alive, has been hailed as a masterpiece and marvelled at by millions since Michelangelo finished it in 1504.

webTitle: Darwin setback for Ballydoyle

fields.headline: Darwin setback for Ballydoyle
fields.standfirst: Favourite goes lame but O'Brien still saddles first two at Curragh
fields.trailText: The highly regarded Darwin, one of Aidan O'Brien's chief hopes for Classic honours next year, was found to be lame after finishing only sixth in yesterday's Group One National Stakes at the Curragh.
fields.body:
The highly regarded Darwin, one of Aidan O'Brien's chief hopes for Classic honours next year, was found to be lame after finishing only sixth in yesterday's Group One National Stakes at the Curragh.

Darwin, the 4-9 favourite, was one of four runners in the nine-strong field from O'Brien's Ballydoyle yard, who still won the race with 10-1 shot Beckett.

The change in the going overnight to nearing soft put the emphasis on stamina rather than speed in the seven-furlong contest and it was King's County who kept on for second place, three lengths behind the winner to give O'Brien a one-two in the race.

Beckett earned a 20-1 quote from William Hill for the Sagitta 2,000 Guineas.

"Beckett has had a hard race but he is a handy horse that moves well and we should be able to get him ready early next spring," said O'Brien.

Meanwhile, Honours List, a two-length second to Tobougg in the Prix de la Salamandre at Longchamp on Saturday, could be set for a return trip to France.

O'Brien said: "He could go back to Longchamp for the Grand Criterium (October 8) as Michael Kinane said the horse spooked just after the furlong marker yesterday, losing his momentum at a crucial stage of the Salamandre."

Asked about Sagitta 2,000 Guineas favourite Hemingway, who was forced to miss the French Group One race because of a slight setback, O'Brien added: "He had five days off but comes to hand quickly and could still go for the Dewhurst Stakes."

Victorious trainer Mick Channon, who was forced to watch Tobougg's victory on a television monitor at Newbury after earlier arriving at Heathrow without his passport, said that he had felt for some time that the winner was the best horse he had ever trained. He may soon be forced to watch Tobougg from afar on a permanent basis, however, as the colt, now 14-1 with Hill's for the Guineas, will surely figure high on the Godolphin transfer list.

James Fanshawe will decide at the weekend whether to aim Saturday's Irish St Leger winner Arctic Owl at the Melbourne Cup.

His gelding looks potentially well treated with 8st 13lb to carry at Flemington on November 7 as he escapes a penalty for his length-and-a-half defeat of Yavana's Pace at the Curragh.

Newmarket basks in the title headquarters of British racing but is in severe danger of harming its reputation permanently if continuing to make the sort of elementary mistakes made at both its courses this year.

The £16m Millennium Grandstand opened on the Rowley Mile course in the spring was castigated by the course's annual members for clearly favouring corporate customers who were given the bulk of the prime viewing slots. Many ordinary racegoers, whose view of the racing was much more restricted, were also unimpressed.

Newmarket's prestigious midsummer meeting on the July course also came under fire when the results of races were clearly affected by a significant track bias.

On Saturday, the inauguration of a new meeting back on the Rowley course with two races confined to pure Arab horses as the centrepiece was a predictable flop with the attendance described as "disappointing".

Newmarket did show some foresight and innovation in appointing 28-year-old Lisa Rowe as its new managing director. She takes over in October but clearly has work to do if she is to steer Newmarket back on course.

Horses drawn high in sprints have a major advantage when the ground rides soft at Kempton and the in-from Budelli (3.40), perfectly placed in stall 24, looks well worth a proper bet today.

webTitle: Prescott goes fishing for undercover information

fields.headline: Prescott goes fishing for undercover information
fields.trailText: John Prescott has stumbled on a novel way of keeping tabs on what Tony Blair is up to - Billy the Big Mouth Bass, the electronic fish he gave the prime minister as a gift to cheer him up.
fields.body:
John Prescott has stumbled on a novel way of keeping tabs on what Tony Blair is up to - Billy the Big Mouth Bass, the electronic fish he gave the prime minister as a gift to cheer him up.

Billy, a lifesize model with a huge mouth and musical abilities, was the deputy prime minister's way of showing solidarity with the boss when Mr Blair was going through a rough patch after his ill-judged speech to the Women's Institute and the spate of leaked memos stolen from an adviser's dustbin.

When someone presses a button, Billy sings "Don't worry, be happy", turning his head and opening his mouth to the music.

It is one of several tricks which has made him a popular toy.

An import fromthe United States, the toy was bought by Mr Prescott from a London store and presented to the prime minister.

Anxious to show his appreciation to a sensitive colleague, Mr Blair put the fish in a conspicuous place - on top of the television set in his spacious office at No 10.

But Billy turned out to be so compelling a spectacle to visitors that he has become a major source of information to Mr Prescott about who is getting in to bend the prime ministerial ear.

"He is a grotesque, mounted plastic fish like you see on a hotel wall. Some people think he looks a bit like John Prescott himself," explained a senior MP who has seen the toy.

"When I saw John later I told him. He replied 'I bought it as a bit of a laugh. But it is the only bloody way I can keep up with who he is seeing. They all come out and say 'I saw your bloody fish, John'," the MP reports.

Mr Prescott's spokesman yesterday confirmed details of the gift.

However, he denied that espionage was the motive for placing Billy in the heart of the Blair camp.

Mr Blair's spokesman, Alastair Campbell, would only say: "Billy makes everyone who sees him laugh."

webTitle: MG Rover tells BMW it wants more

fields.headline: MG Rover tells BMW it wants more
fields.standfirst: Special report: Rover in crisis
fields.trailText: MG Rover, the car manufacturer, last night said it was seeking more cash to boost profitability and separately was hoping to squeeze more money out of its former German owner, BMW.
fields.body:
MG Rover, the car manufacturer, last night said it was seeking more cash to boost profitability and separately was hoping to squeeze more money out of its former German owner, BMW.

The British company, which lost £720m last year and saw its market share shrink, explained that it would be asking external financiers to help with dealer retail finance and finished vehicle inventories.

MG Rover said these new arrangements were in line with what other manufacturers were doing and should not be interpreted as the company being short of cash or struggling.

"We are cash rich with this debt-free business and will sell 200,000 cars this year which is very much in line with all our our targets," said spokesman Gordon Poynter.

He denied reports that MG Rover was seeking an extra £150m from BMW to secure the long-term future of the group as a mass-market carmaker. But he admitted there was a discussion with BMW over the value of the assets it had bought and that this could involve more money being handed over.

The German company sold Rover in May for a symbolic £10 and gave the purchaser, Phoenix consortium, an undisclosed dowry estimated to be worth between £450m and £575m. This was in part to cover 1,000 redundancies and the cost of relocating the Rover 75 from Cowley, where BMW will produce the new Mini, to Longbridge.

Now there is speculation that issues such as government actions to reduce the price of cars in Britain has affected the value of thousands of unsold cars in MG Rover's possession.

The German carmaker confirmed that it might have to make an additional payment to its former subsidiary if it was decided that the British carmaker's assets were worth less than originally thought.

BMW spokesman Richard Gaul said his company was having a detailed valuation of Rover carried out by accountancy firm KPMG.

The due-diligence review was likely to last until late autumn but the company had already made provisions for the eventuality of an additional payment to Phoenix.

"I don't think we'll have differences at the end," Mr Gaul said pointing out the two sides had agreed to call in a neutral arbiter should they fail to come to an agreement.

The MG Rover spokesman said adjustments might be needed to May valuations but added: "It could go either way. It is a matter of commercial confidentiality."

MG Rover says it is well advanced in its plans to start producing a Rover 75 estate car and three new MG models.

Meanwhile Ford is reported to be ready to inject £150m in a radical overhaul of Land Rover which would see production increased by 60% to 275,000 vehicles a year.

The money would be used to modernise its Solihull base and to create a new Range Rover model costing upwards of £80,000. A V6 version of the Freelander will be sold in the US and Japan.

webTitle: Race discrimination victim wins £25,000 over council equality job

fields.headline: Race discrimination victim wins £25,000 over council equality job
fields.trailText: A Pakistani man who was passed over for a job in favour of an Indian man has been awarded almost £25,000 in compensation for racial discrimination.
fields.body:
A Pakistani man who was passed over for a job in favour of an Indian man has been awarded almost £25,000 in compensation for racial discrimination.

Mohammed Sharief, 43, had been chosen as the best candidate for an adviser's post within Derby city council's equality unit.

But just as he was about to be offered the job the council's then deputy leader, Mark Young, stepped in.

An employment tribunal panel said Mr Young had been "enraged" by the initial choice of candidate.

He was angry at not being consulted on the first interviews and felt the process was flawed.

The panel said he was intent on satisfying the city's ethnic minority mix in the unit, which already had a Pakistani on its staff.

Mr Sharief said his failure to get the job had affected his career and his standing in the community.

"When it became public, it became very hard for me to function in Derby."

He added: "People were always asking me why I didn't get the job.

"I only found out after I served some legal papers on the tribunal that I had been about to be offered it.

"As I understand it now, the assistant chief executive was on the verge of ringing me up when Mr Young stopped her.

"It was clearly political interference on his part. He had not made any promises that anybody was aware of, and for him to cite that was wrong."

Giving evidence to the tribunal, Mr Young insisted that he had only stepped in because of a promise he had made to Derby's ethnic communities.

He said he had assured local Pakistani, Indian and Afro-Caribbean leaders that independent observers would witness all interviews for key posts.

But he admitted he failed to inform council officers or members about this pledge.

He added: "With hindsight, there should have been more communication."

A spokesman for the council said that it believed that Mr Young had been "acting in good faith and had been attempting to broaden and strengthen the recruitment process".

The tribunal ruled that by scrapping its initial process the authority racially discrim inated against a trio of Pakistani candidates.

Mr Sharief, of Derby, was awarded £19,815 for loss of earnings and £5,000 for injury to his feelings.

The other unsuccessful candidates, Mohammed Ayub, of Derby, and Mahoof Rashid, of Rotherham, received compensation of £5,000 and £2,000 respectively.

Solicitor Kevin McFadden, who represented all three men, said: "Race discrimination is not always obvious, and takes many subtle forms.

"More than sending out a message to other local authorities, I hope that the council learns a salutary lesson from this case."

Mr Young stood down as deputy leader in May this year and now works for the Manufacturing, Science and Finance union.

webTitle: Spitfires roar Flypast to remember The Few, 60 years on

fields.headline: Spitfires roar Flypast to remember The Few, 60 years on
fields.trailText: Spitfires roared above London and at Biggin Hill again yesterday as the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Edinburgh led tributes to "The Few" in the Battle of Britain 60 years ago.
fields.body:
Spitfires roared above London and at Biggin Hill again yesterday as the Prince of Wales and the Duke of Edinburgh led tributes to "The Few" in the Battle of Britain 60 years ago.

A day of anniversary celebrations culminated with the lowering of the RAF ensign and playing of the last post at Biggin Hill, the Kent airfield at the heart of operations against the Luftwaffe in 1940.

A thanksgiving and re-dedication service in Westminster Abbey was followed by a flypast of Spitfires - the fighter which came to symbolise the conflict.

The chief of the air staff, Sir Peter Squire, said: "The Battle of Britain remains one of the greatest achievements of the RAF. The courage, dedication and self-sacrifice displayed by The Few in their victory over the Luftwaffe, together with the unfailing support provided by their ground personnel, continues to inspire the RAF today."

The Dean of Westminster, Wesley Carr, who led the service, said: "We affirm again our determination to put an end to all armed conflicts; we express our penitence for those occasions when they become necessary; and we acknowledge with sorrow the suffering and destruction they cause."

During the flypast at Biggin Hill spectators saw 16 Spitfire and four Hurricane fighters take off.

RAF personnel in Belfast exercised their freedom of the city, with a march for the first time in five years.

webTitle: Two 'Catholic' charities linked to Nazis, says report

fields.headline: Two 'Catholic' charities linked to Nazis, says report
fields.trailText: Two charities claiming to promote international Catholicism have close links with a neo-Nazi political group and an Italian fascist, according to a report published by the charity commission today.
fields.body:
Two charities claiming to promote international Catholicism have close links with a neo-Nazi political group and an Italian fascist, according to a report published by the charity commission today.

The damning report found that the sister charities, the St George Educational Trust (SGET), and the Trust of St Michael the Archangel (TSMA), have got a "close association" with International Third Position (ITP), a far-right group that opposes third-world immigration to Europe, Zionism, and homosexuality.

Both charities have had their assets frozen pending the conclusion of the investigation.

In breach of the Charities Act, neither charity has filed accounts for the year ending March 1999. They have been served with an order requiring them to file accounts by October 12 or face a contempt of court charge.

Roberto Fiore, a fascist politician and businessman, is a trustee of SGET. The charity commission found that his company, Meeting Point, had received payments from TSMA. The money was for rent owed on the charity's shop on Shirland Road in Maida Vale, west London.

In 1985, Mr Fiore was sentenced in Italy, in his absence, for being a member of the political wing of the Armed Revolutionary Nuclei, a fascist terror group. The group was implicated in the Bologna bombing of 1980, which killed 85 people.

The commission also found that at one stage ITP and SGET operated from the same premises while TSMA was funding renovation work in Los Pedriches, an abandoned Spanish village, which ITP was occupying with the aim of creating a white nationalist community and training centre for volunteer soldiers.

"While in each case the trustees say that these matters are entirely coincidental, the only reasonable conclusion is that a close association exists between the charities and the ITP," says the report.

The commission concluded that the charities' financial and management controls were "weak and needed considerable improvement", and that TSMA's involvement in Los Pedriches had given rise to legitimate public concern. The charity's trustees claim to have ended the link with the village.

Members of ITP began moving to Los Pedriches, 60 miles from Valencia, in 1996, 15 years after the inhabitants had moved out. Seven of the village's eight houses were purchased by foreigners. According to TSMA, accounts of about £7,000 for construction and renovation work came from the charity.

Mr Fiore, who fled to the UK in the early 1980s, is national secretary of Italian fascist party Forza Nuova, whose logo appears on the ITP website. Mr Fiore denied he had links with ITP but said he sympathised with its ideas. "I recognise that fascism is good on certain issues," he said. Asked whether he supported repatriation of black people, he said: "There is a fundamental lack of natural justice if people are brought to live in different countries to where they were born. Everyone should be staying in the place where they live; it is wrong to have Islamic immigration to Italy and thank God in Italy we recognise that."

Asked why he did not live in Italy, Mr Fiore said: "You know my history. I am here on the principle of asylum." As an EU national he does not need asylum to remain in the UK. Attempts to extradite him in the 1980s failed.

The charity commission began its investigation following newspaper reports establishing links between the charities and the far right. Interim findings are being published because of public concern.

Mr Fiore was suspended as a trustee of SGET in 1997 but following an investigation by the commission was cleared last year to resume his trusteeship.

Simon Gillespie, director of operations at the charity commission, said the links between the charities and ITP was unacceptable. "Important issues have been raised in this case. We expect all trustees to be open and honest with us and in their dealings with the public. If our investigations show that people have tried to mislead us, we would view it very seriously."

Under the Charities Act, misleading the charity commission can lead to two years' jail.

webTitle: How we braved some earlier barricades

fields.headline: How we braved some earlier barricades
fields.trailText: You modestly omit to mention that Guardian photographer Walter Doughty's poignant pictures (Easter rising reflected, September 16) are but one example of the paper's enterprising coverage of the events of 1916.
fields.body:
You modestly omit to mention that Guardian photographer Walter Doughty's poignant pictures (Easter rising reflected, September 16) are but one example of the paper's enterprising coverage of the events of 1916.

The official press party sailed for Dublin in the destroyer HMS Dove two days after the rebellion's outbreak (on April 24) and got little further than a hotel on the North Wall where they were daily briefed by British Army spin doctors. However, the Guardian's CP Scott had already dispatched two reporters (a third would follow later) by conventional routes. Admittedly the first hardly covered himself with distinction. JF Radcliffe arrived well ahead of the pack at Kingstown (Dun Laoghaire) where he decided, "The deserted streets are so full of insidious perils that to venture near them is to invite a bullet."

Radcliffe's inactivity was more than redeemed by second string George Leach. Unloaded by a tremulous taxi driver at Drumcondra, he marched through barricades and rifle fire to the centre of Dublin where he was the first reporter to make contact with the insurgents. His post-rebellion report, Five Days Inside The Cauldron, was an undoubted scoop. Meanwhile, an official correspondent on the North Wall beefed, "As evidence of the food shortage, it is only necessary to state we were served roast beef and potatoes for luncheon and dinner, and this for four days running!"

Allen Synge
London

 I was fascinated by the photographs taken by Walter Doughty. However, far from reflecting the Easter rising the photographs actually refer to civil war action in Dublin, probably during 1922 or 1923. The uniformed figures in two of the photographs are actually Irish Free State troops. To have been on site during the brief few days of the Easter rising would have been fortunate indeed. Still, the pictures remain great documentary evidence.

Tadgh O'Sullivan
 Mallow, Co Cork
tadghosullivan@hotmail.com

webTitle: Tories, teachers and trust

fields.headline: Tories, teachers and trust
fields.trailText: I might have been deeply moved by Councillor Bruce-Lockhart's endorsement of William Hague's attack on bureaucracy in education (Letters, September 14), since I agree that we have too much of it. But then I remembered that it was the Conservative government's profound mistrust of teachers which started this disastrous command style and the deluge of government missives.
fields.body:
I might have been deeply moved by Councillor Bruce-Lockhart's endorsement of William Hague's attack on bureaucracy in education (Letters, September 14), since I agree that we have too much of it. But then I remembered that it was the Conservative government's profound mistrust of teachers which started this disastrous command style and the deluge of government missives.

Hundreds of orders were issued to schools by the previous government, laying down every tiny detail of the curriculum, the exact form of tests, how a school report should be compiled, even how to mark the register.

Hague's demand for less bureaucracy is just the latest example of the arsonists calling the fire brigade and then wanting a medal for their public spirit.

Prof Ted Wragg
University of Exeter
E.C.Wragg@exeter.ac.uk

 Councillor Bruce-Lockhart underlines the intellectual confusion which lies at the heart of Conservative education policy.

He would like to see schools given greater freedom to run their own affairs and involvement of government and local authorities reduced, yet he has been vehement in his support of section 28 (Kent County Council has been at the forefront of the campaign for its retention). He clearly does not trust teachers to provide an adequate moral and ethical framework for our children and feels that additional legislation is necessary to control them, yet he sees no contradiction in calling for the shackles of government to be removed.

Once again the failure of the Tories to reconcile their paternalist instincts with their anti-statist beliefs is exposed.

Dr Howard Stoate MP

webTitle: After the crisis - 2 Time to come clean on the dome

fields.headline: After the crisis - 2 Time to come clean on the dome
fields.trailText: Contemplating the fall from grace documented in the polls, Mr Blair and his colleagues should brood with particular care on one finding. Almost three quarters of the electorate agrees with the proposition that the government is arrogant and out of touch. That does not relate to the petrol crisis alone: as interviews with the protesters showed time and again, it also reflects resentment on other issues, and particularly the Millennium Dome.
fields.body:
Contemplating the fall from grace documented in the polls, Mr Blair and his colleagues should brood with particular care on one finding. Almost three quarters of the electorate agrees with the proposition that the government is arrogant and out of touch. That does not relate to the petrol crisis alone: as interviews with the protesters showed time and again, it also reflects resentment on other issues, and particularly the Millennium Dome. The latest spate of reports of incompetent management, unpaid bills (including large sums left unpaid by its sponsors), murky accounting and now, lack of parliamentary sanction for spending, can only serve to solidify the sense of grievance apparent last week. Huge sums have been wasted - not, strictly speaking, of public money, maybe, since it came from the lottery, but money only spent because Tony Blair and some of colleagues perpetuated a project which others in government urged them to abandon. And money spent, too, as many in outlying regions complain, for the glorification of London, with no obvious benefit elsewhere in the country. The arrogant, and ultimately silly (because so plainly dishonest), pretence lately cooked up by the dome's defenders that this whole great enterprise was really designed to rehabilitate blighted north Greenwich can only have compounded resentment.

When a reputation for sleaze engulfed the Conservative party, John Major, defying warnings from political colleagues and Conservative newspapers, set up an independent commission under Lord Nolan to dig out the facts and recommend redress. If Mr Blair and friends are to shed their reputation for arrogance, they ought now to promise a comparable inquiry into the dome, as a recognition of the blunders that have been made, and a demonstration that those culpable will be brought to account - even if their numbers include some of the prime minister's closest friends.

webTitle: The nature of genius

fields.headline: The nature of genius
fields.trailText: Paul Clarke (Letters September 16) misses an important point. It's not difficulty that marks out the genius of Wagner, or any great artist, but profundity.
fields.body:
Paul Clarke (Letters September 16) misses an important point. It's not difficulty that marks out the genius of Wagner, or any great artist, but profundity.

A profound work contains subtleties such that repeated acquaintanceship with the work continually brings new insights into its nature. These subtleties are sufficiently objective for one person to point them out to another. Works of "popular" culture do not generally manifest any such depth of content. What you see at first glance is all there is. Where the confusion arises between "high" and "low" culture is that it is possible to approach both in the same shallow way and derive pleasure from doing so.

If one wants background music then Bach and Bacharach both supply something tuneful. But if one is looking for a deeper artistic experience, only the former will measure up.

Roger Musson
 Edinburgh
Roger@abaxial.demon.co.uk

 Paul Clarke advances all sorts of arguments for equating the Beatles with Beethoven, except the one which really matters - the nature of the response provoked by their works. Great art stimulates us to see the world in a new way, on an endlessly varying basis. Everything else remains essentially the same, no matter how often the experience is repeated. To equate these two types of expression devalues and denigrates artistic creativity.

Alan Waters
Lancaster
A.Waters@lancaster.ac.uk

webTitle: After the crisis - 1 Could this be Mr Kennedy's opportunity?

fields.headline: After the crisis - 1 Could this be Mr Kennedy's opportunity?
fields.trailText: The Liberal Democrats open the party conference season in Bournemouth this week in circumstances which by all the old rules are extraordinary. Britain may be getting back to normal, but Tony Blair, once the great political miracle worker, is not. Two polls yesterday show his party pitched in a week from a lead matching May 1997 to equivalence with the Conservatives, or worse.
fields.body:
The Liberal Democrats open the party conference season in Bournemouth this week in circumstances which by all the old rules are extraordinary. Britain may be getting back to normal, but Tony Blair, once the great political miracle worker, is not. Two polls yesterday show his party pitched in a week from a lead matching May 1997 to equivalence with the Conservatives, or worse. Chillingly, the Conservatives are better trusted at this moment to run the national economy than his super-successful chancellor. The most popular government on record is reduced to parity with one of the most despised of oppositions. There may have been an irreversible change in the public mood - or it may have been more a kind of grand national tantrum. No precedents exist for such a sudden reversal of fortunes, and the explanations need to be sought as much from psychologists as from psephologists.

But with both big parties unloved, there ought to be fresh hope for the Liberal Democrats. Their 21% rating on NOP underlines the potential. Bournemouth gives them the chance to build on it. But to do that Mr Kennedy needs to make sense of the turbulence in the country last week more effectively than he has done so far. He claims advantages here. As the leader of a party with green credentials, but the product of a crofting background and a part of rural Britain where life cannot proceed without the car and the lorry, he sees himself as the right man to strike the balance.

He has no way of ducking the fact that his party has committed itself to some raising of taxes, which on last week's evidence is hardly the mood of the nation. He has no way of ditching the green commitment. So he needs to use Bournemouth to show how his party would reconcile those positions with the kind of popular pressure which burst through last week: a tough assignment when, as the polls confirm, the petrol protest had 78% of the nation, which must have included many potential Lib Dem voters, behind it.

There is another challenge for him in last week's events. In a Guardian interview last week Mr Kennedy held out the prospect of the Liberal Democrats latching on to the anti-politics mood now evident in the country. In yesterday's Observer he wrote about the need for people to "rediscover their scepticism about government." That sounds strange at a moment when we have just been witnessing a spectacular demonstration that scepticism about government in Britain was never higher. The new protest politics which enthralled the nation last week repudiates settled notions of government. When protesters complain that Tony Blair isn't listening, what they really mean is that he won't do as he's told. So the leaders of last week's protest issue an ultimatum: do as we say or we'll hit you again. There was some of that in Paulsgrove: more may follow, all over the place. The Countryside Alliance, desperate to save hunting, is reported to be exploring new forms of civil disobedience in the light of the huge success of the petrol blockades. The old acceptance that governments are put there to make hard choices seems to be dying. Governments are on probation: if they offend, retribution is to be exacted at once - not later on, through the ballot box.

Mr Kennedy's party has always prided itself in excelling the rest in its commitment to parliamentary democracy: that is one reason why it has campaigned so long for an electoral system which would make parliament more genuinely representative. His taste for anti-politics must not be allowed to eradicate that.

webTitle: ...and lessons of a crisis

fields.headline: ...and lessons of a crisis
fields.trailText: I watched every BBC News broadcast on the fuel crisis last week. Every day the pickets said that they represent the whole country. Oddly enough, there appear to be more non-white Home Office ministers than pickets. What can this possibly mean?
fields.body:
I watched every BBC News broadcast on the fuel crisis last week. Every day the pickets said that they represent the whole country. Oddly enough, there appear to be more non-white Home Office ministers than pickets. What can this possibly mean?

Graham Gilchrist
Leeds

 In a survey carried out in my local boozer at 10pm last night, 100 customers were asked the question: "Should the government scrap the duty on beer". Ninety-eight slurred an emphatic "yes". The two "don't knows" were a couple of eight-year-olds drinking pop in the snug.

Bill James
Halesowen, West Midlands

 I wonder how many motorists queuing for fuel in the pouring rain over the last couple of days have realised the connection?

Tony Meacock
 Norwich

 Perhaps the oil bosses should persuade their drivers to hold out until the government is forced to cut income tax as well as fuel tax. They could then reward them with a nice little pay rise with the tax saved on their salaries and share options. Surely this is the type of common interest, third way relationship between workers and corporations that New Labour has been encouraging for so long.

David Coltman
Mannheim, Germany

 My father telephoned me yesterday complaining that he'd driven round all day trying to fill his tank. I didn't even know he drove a tank.

Andrew Blanchard
Prague, Czech Republic
ablanchard@lycos.com

 If I discover that Brian Aldridge was involved in the fuel blockade, I'll never listen to The Archers again!

GJ Price
Wolverhampton

 As all these protesters are self-employed, fuel tax is pretty well the only tax they pay. If the average person was aware of the minuscule level of income tax that small businessmen pay, they would have no support at all.

Quentin Sadler
Worcester Park, Surrey
quentin.sadler@tesco.net

 Apart from regenerating the Greenwich peninsula, the Millennium Dome provided 30,000 jobs and a fine day out for millions. However it cost the nation £1bn so everybody thought it was a scandal. The hauliers' blockade caused disruption to essential services and massive inconvenience to tens of millions. It too cost the nation £1bn, but everybody thought it was marvellous.

Brian Hanson
Horsham, West Sussex

 It is time for senior citizens to get together and begin buying up lorries and trucks - the larger the better.

Patrick Dodd
London
cft-pdodd@supanet.com

webTitle: The politics of protest...

fields.headline: The politics of protest...
fields.trailText: Polly Toynbee (OK, keep on trucking, September 14) asks why the Green party wasn't on the streets protesting against the lorry drivers seeking cheap fuel. Some of us were doing what we were elected for: pressing the European parliament to take on board climate change.
fields.body:
Polly Toynbee (OK, keep on trucking, September 14) asks why the Green party wasn't on the streets protesting against the lorry drivers seeking cheap fuel. Some of us were doing what we were elected for: pressing the European parliament to take on board climate change.

In the same summer that scientists found water at the North Pole where for 50m years there's been ice, I was steering a report through the European parliament arguing for the introduction of environmental charges and taxes on the aviation industry to encourage airlines to reduce the CO2 emissions. The report was agreed by the parliament by an overwhelming majority on the day the fuel protests started. Why wasn't the Guardian telling its readers about this sensible step forward?

The Greens are pressing the government not to back down in the face of the misguided fuel protests. The royal commission on environmental pollution is proposing that the UK reduces its greenhouse gas emissions by 60%. Now is the time for the government to take the lead in showing how neither air passengers nor road hauliers and private motorists pay their way since the tax take from transport does not cover all the resulting costs of roads, accidents, damage to buildings, chronic respiratory illnesses and climate change causing flooding and changes to agriculture.
Caroline Lucas MEP
Green party

 Liberal Democrats believe that the government must be more open about the money it receives from fuel and how it is spent. Taxes on fuel should not be a back-door way of raising revenue - they should be used to reform the tax system to protect the environment. Because revenues raised have not been returned to the travelling public, we have voted against increases in fuel duty by both Labour and the last Conservative government. We also believe that oil companies should not be allowed to exploit those reliant on personal transport in rural areas.

We call on the government to: place a cap on fuel taxes (in real terms) for five years so that the government does not profit from future increases in fuel prices; use the VAT windfall that it has received from the higher than expected fuel prices to ease the burden on the travelling public (it should not be used to boost the chancellor's pre-election war chest); ensure that oil companies recognise their social responsibilities, both in respect of pricing and security of supply (if they fail to do so, we will take measures to tax their excess profits); and support people in rural communities who rely on fuel through rate relief on rural fuel stations and increased investment in community public transport.
Matthew Taylor MP
Don Foster MP
Dr Vince Cable MP
Charles Kennedy MP

 I agree with William Hague, that we must have fair taxation of fuel if UK road hauliers are to compete with their European counterparts. The commonsense way to do this would be through a unified taxation policy throughout the EU devised to take account of environmental issues. The problem is that Hague doesn't support the EU and he has abandoned the former Conservative government's environmental policy!
David Woods
Lichfield, Staffordshire

 I'd like to propose a personal vote of thanks to those who blockaded the refineries last week. Prior to the last election I was ambivalent about New Labour. The events of last week removed this doubt, as I can now see clearly what the alternative is.
DJ Browning
Altrincham, Cheshire

 Given the choice of government between the oil companies and even the Raving Loony party, I've no doubt collusion with the "Loonies" would be the safer bet.
Robin Townsend
Canterbury, Kent

webTitle: Prescott blocks release of road finance details

fields.headline: Prescott blocks release of road finance details
fields.standfirst:
Secrecy thwarts freedom of information minister
Special report: transport in Britain
Special report: freedom of information
fields.trailText: John Prescott has barred Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister in charge of freedom of information, from access to the financial details of a deal to build Britain's first private toll motorway.
fields.body:
John Prescott has barred Mike O'Brien, the Home Office minister in charge of freedom of information, from access to the financial details of a deal to build Britain's first private toll motorway.

Mr O'Brien is still at loggerheads with Mr Prescott over the £750m Birmingham northern relief road, following the deputy prime minister's u-turn on Labour's election pledge to cancel the scheme.

The road runs through Mr O'Brien's North Warwick constituency, and he was one of four Labour MPs who backed protesters taking the government to court to reveal details about the deal. The protesters won a ruling giving Mr Prescott discretion to release commercial figures related to the controversial scheme.

However, Mr Prescott has refused to release any financial information, to protect the consortium planning the development. He cited "commercial secrecy" - one of the main planks for withholding documents under the freedom of information bill promoted by Mr O'Brien - as the reason for not handing it over.

"No doubt Mr Prescott has had to act on the best legal advice of his civil servants," Mr O'Brien said.

The MP and the protesters wanted details of the tolls for drivers, and of the huge compensation bill Mr Prescott would face if the government ever cancelled the scheme.

After Tony Wright, Labour MP for Cannock Chase, tabled a parliamentary question, protesters also found that almost £20m was to be spent on widening the M42 connecting road to help traffic use the private motorway. At that time MPs had been told that construction of the private road would cost taxpayers nothing, and details of the widening scheme had been withheld from the public inquiry into the scheme.

The deal had been signed by the Tories under Lord Parkinson when he was transport secretary, and included confidentiality clauses.

Before Labour was elected, Frank Dobson, then environment spokesman, pledged that Labour would not build the road. Mr O'Brien was also quoted in a Labour press release as saying: "The road is environmentally damaging and unnecessary. It will not cure congestion on the M6."

Labour is also committed to all private road deals agreed by the government being open to public scrutiny - but the deal was signed by the Conservatives in 1994, and, says the party, the rule cannot be retrospective.

Yesterday, Mr O'Brien said he still opposed the building of the road even though it was government policy. "Mr Prescott has got his views on the road, I have got mine and I have not changed mine. I still oppose the road." He blamed the Tories for signing the confidential deal.

This has not impressed protesters. Gerald Kells, of Friends of the Earth, said: "Mr Prescott has used as little open government as he can get away with and left the public completely in the dark."

Mr Prescott's official statement says: "The secretary of state has decided to withhold all those parts of the agreement which fall within the discretionary exemption on commercial confidentiality. In his view to disclose these provisions would harm Midland Expressway Ltd's (the consortium of banks and builders) commercial interests, and would not substantively add to anyone's understanding of the possible environmental impacts of the proposed road."

webTitle: Growers fight plant centre closure

fields.headline: Growers fight plant centre closure
fields.standfirst: Special report: GM debate
fields.trailText: A leading research centre is facing closure in a move which has revived fears about scientific promotion of GM crops and a brain drain from laboratories in the north.
fields.body:
A leading research centre is facing closure in a move which has revived fears about scientific promotion of GM crops and a brain drain from laboratories in the north.

Commercial growers and MPs are pressing the government to save the 175-acre specialist unit at Stockbridge House at Cawood, near Selby, North Yorkshire, which has pioneered biological pest control, hydroponics (growing plants without soil) and other alternatives to genetic adaption of plants.

Fifty jobs would go in March under a planned restructuring of Horticultural Research International, the government's main testing and development arm for market gardening, fruit and related crops.

The Cawood unit, which has recently added to its three acres of glasshouses, is the only northern laboratory run by HRI, which is planning to concentrate on its scientific centres at West Malling, Kent, and Wellesbourne, Warwickshire.

The axe was announced by HRI chief executive Professor Michael Wilson, a proponent of genetic research, to Stockbridge staff, some of whom were in tears at the prospect of losing tied housing on the site. Six scientists at the centre have been offered relocation to the midlands and south.

Commercial growers, who pay half the costs of the centre, have also warned that their money may not be transferable to different research, and are backing a rescue attempt linked to the government's huge central science laboratories only 20 miles away in York.

"This would be a match made in heaven," said John Grogan, Labour MP for Selby and one of the backers of an emergency campaign to keep Stockbridge intact. "There's an obvious synergy and we're putting a robust place and business plan together."

Senior advisers to Nick Brown, the agriculture minister, are to hold talks with the group, which is supported by the National Farmers' Union and headed by a former director of Stockbridge, Michael Bradley.

He said yesterday: "It's a viable site, it's got a good team and a good budget. There's an awful lot of horticultural science about at the moment, but much less work on the practical technology which makes that science useful to growers. That's the speciality of Stockbridge and we believe it can survive and prosper."

Prof Wilson said that the HRI had to remain "the major UK player, fighting fit, competitive and the source of the highest quality research and development".

Recent years had seen a slower growth than forecast in commercial operations to make up for a steady cut in the public sector grant to the non-departmental public body, which is responsible to the agriculture ministry but dependent on private sector income as well.

Scientists in the north are still sore about the government's decision earlier this year to build a £500m synchotron at Didcot in Oxfordshire rather than Daresby in Cheshire - a site with a greater expertise in generating high energy X-ray beams to penetrate the structure of proteins, potentially invaluable in the development of medical drugs.

webTitle: Budget road to the isles

fields.headline: Budget road to the isles
fields.trailText: Your two tourists who spent £3,179 on a holiday in Skye and Harris shouldn't deter anyone else (Travel, September 16).
fields.body:
Your two tourists who spent £3,179 on a holiday in Skye and Harris shouldn't deter anyone else (Travel, September 16). From my credit card and cash details I can reconstruct the cost of this summer's holiday in the Highlands and Skye: it was £851 for the two of us. Admittedly we have a head start living in Scotland, but even adding their car hire and sleeper to our budget only brings it to £1,319. I can recommend a good B & B in Skye for £17 per head, while in the Fort William area some are only charging £13.

Margaret Squires
St Andrews, Fife
quartobooks@tesco.net

 So, the state censors of the British Board of Film Classification regard the cast of the hit British film Saving Grace as "innocuous, middle-aged and decayed" (More sex, please, we're British filmgoers, September 15). This particular member of the cast regards Mr Robin Duval, Mr Andreas Whittam Smith and their cronies as redundant, senile, decrepit apparatchiks - so there.

Clive Merrison (aged 55 and dangerous)
London

 To offset the bad news, I can report a wonderful extension of consumer choice. My local wholefood shop now sells condoms for vegans - because "ordinary condoms contain milk proteins". The condoms are made in Germany, which accounts for the cry of "Vorsprung durch technik" which now rings from many a local bedroom.

Edgar Newton
York

 At last we've found a safe and convenient new enemy to replace the Soviet threat (Rock shock, September 16). Spending billions on preparing to deal with asteroids which might hit the Earth is an admirable way of soaking up loose cash which would otherwise fuel inflation.

Terry Morgan
Leeds

webTitle: Doctors demand pay rise of 14%

fields.headline: Doctors demand pay rise of 14%
fields.standfirst:
Increase needed to motivate profession, says BMA
Special report: the future of the NHS
fields.trailText: Doctors last night put in a demand for a 14% pay rise to "motivate" the profession during the upheaval of the government's NHS reform.
fields.body:
Doctors last night put in a demand for a 14% pay rise to "motivate" the profession during the upheaval of the government's NHS reform.

The British Medical Association told the government that its ambitious targets for recruiting more consultants and GPs would not be met without substantial pay rises.

Alan Milburn, health secretary, has not yet given any indication to the doctors and dentists review body about the extra resources for salaries built into his national plan.

But he is understood to be anxious to break away from national percentage increases to set aside part of each annual settlement to reward high performers and top up salaries in regions with particular recruitment problems.

The BMA said in its evidence to the review body that ambitious targets for increasing numbers of doctors would not be met unless pay was put on a par with that of other professionals. GPs earn an average of £54,220 a year and consultants start at £48,905, rising to £84,005.

The BMA said that at least 6% more was needed from next April to maintain the profession's earnings, with a further 8% to make up for the slippage in salaries since 1995.

As part of the NHS plan in July, the government promised an extra 7,500 consultants and 2,000 GPs by 2005. Ministers expect to recruit doctors from abroad in the short term before increased training places come on stream. There are also proposals to stop newly qualified NHS consultants doing private work for the first years after qualifying.

The BMA said: "The intention in the NHS plan for consultants to become increasingly involved in mentoring, training and leadership, together with the administrative burdens imposed on all doctors by revalidation and clinical governance, can only result in a more intense clinical workload if demand is to continue to be met.

"Measurable output per doctor has been maintained in the face of unquantified workload, only at the expense of more intensive workload, and this should continue to be recognised in pay levels."

Ian Bogle, the association's chairman, said: "This year's review comes after the NHS plan in England, in which the government acknowledged that the need for new doctors was so great it would try to recruit more doctors from abroad. Pay is not the whole story, but it is an important factor in helping to motivate people."

A Department of Health spokesman said: "We will be submitting our evidence to the review body shortly. What the government wants to see is a reformed pay system for the health service which rewards doctors and nurses who make the biggest contribution to the NHS. It should also deal with differences around the country in successfully recruiting and retaining staff."

In addition to London weighting, this might include other regional variations, taking account of differences in living costs, he said.

webTitle: Jailed tycoon back in business

fields.headline: Jailed tycoon back in business
fields.trailText: Alan Bond, who served three years in jail for his part in Australia's biggest corporate fraud, is poised to make his return to the business world.
fields.body:
Alan Bond, who served three years in jail for his part in Australia's biggest corporate fraud, is poised to make his return to the business world.

Bond, who once owned Castlemaine XXXX beer and a stake in TV-am, is understood to be working as a consultant for Money Centre, a financial services company offering high interest, short-term loans.

The move comes within six months of his release. He had admitted dishonesty in relation to an A$1bn loan to Bond Corporation from Bell Resources, a company he bought from fellow entrepreneur, Robert Holmes à Court. Bond was one of the highest-profile businessmen of the 1980s and at one stage Bond Corporation had assets worth £5bn. Bond's love of art proved his undoing. In 1996 he was jailed for corporate fraud in relation to the addition of Manet's La Promenade to his multi-million dollar collection.

webTitle: BT and AT&T mull £138bn asset shuffle

fields.headline: BT and AT&T mull £138bn asset shuffle
fields.trailText: British Telecom and its American counterpart AT&T, are contemplating a radical transatlantic plan to break up the two telecommunication groups and reconstitute themselves as two focused global businesses, covering mobile telecoms and international business services.
fields.body:
British Telecom and its American counterpart AT&T, are contemplating a radical transatlantic plan to break up the two telecommunication groups and reconstitute themselves as two focused global businesses, covering mobile telecoms and international business services.

At the same time, two "rump" businesses, covering traditional domestic fixed line telecoms, including the domestic phone network, would be created in Britain and the US. Such a move amounts to one of the most ambitious pieces of corporate alchemy ever seen. AT&T is valued at about $120bn (£86bn). Its mobile business alone is reckoned to be worth $70bn. Despite BT's sliding share price, the company is worth £52bn.

But sources warned that the plan was still in "skeletal" form and was just one of a wide range of options being examined as BT and AT&T try to reposition themselves.

AT&T chairman Michael Armstrong and his counterparts at BT, chairman Sir Iain Vallance and chief executive Sir Peter Bonfield, have developed deep business ties and the two groups have transatlantic alliances covering mobile and international business service units, respectively named Advance and Concert. The idea of solidifying these two existing alliances into separate entities, each of which could be floated in its own right, has been toyed with for months. Both managements are under intense pressure from Wall Street and the City to unlock shareholder value and at the same time shed their reputations as introverted former monopolies.

John Malone, an AT&T board member and largest individual shareholder through his vehicle Liberty Media, has long been agitating for a split-up of the US company. He argues for splitting off the wireless group entirely - making it easier for Wall Street to value the rest of the company's assets, while underscoring their trading discounts.

But the practical obstacles to what would amount to a simultaneous merger and multiple demerger of BT and AT&T are daunting. Potential trip-wires would include the allocation of senior management posts among the two in ternational and two domestic businesses formed, decisions on domicile - whether British or American - and also the attitude of regulators in Washington, Brussels and London.

Analysts point out that a deal would take many months, or even years, to implement, and would result in upheaval for 250,000 global staff.

There is this idea that the company is just sitting on its hands, one banker close to BT noted but, like AT&T, whose stock price has halved this year, BT executives, having watched the company under-perform by a similar margin, feel increasing frustration at the market's refusal to acknowledge the amount of restructuring already under way.

The idea of solidifying these two existing alliances into separate entities, each of which could be floated in its own right, has been toyed with for months. Both managements are under intense pressure from Wall Street and the City to unlock shareholder value and at the same time shed their reputations as introverted former monopolies. John Malone, an AT&T board member and largest individual shareholder through his vehicle Liberty Media, has long been agitating for a split-up of the US company. He argues for splitting off the wireless group entirely - making it easier for Wall Street to value the rest of the company's assets, while underscoring their trading discounts. But the practical obstacles to what would amount to a simultaneous merger and multiple demerger of BT and AT&T are daunting. Potential trip-wires would include the allocation of senior management posts among the two in ternational and two domestic businesses formed, decisions on domicile - whether British or American - and also the attitude of regulators in Washington, Brussels and London. Analysts point out that a deal would take many months, or even years, to implement, and would result in upheaval for 250,000 global staff. There is this idea that the company is just sitting on its hands, one banker close to BT noted but, like AT&T, whose stock price has halved this year, BT executives, having watched the company under-perform by a similar margin, feel increasing frustration at the market's refusal to acknowledge the amount of restructuring already under way.

webTitle: Water regulator dilutes opposition to mergers

fields.headline: Water regulator dilutes opposition to mergers
fields.trailText: Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator, is preparing to relax the strict opposition to mergers adopted by his predecessor, Sir Ian Byatt.
fields.body:
Philip Fletcher, the new water industry regulator, is preparing to relax the strict opposition to mergers adopted by his predecessor, Sir Ian Byatt.

Mr Fletcher, who took over as director general of Ofwat six weeks ago, said: "If someone comes to me with a consolidation proposal, I would be prepared to consider it."

He said much would depend upon how competition within the industry developed. "There could be benefits flowing through in a way which Sir Ian could not see and I cannot see at the moment. There is a tiny crack in the door."

Sir Ian opposed mergers between water companies as they reduced scope for comparing performance of individual companies, a fundamental part of his regulatory process. The price cuts he demanded for approving mergers removed the attraction of such deals.

Mr Fletcher said his guess was that restructuring would result in more change in the water industry over the next few years than common carriage, inset agreements or direct price competition.

He agreed with Sir Ian on the need for a cautious approach to some of the proposals for changing the ownership of water company assets.

Earlier this year Sir Ian pulled the plug on Kelda's plan to sell its Yorkshire Water assets to a mutual business operating on behalf of customers. Western Power Distribution was also forced to modify its plans for hiving off Welsh Water's assets into a non-profit making company.

Mr Fletcher said several companies were considering new models for ownership of the assets of their regulated businesses. Most of them involved a switch from equity to largely debt-finance.

He said: "I hope that as WPD's takeover of Hyder [Welsh Water's parent company] goes through, we may see useful proposals which take the debate further and ensure protection of public health and benefits for customers."

Mr Fletcher said companies contracting out the running of their regulated businesses would have to ensure open competition for the contract.

Such contracts would have to run for a sufficiently long period but must not be allowed to become "a cosy relationship which will go on for ever".

He said there would be a case for extending the licencing regime to contractors if outsourcing of regulated operations became common.

webTitle: Monday briefing

fields.headline: Monday briefing
fields.trailText: Kingfisheris to put its stake in LibertySurf, the French internet service provider, up for sale in a move that could net it £600m.
fields.body:
Sunday Times

Kingfisher is to put its stake in LibertySurf , the French internet service provider, up for sale in a move that could net it £600m.

Kingfisher owns about 35% of LibertySurf with a similar stake owned by Europweb , the investment vehicle of Bernard Arnault, the French fashion magnate. Deutsche Bank is advising LibertySurf on its options and the company has been linked to Vivendi , the French communications group.

G7 finance ministers will warn Opec about the dangers of high oil prices. The newspaper quoted Treasury sources as saying the warning would be issued when G7 leaders met in Prague next weekend. The chancellor, Gordon Brown, will push his fellow G7 finance ministers to send a tough message to oil producing nations at the meeting, the report said. The warning might include a threat by the US to release some of its strategic petroleum reserve on to the market to drive down prices.

Sunday Telegraph

Altodigital , the provider of internet services for small and medium-sized companies, has appointed WestLB Panmure to lead a stockmarket flotation of the company worth £400m.

Altodigital, which includes GWR , the independent radio group, among its investors, expects to float on the London stockmarket in the first quarter of 2001.

Trinity Mirror has hired Joe Sinyor, the head of Sony UK and former boss of the Dillons bookstore chain to run its main newspaper business, according to Telegraph.

Mail on Sunday

The departure of London Stock Exchange chief executive Gavin Casey has cleared the way for deals with US stock market Nasdaq and European bourses. Mr Casey was blocking the creation of a viable pan-European stock market, according to sources close to the affair.

Observer

Littlewoods , the catalogue and stores chain, has been hit by a severe sales slump which threatens a stock market flotation expected by the controlling Moores family. The problems, plus rock bottom staff morale, may fuel a rebellion against the board.

Tony Blair's vision of turning the UK into the best country in the world for e-commerce has suffered a serious setback after a huge falling out between telecom firms and industry watchdog Oftel .

Sunday Business

Smiths Industries has been approached by TI Group as a possible buyer of its Dowty aerospace division for around £600m. The paper says there are no ongoing discussions but Smiths may table an offer at short notice. American aerospace combine BF Goodrich is said also to be in the running.

The Sultan of Brunei has sacked Citibank as one of his government's fund managers in the aftermath of the Asian crisis and the sultan's dispute with his spendthrift brother, Prince Jefri. Citibank ran a $4bn invesment fund on behalf of the Brunei government.

US healthcare products cpmpany Baxter International is in talks about taking a stake in Britain's Peptide Therapeutics despite Peptide already talking about joining up with another firm. Baxter is seeking to buy a 20-25 % stake in Peptide.

IoS

Larry Ellison, founder of US software producer Oracle , is giving up his salary. But the 56-year-old need not despair. Worth an estimated $47bn he will instead receive 20m share options.

webTitle: Body Shop boss plans to quit

fields.headline: Body Shop boss plans to quit
fields.standfirst: Roddick turns to campaigning
fields.trailText: Anita Roddick, founder of the Body Shop, yesterday said she planned to step down from the high-street chain.
fields.body:
Anita Roddick, founder of the Body Shop, yesterday said she planned to step down from the high-street chain.

The launch of her book, Business As Unusual, today marked the end of an era, she said. She needed "breathing space" and "the political freedom to do other things after 25 years in commerce".

"I'm not sure how much longer I'm going to hang around... I don't want to keep on emoting about the shape of a bottle or whether or not we should go for elderberry body butter," she said in a Sunday newspaper interview.

Her ambitions , she added, were to "smash the World Trade Organisation, blow up the armaments industry, do some real populist campaigning that moves politicians to concentrate on something other than their own careers".

She said she would stay on at Body Shop as co-chairman with her husband Gordon "for at least two years". The two of them started the Body Shop business, with a first store in Brighton. The have since built up a global chain of 1,754 shops which now has a market value of £220m.

The company was floated on the London stock market in 1984. Profit became the driving force: "Everything became about how much we were worth," she said sadly.

Her position has been the subject of City speculation since Patrick Gournay, former boss at Danone of France, became chief executive in May 1998. The following year profits had slumped to £3.4m but in March the company reported a bounceback with a pre-tax profit of £28.8m

A Body Shop spokesman said last night there was no question of Ms Roddick quitting immediately. "She is still very much a part of the business, but is increasingly doing things of her own."

webTitle: Poor old George

fields.headline: Poor old George
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Gore is ahead for the first time, even allowing for the three-to-four-point margin of error. The radiance shed by the stars - and Gore's wife Tipper - must have something to do with how the public sees Al Gore these days. I can't prove that statistically, but it can't do any harm that Indiana Jones implies you're a good guy to go tiger shooting with and Julia Roberts finds your bashfulness sexy.
fields.body:
It is time to feel sorry for GW Bush. He has tons of charm, but he is up against Harrison Ford, Julia Roberts, Michael Douglas, Matt Damon, Jimmy Buffett, Paul Simon and Bette Midler - and Jesus Christ superstar as played by the Democrats' vice-presidential candidate Joe Lieberman, the senator with a halo. GW has only Charlton Heston, in the very old chariot provided by the National Rifle Association. GW's running mate is the tubby, follically challenged Dick Cheney who is out in the sticks giving a very good impersonation of Beelzebub, all pitchfork and no polish.

Gore is ahead for the first time, even allowing for the three-to-four-point margin of error. The radiance shed by the stars - and Gore's wife Tipper - must have something to do with how the public sees Al Gore these days. I can't prove that statistically, but it can't do any harm that Indiana Jones implies you're a good guy to go tiger shooting with and Julia Roberts finds your bashfulness sexy.

Gore himself hasn't changed much. He has come out of country brown suits with an open collar and into city suits, white shirt with tie, but he is still the solid, decent, worthy candidate who was behind Bush in the August popularity stakes. Clear majorities of Americans saw Bush as being more likable, more honest and ethical, more likely to say what he believed rather than what people wanted to hear. Bush was even slightly ahead as "caring for people like you". Now Gore has reversed the ratings, a trend that began with the post-convention bounce but has continued. Although the Republicans have spent a fortune on television commercials painting the vice-president as a dissembler, who will say anything for a vote, Gore is ahead by five points in the honesty rankings.

Feel sorry also for GW because, while lending their charisma, Hollywood has enabled the Gore campaign to coin millions. The single star-studded event at the Radio City Hall in New York the other night, organised by Miramax's Harvey Weinstein, Jann Wenner of Rolling Stone and impresario John Sykes, yielded an extraordinary $6m for the Democrats. It is enough to make a good Republican puke when at the same time Al and "Holy Joe" have been denouncing Hollywood and the music industry for producing too much sex and violence. They have even advertised their approval for a measure of government control which has produced the topsy-turvy situation of the Republicans reaching for their First-Amendment pistols.

And feel sorry for GW because his own party has done its bit to undo his lead. The vocabulary of American political discourse is coarser than the British. It did not really do GW and Cheney much harm when a microphone picked up their description of a New York Times reporter as "a major league asshole". But there was instant recoil from the Republican television commercial where they flashed the word RATS in big luminescent capitals at the end of an attack on Gore's penchant for bureaucRATS.

It was not so much the epithet that reverberated. If the Republicans had smiled when they said it, they might have got away with this, but they pretended that those seeing the word RATS must have been mistaken: I saw it and jumped in synchrony with millions of less-than-fully-alert viewers from Gotham to Sunset Boulevard. The Republicans were treating the public as simpletons just as they did when they repudiated the time-honoured formula for three national debates (all channels) and proposed one debate and two chat shows, which would have meant their man being exposed to millions fewer. The attempt then to portray Al Gore, who rejected the subterfuge, as the one who was funking national debates was farcical. It didn't play in Peoria or anywhere else, so the Republicans have retreated. There will be the usual three debates. How could they have so underrated the intelligence of the voters? Are they so devilishly cunning that the fumbling is all part of a plot to lower expectations for GW's performance so that he will look better on the night?

There has been tumult inside the Republican hierarchy over all this, a split between the boys in Austin, Texas, who have been managing things, sort of, and leaders of the Republican national committee in Washington who fear that GW is having done to him what his dad did to Michael Dukakis in 1988: Dukakis, too, was the front-runner until midsummer, then lost his momentum.

Now GW has called in Ed Gillespie as an emergency adviser to redirect his "message campaign" and the early word is that he will no longer count on charisma, but attack on the issues. Gore is the supreme policy wonk whose idea of a good time is going to bed with a dossier from the Office of Management and Budget. The order to seize his guns is reminiscent of the order to the Light Brigade at Balaclava. It is magnificent, but is it war?

webTitle: Lord Harmar-Nicholls

fields.headline: Lord Harmar-Nicholls
fields.standfirst: Self-made Tory peer more adept at business than politics
fields.trailText: Cheery, flamboyant Lord Harmar-Nicholls, the former Conservative MP for Peterborough (1950-74) and MEP for Greater Manchester South (1979-84), who has died aged 87, had a Davey lamp on his coat of arms to show his pride in his father's origins as a miner. Harmar was a pushy, self-made west midlander with a special talent for upsetting Old Etonian Tories with condescending advice.
fields.body:
Cheery, flamboyant Lord Harmar-Nicholls, the former Conservative MP for Peterborough (1950-74) and MEP for Greater Manchester South (1979-84), who has died aged 87, had a Davey lamp on his coat of arms to show his pride in his father's origins as a miner. Harmar was a pushy, self-made west midlander with a special talent for upsetting Old Etonian Tories with condescending advice.

Too often, he reminded Harold Macmillan of his 1950 rebel motion advocating the building of 300,000 houses, a feat on which Macmillan had built his early reputation. Once prime minister, Supermac repaid Harmar by refusing to promote him beyond the rank of parliamentary secretary, making him resign from government in 1960.

But, while he was not as clever as he believed, there was no malice in Harmar - Labour's MP-novelist Maurice Edelman tagged him an "inoffensive Tory prole". Nicholls asserted, "I like to live dangerously," an apt description of his fingertip hold on Peterborough during eight close elections. When he turned up in the Commons after 1966's record-breaking tight vote - which he won by three after seven recounts - friend and foe held up three fingers in welcome.

Born in Darlaston, Staffordshire, Nicholls was educated at the local council school, and Queen Mary's grammar school, Walsall. In 1930, he became an active young conservative, and the next year was founder-chairman of Darlaston unemployed workers council. By 1936, he was vice-chairman of the West Midlands Junior Imperialist League, having won several debating prizes, and, in 1938, joined Darlaston district council.

He had also made his first job move after serving behind the counter of his father's wallpaper shop, by becoming articled as a surveyor. By 1939, he had his own firm of surveyors, and another of estate agents.

Nicholls volunteered for the Royal Engineers, and was flown back from Burma to contest the 1945 election, against Sydney Silverman in Nelson and Colne. Defeated there, he contested the 1946 Preston byelection, but it was only in 1950 that he narrowly captured Peterborough by 144 votes. Unashamedly rightwing, he backed capital punishment and privatising mines. He soon established a reputation as an eager beaver, urging government- backed low deposits to encourage home ownership.

As parliamentary secretary for agriculture from 1955, he made a poor start, and was moved sideways by Macmillan to the Ministry of Works in 1957. There he did sensible things, like transferring departments south of the Thames. But he did not make himself popular by gratuitous advice. When Peter Thorneycroft, Nigel Birch and Enoch Powell resigned after failing to get £50m of public spending cut, he said, "They all ought to have their heads knocked together."

After his 1960 resignation, Nicholls paid more attention to his business interests, expanding into casinos, theatres, Radio Luxembourg and insurance. Above all, he was an early agitator for commercial television as chairman of the National Broadcasting Development Committee. Once he wandered into dodgy territory, becoming a director of conman Bernie Cornfeld's £2,500m IOS (Investors Overseas Services), a crooked offshore mutual fund, which collapsed in 1970. He lost credibility, and his Commons seat, in October 1974 after advocating a coalition government, and was given a life peerage.

His temporary political comeback as an MEP in 1979 did not suit his Eurosceptic soul; he was a pro-Commonwealth man who believed British people should continue to populate the white Commonwealth. He was not re-selected.

In the Lords, he continued to play the role of a partisan cheeky-chappy, leading Labour's po-faced Europhile Lord (Michael) Stewart to complain that his interventions prevented Labour peers from making coherent contributions. But Harmar-Nicholls could be serious, as when he helped defeat Mrs Thatcher over football identity cards. Or when he tried, in 1994, to improve licensing requirements for agencies recruiting entertainers for overseas, sometimes a cover for international pimping.

fields.bodyText: Cheery, flamboyant Lord Harmar-Nicholls, the former Conservative MP for Peterborough (1950-74) and MEP for Greater Manchester South (1979-84), who has died aged 87, had a Davey lamp on his coat of arms to show his pride in his father's origins as a miner. Harmar was a pushy, self-made west midlander with a special talent for upsetting Old Etonian Tories with condescending advice. Too often, he reminded Harold Macmillan of his 1950 rebel motion advocating the building of 300,000 houses, a feat on which Macmillan had built his early reputation. Once prime minister, Supermac repaid Harmar by refusing to promote him beyond the rank of parliamentary secretary, making him resign from government in 1960. But, while he was not as clever as he believed, there was no malice in Harmar - Labour's MP-novelist Maurice Edelman tagged him an "inoffensive Tory prole". Nicholls asserted, "I like to live dangerously," an apt description of his fingertip hold on Peterborough during eight close elections. When he turned up in the Commons after 1966's record-breaking tight vote - which he won by three after seven recounts - friend and foe held up three fingers in welcome. Born in Darlaston, Staffordshire, Nicholls was educated at the local council school, and Queen Mary's grammar school, Walsall. In 1930, he became an active young conservative, and the next year was founder-chairman of Darlaston unemployed workers council. By 1936, he was vice-chairman of the West Midlands Junior Imperialist League, having won several debating prizes, and, in 1938, joined Darlaston district council. He had also made his first job move after serving behind the counter of his father's wallpaper shop, by becoming articled as a surveyor. By 1939, he had his own firm of surveyors, and another of estate agents. Defeated there, he contested the 1946 Preston byelection, but it was only in 1950 that he narrowly captured Peterborough by 144 votes.
