webTitle: Fred Carneson

fields.headline: Fred Carneson
fields.standfirst: The great escaper of South Africa's freedom struggle
fields.trailText: Fred Carneson, who has died of a brain tumour in Cape Town aged 80, was one of the great escapers in South African political life. He was finally jailed by the apartheid regime in 1966, but it took the security police 10 days and nights of sleep deprivation to break him.
fields.body:
Fred Carneson, who has died of a brain tumour in Cape Town aged 80, was one of the great escapers in South African political life. He was finally jailed by the apartheid regime in 1966, but it took the security police 10 days and nights of sleep deprivation to break him.

As the son of a railwayman, Carneson's white, Catholic working-class background made him unusual in the anti-apartheid struggle. His first job was in the post office in Pietermaritzburg. But he was intelligent, and he questioned the treatment of the city's Indians. He found a book of the great philosophers in his local library and was converted to communism, joining the party at 16.

During the second world war, with the South African army surrounded at Tobruk, he ignored the order to surrender and escaped across the desert in a van, complaining that you could not fight fascists from a prison camp. He settled in Cape Town after the war, became a member of the Communist party's central committee and was elected by African voters as a "native" representative on the Cape provincial council.

The Communist party was outlawed in South Africa in 1950, but Carneson and others continued their political work, though forbidden to do so by banning orders. In 1956, he was one of 156 activists of all races tried for treason. His acquittal, after three years, was another escape. Soon afterwards, his wife, Sarah, was detained, and he went into hiding.

When the African National Congress and the Communist party turned to sabotage, Carneson was heavily involved in the Cape Town cell. At first, he escaped arrest, but well after Nelson Mandela and the Rivonia defendants had been jailed for life, the police caught up with him

He was methodically tortured. When his daughter, Lynn, tracked down the prison doctor, he told her: "Mr Carneson is in good condition, considering ..." Carneson was a gregarious, sometimes boisterous, man, who loved a good party, and the experience affected him deeply. He told his fellow prisoner, Denis Goldberg - whom he had recruited into the sabotage cell - that, at the end, he was unable to control his body. It was not said as an excuse, but as an explanation.

Carneson gave the police some names, but refused to repeat them at his trial. Here again, he was lucky to be acquitted of sabotage; had he been found guilty, the bombmaking equipment that had been found would have meant death or, at best, life imprisonment. As it was, he was sentenced to five years nine months on a lesser charge.

His luck began to run out. Sarah, her life severely circumscribed by the anti- apartheid laws, left to join her children in London. Their second daughter, Ruth, suffered a series of breakdowns.

Released in 1973, Carneson also came to England. His membership of the Chartered Institute of Secretaries helped him land a job with the National Union of Teachers, and he later worked for the mental health charity Mind, all the while playing a forceful part in exile politics.

When the thaw came, the Carnesons returned home, where Fred was again elected for the now-unbanned Communist party to the provincial council from which he had been expelled 40 years earlier. It was a life of some sadness, but, in the end, he witnessed black liberation, even if it was not to be within a communist society.

He is survived by Sarah and their children Lynn, Ruth and John.

webTitle: Charity cheques frozen as GayFest directors fall out

fields.headline: Charity cheques frozen as GayFest directors fall out
fields.trailText: An extraordinary spat has broken out between the organisers of one of Britain's biggest gay festivals.
fields.body:
An extraordinary spat has broken out between the organisers of one of Britain's biggest gay festivals.

Despite the success of Manchester's GayFest 2000 - after last year's Mardi Gras gay festival had left charities empty handed - the directors have fallen out. This year's festival attracted thousands of people over the August bank holiday and raised £105,000 for charity.

But at a committee meeting after the event, a motion of no confidence was passed in Brian Shaw, chairman of GayFest. Members were concerned that he had aligned himself with the city council amid accusations that the council had not supported the festival.

Mr Shaw has responded by freezing the GayFest bank accounts pending an annual general meeting.

But his fellow director Julia Grant, who was also the event organiser, said she would present the cheques to the charities on Thursday night at her bar in Manchester's gay village. "The charities are desperate for this money," she said. "If Brian Shaw tries to stop that, shame on him. As far as I am concerned, he has not frozen the bank accounts because he can't."

Mr Shaw said the cheques, to charities such as the Lesbian and George House Trust, an HIV/Aids charity, would bounce.

Ms Grant said the disagreements, which many observers see as little more than internal squabbles, began before the festival. She claimed that Manchester council had failed to support GayFest 2000.

The council had refused to give £3,000 towards the candelit vigil in Castlefield, and during the weekend it did not fly the rainbow flag over the town hall, as it had done for Mardi Gras in previous years. She said the gesture sent a bad message to the gay community.

When Ms Grant publicly criticised the council at the candlelit vigil and claimed that there were councillors who did not want the event to happen, Mr Shaw signed a statement with the deputy council leader, Martin Pagel, dismissing her comments.

Mr Shaw was unavailable for comment but in interview with the Manchester Evening News, he said: "I would have thought that Julia Grant would want to discuss this [that the cheques will bounce]. It's not fair on the charities."

A message from him posted on the GayFest website said: the bank accounts "are now frozen pending an annual general meeting. The chair and officers of Manchester Gayfest Ltd are still in place until such time as the difficulties within the organisation are resolved .

"The good causes fund will be distributed to the charities as soon as possible. The opponents of GayFest are the only winners of this situation. We intend to work positively to resolve this situation."

Councillor Pagel said that, far from being obstructive to GayFest, the council had been a firm supporter and had sponsored the candlelit vigil. He said the idea that Mr Shaw had gone native and aligned himself to the council was an insult to his integrity and independence.

webTitle: The strange case of the Lib Dems

fields.headline: The strange case of the Lib Dems
fields.standfirst:
Charles Kennedy said yesterday that he would rather work with Labour than with the Tories, but a left-leaning strategy is fraught with danger
Special report: Charles Kennedy
fields.trailText: Charles Kennedy is a social democrat who looks happiest among those of a mildly collectivist bent - Scots, public sector workers and the like. His party's mini-manifesto, put out in advance of this week's annual meeting by the seaside, outflanked the government to its left on taxes and spending, and he said yesterday that in the event of a hung parliament he would prefer to work with Labour.
fields.body:
Charles Kennedy is a social democrat who looks happiest among those of a mildly collectivist bent - Scots, public sector workers and the like. His party's mini-manifesto, put out in advance of this week's annual meeting by the seaside, outflanked the government to its left on taxes and spending, and he said yesterday that in the event of a hung parliament he would prefer to work with Labour.

That cohered with the leftwards bent of recent years. Lib Dems are in coalition with Labour in Scotland, members of Blair cabinet committees and tacit electoral cooperators. Merger won't happen, not least because Tony Blair reconstructed his party as a highly disciplined outfit. As John Bartle of Essex University wryly observes, Millbank "is hardly likely to cope well with the individualistic and quasi-anarchic Liberal Democrats". What is more likely is "Romsey plus", after the Hampshire byelection earlier this year in which the Lib Dems won a safe Tory seat. Labour and the Lib Dems will go on selecting candidates in every constituency, but where the Lib Dem is performing strongly against the Tory, Labour's campaign will be "nominal".

Why the charade is necessary is that Lib Dem voters are not at all on the left and the idea that they are voting, even indirectly, for Labour would put them off. The tactic undoubtedly worked in 1997, which may come to rank as the most successful tactical campaign any party has fought. In February 1974 - an election, incidentally, called to decide who ran the country - the Liberals (as they then were) won a fifth of all British votes cast. Jeremy Thorpe was invited to coalition talks with Ted Heath, but all those votes had secured him were 14 Commons seats. In 1997, despite getting 800,000 fewer votes than in 1992 and 16.8% of the total vote, Lib Dems more than doubled their tally of seats from 20 to 46. In 1992, in their "heartland" region of the south-west, they won six seats out of 48 with 31% of the vote. The same proportion in 1997 won 14 of the region's 51 seats.

That is a tribute to Lib Dem campaigning. But it does not rescue them from the perennial question facing the third nag in a three-horse race: who is your main rival? Mr Kennedy has pronounced the Tories the enemy, Labour mere competitors. That conforms with the chart. (It comes, with other data in this article, from an unpublished paper by Andrew Russell, Ed Fieldhouse and Iain MacAllister of Manchester University.) Labour is now the second preference of around 65% of prospective Lib Dem voters. It is a turnaround. During the 80s their alternative vote was definitely Tory. As things stand, even the weakest form of "electoral reform" (which is not strictly speaking proportional representation) is the alternative vote or AV. This scheme benefits Lib Dems and Labour alike since for both their supporters the Tories are third choice.

But Mr Kennedy cannot rely on his voters in anything like the same way as Tony Blair or William Hague. John Curtice of Strathclyde University once memorably called the Lib Dem vote fickle and incoherent. Lib Dem voters are not easy to distinguish beyond being Methodists - proportionately not many Catholics vote Lib Dem. Sociologists detect no consistent profile for Lib Dem voters: you cannot easily tell them apart by job, gender or age. They turn out to be remarkably similar to Tory voters in their middle-classness. In recent years then, the Lib Dems have pulled off a remarkable feat. The party has moved left but their voters still look like a natural constituency of the centre-right. This might, of course, be further evidence of the ineptitude of the Tory party in failing to keep to the middle ground. It is too early to tell what effect the fuel crisis may have on voting intention. A Gallup poll in the Daily Telegraph on Friday - some of its data collected before the fuel famine - showed a slight gain in Lib Dem support since early August. During the crisis, Mr Kennedy hardly covered himself in glory, studiously refusing to commit himself on the picketing. For the conference his resounding call is to make the Lib Dems the party of non-politics. But as a natural home for swingers, perhaps equivocation is good tactics.

In 1997, only 12% of voters labelled themselves as Lib Dems; such identification is consistently lower than the party's election showing. People switch to them, having fallen out of love with the others. Nearly two-thirds of the Lib Dem vote in 1997 came from "new" recruits.

Until now it has been plausible for Lib Dems to hope they might gain at the next election on the Romsey principle. If the Tories make themselves more extreme, the Lib Dems pick up defectors. A swing of 5% away from the Tories towards the Lib Dems would bring 12 extra seats. But what if Tory support firms up? The only gains the Lib Dems could then make would be at Labour's expense. Here the analogy is with Liverpool and Sheffield, where abstainers and switchers secured significant municipal victories for the Lib Dems at Labour's expense. The electoral significance of such a switch depends on constituency arithmetic.

The number of seats where Lib Dems ran closely second to Labour in 1997 were few. Charles Kennedy, like his predecessors, has to be Janus-faced with a vengeance, saying different things in Scotland, where his party shares power with Labour, and in the regions of England. Unfortunately, this week he is out in the open and the mystery that is the Lib Dem party runs the risk of being exposed.

webTitle: Northern League's new threat to Italian unity

fields.headline: Northern League's new threat to Italian unity
fields.trailText: The spectre of northern Italy breaking away from the south returned yesterday when the Lombardy region said it would hold a referendum on devolution which could lead to independence.
fields.body:
The spectre of northern Italy breaking away from the south returned yesterday when the Lombardy region said it would hold a referendum on devolution which could lead to independence.

In a move which stunned the government, the Northern League said it wanted to force the transfer of powers from the state to the wealthy region it controls.

The government called the plan dangerous, unconstitutional and liable to spin out of control.

The threat could also unravel the centre-right opposition, led by Silvio Berlusconi, which welcomed the Northern League into its coalition on the condition that it renounced separatism.

A poll in yesterday's La Repubblica showed a coalition led by Mr Berlusconi, a former prime minister, and including the Northern League would defeat the centre-left government in the national elections which are due in the spring.

Tentative government plans for fiscal devolution have come to nothing, allowing the League's leader, Umberto Bossi, to seize the initiative.

Politicians in the relatively impoverished southern regions have begun forming alliances as the prospect of isolation looms.

Lombardy, which will hold the referendum for control of the police, health, trade and education on the same day as the general election, is expected to be followed by Venetia and Piedmont, which have resented the south's drain on resources virtually since Italy was unified in 1861.

"There is unlikely to be blood on the streets - whatever the response, the vote can have no immediate legal effect," a political scientist at the American University of Rome, James Walston, said.

"But if the three biggest and richest regions of the north vote in favour of devolution, the political effect will be devastating.

"Bossi has tossed a verbal hand grenade into political discourse. This initiative could take on a momentum of its own."

Mr Bossi's inconsistency about the level of autonomy he wants has rattled Italy since his party emerged in the early 1990s.

Leaders of the government coalition condemned his ultimatum as an attack on the unity of the state.

"Regional referendums are objectionable from a legal point of view; they are outside the law," the prime minister, Giuliano Amato, said.

By challenging Rome's legitimacy the referendums could unleash a crisis in Italy's democratic institutions, he said.

But some in the government sensed a chance to attack the resurgent opposition, which seeks to contrast its discipline with the fractious centre-left.

"It is demagoguery which will boomerang on them," said Massimo Cacciari, who survived the left's hammering in Venezia in last April's regional election.

The opposition hoped it had tamed the League's mercurial leader, but yesterday he led supporters in a ritual of carrying water from the Po river to the Venetian lagoon, a tradition he invented three years ago to rally support for his notional independent state "Padania".

Mr Bossi insisted that he no longer wanted independence, but his coalition partners feared that he was already slipping the leash. His walkout caused the collapse of Mr Berlusconi's first government after seven months in 1994.

In a relationship patched up this year, Mr Berlusconi promised to dole out limited autonomy in return for the League's votes, which he is thought to need to return to power.

Yesterday his Forza Italia party said it backed the referendum call, but analysts said the opposition's unity was in danger of fracturing.

"Regional referendums are objectionable from a legal point of view; they are outside the law," the prime minister, Giuliano Amato, said. By challenging Rome's legitimacy the referendums could unleash a crisis in Italy's democratic institutions, he said. But some in the government sensed a chance to attack the resurgent opposition, which seeks to contrast its discipline with the fractious centre-left. "It is demagoguery which will boomerang on them," said Massimo Cacciari, who survived the left's hammering in Venezia in last April's regional election. The opposition hoped it had tamed the League's mercurial leader, but yesterday he led supporters in a ritual of carrying water from the Po river to the Venetian lagoon, a tradition he invented three years ago to rally support for his notional independent state "Padania". Mr Bossi insisted that he no longer wanted independence, but his coalition partners feared that he was already slipping the leash. His walkout caused the collapse of Mr Berlusconi's first government after seven months in 1994. In a relationship patched up this year, Mr Berlusconi promised to dole out limited autonomy in return for the League's votes, which he is thought to need to return to power. Yesterday his Forza Italia party said it backed the referendum call, but analysts said the opposition's unity was in danger of fracturing.

webTitle: Office hours

fields.headline: Sec's tips
fields.standfirst: 3: Meetings
fields.trailText: 3: Meetings
fields.body:
Ask how much time is spent in meetings each week and, for most people, the answer will be "too much". Meetings are a necessary evil, but they don't have to take over your working life. Follow a few simple rules and you'll find the meetings you chair are quicker, more effective, and, possibly, even enjoyable.

 A productive meeting begins long before anyone sits down at the boardroom table. Think carefully about what it is for and who should attend. If you don't invite the right people to get the decisions you need, you'll end up scheduling yet another meeting.

 Let everyone know in advance what the purpose of the meeting is and circulate an agenda so they can prepare. That way you avoid the "first-quarter drag" where people use your meeting time to get themselves in gear. Put a realistic time limit on the agenda, and print timings next to each element of the meeting. This is in the ever-optimistic hope that you can encourage colleagues to stick to their allocated 15-minute slots. It's also worth telling others what they need to bring along. There's nothing more frustrating than people constantly leaving the room to get relevant papers.

 Once in the meeting, be positive and enthusiastic - if you act like you'd rather be somewhere else, your colleagues will feel the same way. Watch the clock and keep referring people back to the timings on the agenda. Make it a point of pride that your meetings don't run over. You'll find that attendance will plummet if people suspect that a one-hour meeting for you really means three hours.

 Deal with bad behaviour quickly. Don't pander to latecomers - start bang on time. If people interrupt others constantly, ask them to wait until their colleague has finished speaking, and then ask them for their point.

 Stick to, and finish, the agenda. If discussions break out on other matters, schedule them for another time, and keep ploughing forward. It's great to have the odd interruption for a joke, but don't let constant sidetracking take hold - it becomes boring for everyone, and you never get the meeting finished. At the end, thank everyone for their time and be sure to circulate any minutes promptly to keep people feeling that they're part of a high profile, dynamic group.

 Believe it or not, a productive meeting can be extremely energising and motivating - and it does wonders for team spirit. Perfect the art and you'll have people asking you when your next meeting is.

 Penny Cottee is editor of Executive PA magazine

webTitle: Damn the definitions, says Lowry chief

fields.headline: Damn the definitions, says Lowry chief
fields.standfirst: Arts centre boss wades into high and low culture debate with plea for a 'hands off' approach
fields.trailText: State subsidies for arts centres can lead to the kind of controls reminiscent of Soviet culture ministries, the head of one of Britain's newest and most popular venues claimed yesterday.
fields.body:
State subsidies for arts centres can lead to the kind of controls reminiscent of Soviet culture ministries, the head of one of Britain's newest and most popular venues claimed yesterday.

Stephen Hetherington, chief executive of the Lowry, said he was happy to run his "village economy" on the banks of the Manchester ship canal in Salford without state support.

In the first major regional contribution to the high/low art debate, he told the Guardian that arts subsidies had contributed to the British obsession with cultural definitions.

He sided firmly with the populism of Lord Bragg, who last week denounced Sir John Drummond, John Tusa, and other defenders of high art as "senior citizens of our official culture".

The Lowry, the £105m national millennium landmark project for the arts, opened in April and buys in all shows for its two auditoriums, producing no work itself.

It was given a £44.6m capital grant from the Arts Council of England but receives no revenue funding from the council, although many of the companies that appear there do.

"I feel far freer than I would if I had a large subsidy cheque coming in every year," said Mr Hetherington. "That cheque comes with someone else's rulebook, philosophy and agenda. You cannot run your own business. You are definitely not your own master.

"That prevents you developing the kind of agenda we have here, one directed exactly at our location in this community."

He acknowledged the council's huge contribution to the Lowry project and its role in funding creative work by major companies such as the Royal Shakespeare Company and the Royal Opera House. But a revenue subsidy could lead to a much narrower definition of culture, particularly if a funding body decided one year to support everything from the Chippendales to the Paris Opera Ballet but narrowed its range of activities the next.

The Lowry, named after LS Lowry, an artist who won wide popular acclaim and affection, would never set out to "improve" its audience. "To be part of the fabric of our community here, it would be no use for us to sit on our high horse and say, 'We think this is very good for you.' We would then be making judgments for other people."

Mr Hetherington said he made no value judgments on the work he brought to Salford. "Compare a love-sick adolescent weeping to a chart-topping love song with someone having a great Wagnerian orgasm at Bayreuth.

"Who has the more profound experience? You cannot determine that because for the individuals concerned they are equally powerful things.

"If these experiences belong to the society around us and are important to it, we want to present them in our building."

The Lowry was not Harrods but John Lewis, where shoppers could rely on quality in everything - a fountain pen or an expensive sofa.

"The high culture debate is as profoundly useless as the discussion about what is or is not art. The contemporary fixation with cultural definitions has grown up alongside the subsidy system.

"Once you have a public body giving public money, the work to be supported needs to be defined.

"Who makes these definitions? The bureaucrats have set up a system which requires them."

Mr Hetherington described himself as a cultural free-marketeer who was fascinated by the music, dress and fashion of the Manchester club scene.

"It's not all beautiful - but neither are sheep in formaldehyde."

webTitle: In brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Detectives were last night questioning two youths arrested in connection with the death of David Hatswell, 16, whose body was discovered with stab wounds in a car park in Rhyl, north Wales.
fields.body:
Two questioned over death

Detectives were last night questioning two youths arrested in connection with the death of David Hatswell, 16, whose body was discovered with stab wounds in a car park in Rhyl, north Wales.

Black success undervalued

The black community is succeeding in a variety of professions such as politics, law, business, medicine and the media but greatly underestimates its contribution to the economy, a survey by the financial services company Western Union said yesterday.

Scottish driving test successes

Learner drivers in Scotland have a much higher chance of passing their tests than anywhere else, according to figures released yesterday by the driving standards agency. The Highland town of Kingussie had an average pass rate last year of 79.2% -nearly double the national 43.7%.

Yoko Ono to host Lennon special

Yoko Ono will present a Top of the Pops special on September 27 to mark the 60th anniversary of John Lennon's birth . The show will feature tracks like Give Peace a Chance, Power to the People and Instant Karma. Lennon would have celebrated his 60th birthday on October 9.

Moving house to escape hell
Neighbours from hell are the reason for 6% of people moving house, according to a survey for the Alliance and Leicester building society. Another 5% moved to be nearer their families.

£20m jackpot

One ticket holder won Saturday's £20m lottery jackpot with numbers 4, 22, 23, 26, 42, 47. The bonus ball was 5. Two winners shared the Thunderball jackpot of £500,000 with numbers 4, 12, 19, 28 and 33. The Thunderball number was 7.

webTitle: Office hours: Diary

fields.headline: WPM
fields.trailText: Diary
fields.body:
 Recruitment consultancy Stopgap has come up with a revolutionary way for firms to hang on to prized workers - be nice to them. As skills shortages loom, Stopgap recommends that bosses put more effort into making their staff feel special: flattery, pictures on the noticeboard and Christmas presents are, apparently, the way to ensure that employees stay loyal and close to their desks. Larger companies might have to take more drastic steps - for how can the MD of a multinational be expected to pass favourable comment on every new hair colour of every admin assistant? - and appoint a full-time Director of Contentment, charged with keeping up the collective chin of the workforce. Can rousing sing-alongs in the staff canteen be far behind?

 Something a Director of Contentment would never stand for, of course, is staff getting the sneaking suspicion that important company decisions were being made behind their backs. Not good at all for the firm's happiness quota. So surely textile firm Coats Viyella didn't intend staff to hear news of the imminent closure of its Shepshed plant - with the loss of all 546 jobs - on the local radio station as they started their working day? Note to prospective Directors of Contentment: this is not a lesson in the perils of having radios in the workplace.

 WPM was thrilled to learn that the gender barriers are being crushed beneath the advancing weight of male support staff. According to a government report, Employment Now, released last week, more men than ever before are working as receptionists, a rise of 56% since 1997. So, instead of a handful of men manning front desks, there's now a slightly more substantial handful of men manning front desks.

 "No physical training programmes in this council are needed. Everyone here takes plenty of exercise jumping to conclusions, flying off the handle, flogging dead horses and stabbing colleagues in the back." Not an office mission statement, oddly, but a message that appeared on - and quickly disappeared from - the noticeboard at Lewisham town hall last week.

 WPM's website of the week is www.DeskDemon.com, which bills itself, rather optimistically, as "heaven at work". WPM refrained from too many blissful raptures while surfing the site, but the online toolbox - offering email, contacts books, calculators and "to do" assistance - would certainly seem to ease life's little stresses, and most of them can be accessed from WAP phones if you manage to escape from the office. And if today's feature on salary shyness (see page 5) makes you wonder if you're getting what you deserve, you could join the DeskDemon discussion groups to find out what a secretary is really worth these days.

 More than his or her weight in gold, it would seem, as insurance company CGNU last week admitted that it had miscalculated one of its pension funds by around £15m. As Mick McAteer of the Consumers' Association pointed out, "The lesson of this mistake is that it's crucial to get the administrative, back office stuff right. Sometimes investment groups concentrate too much on marketing and performance, and don't sort out the vital administrative side of investment." Undervalued support staff? Time to roll out the flattery and the Christmas presents, obviously . . .

 An email reaches WPM from management consultants Breakthrough Technologies, urging workers everywhere to count their blessings as the fuel crisis rumbles on. The fact that employees are being forced to work from home, they say, could encourage bosses to see the long-term benefits of flexible working - although the authors of these glad tidings mystifyingly omit to mention the benefits to the worker of unscheduled days off. Rationed petrol, they add, has meant that more workers have been forced to share cars with colleagues, which could lead to interesting exchanges of information on issues not normally discussed within office walls. Such as, where did they find a service station that was still selling fuel? And, more pressingly, why didn't they leave the tank on empty, allowing them - and you, unlucky car-buddy - to spend a day "stranded" at home?

webTitle: Office hours: Does the office have a future

fields.headline: Coming to a screen near you...
fields.standfirst:
By 2020 the workplace will have changed beyond recognition. Now, where have you heard that before? Merope Mills on the soothsayers and the sceptics
<BR.<A HREF="http://www.workunlimited.co.uk/">Work Unlimited
fields.trailText: By 2020 the workplace will have changed beyond recognition. Now, where have you heard that before? Merope Mills on the soothsayers and the sceptics
fields.body:
The soothsayers were back in business last week, this time casting their prophetic eyes over the future of our employment. Tomorrow's Work, the latest report into the future of the world of business, paints a picture of six-hour days, double pay and all the flexibility that an employee's heart desires.

Following a survey of 1,500 workers and 150 companies, the report is confident in its predictions. Author Graeme Leach, chief economist at the Institute of Directors, boldly claims that, by 2020, the nine-to-five rat race will be extinct and present levels of self-employment, commuting and technology use, as well as age and sex gaps, will have changed beyond recognition.

"The labour market in 2000 is far more traditional than perceived," says Leach. "It is not dominated by part-time employment, flexible working, home-working, teleworking or portfolio workers. But by 2010, I think that's all going to be different. There's going to be huge sea-change in the labour market." He anticipates that, in 20 years' time, 20-25% of the workforce will be temporary workers and many more will be flexible, that 25% of people will no longer work in a traditional office and that 50% will work from home in some form.

There remains, however, a temptation to mumble that we have heard it all before. The future of work and the benefits for workers have been championed frequently in the past, but to no avail. We all continue to trek to our offices on a daily basis because, as much as we moan about it, we know that working in-house is the most effective way of getting things done. Leach is all too aware of this scepticism, arguing that that is why his report forecasts the real changes to happen 20 years from now.

"What our survey showed was that around 20% of organisations think there's going to be massive organisational change within the next decade, and 60% think it's going to be significant. If they are already preparing for that, the changes won't be far behind."

It is a position shared by Jeremy Myerson, director of the Helen Hamlyn Research Centre. "Nobody knows what it's going to be like exactly, but there are various things that we can predict," he says. "For example, the demographics of the workplace are going to change. By 2020, more than 50% of Europe's adult population will be over 50, and there will be a relative shortage of young workers, so employers will have to have more age-friendly policies."

He goes on to forecast a more feminised workplace, spread over a range of locations with miniaturised, fully portable technology. "The current divisions at the moment between stuff you have on a hard screen, and stuff you carry around on paper will go. Instead there'll be display technology which involves electronic screens with all the character istics of paper. This is not over the horizon - this is all very close. This will all be current by 2020."

Of course, no prognosis is complete without its doubters and Clare Lees, associate director of the Henley Centre, which forecasts work trends, is just one of these. "The paperless office will never happen," she says. "Not until we start changing habits in schools, where kids grow up writing and reading books, will we start changing our attitude to paper." Likewise, she is not convinced by the home-working habit. "Right now, only 1% of the working population are formally contracted home-workers - it's hardly the mass market."

Lees highlights instead the "homing at work" trend, where lengthening working hours encourage people to do home-shopping and internet surfing at the office. "In some companies, that's been actively encouraged, because if they're expecting people to work long hours it's a bit of a trade-off," says Lees. "Giving people that flexibility is kind of a treat, but since more than 52% of working adults say they do some kind of homing at work, it's reasonable to say that if you didn't offer that, people would just walk."

One of the business benefits of flexible working, of course, is that the costs of equipment, phone calls and computer use are all lessened by the presence of fewer full-timers in the office. It's a trade-off Barbara Narkiewicz is willing to accept, having gained more from her job since she started her flexible three-day week contract with Kelly Services recruitment company. "Hooked to my ISDN line at home, I can be very productive over a short space of time," she says. "I don't get distracted and I don't have to commute every day." Her decision to work from home was taken because she felt she wanted more leisure time for other things: "I just wanted to fulfil other ambitions that weren't work related."

In line with Leach's report, Narkiewicz is convinced that a growing appreciation of leisure time will see more workers following her initiative: "I feel a lot of people want to do a similar thing. More and more people will start to work like this."

Lucy Cox, an office manager and receptionist with GCI Jane Howard, has been job-sharing for a year. As a single mother, the appeal of shorter working hours is that they allow her to spend more time with her son. "A lot of mothers I know are in a similar position. They don't want to be stuck in a domestic situation. They want to mix with adults and bring some money home, but they don't want to feel that they're constantly fighting a battle to meet their children at the correct time. I can see it happening more and more."

Her desire to "mix with adults" is one that will ensure the office situation will survive in whatever form. Home-working can be a lonely business and one which not everyone would voluntarily embrace. As Leach himself admits: "There's a fear of being outside the loop, of being seen as not working. It's very difficult to imagine those pressures will disappear. Assuming they continue, then so will the office environment."

"There will always be workplaces," says Myerson, "because you need a sort of intense interactive experience." Leach agrees that "the reason you'll go to an office in the future is not to process information or to do private considerative work, but to meet other people. The office of the future will be much more of a social landscape." Even dissenter Lees is ready to concede that we could end up in "the ridiculous situation where you're doing all your work at home but having to go into work to socialise."

Leach is keen to stress that flexible working doesn't necessarily mean working from home. "Work will be done anywhere the laptop can be plugged in or connected to the office. We are still saying that the overwhelming majority of employees will work in an office environment but it will change. The key thing is that it will be a change the workforce generally feels positive about, as opposed to it being forced on us, and taken as the price of globalisation and economic competition."

Cox is testament to that positivity and has no fears for what the future holds. "I think with what I do - running an office - even if people do work more from home or on the mobile, you've still got offices that need to be staffed. There's still a job there. It's definitely not the end to work as we know it."

He goes on to forecast a more feminised workplace, spread over a range of locations with miniaturised, fully portable technology. "The current divisions at the moment between stuff you have on a hard screen, and stuff you carry around on paper will go. Instead there'll be display technology which involves electronic screens with all the character istics of paper. This is not over the horizon - this is all very close. This will all be current by 2020." Of course, no prognosis is complete without its doubters and Clare Lees, associate director of the Henley Centre, which forecasts work trends, is just one of these. "The paperless office will never happen," she says. "Not until we start changing habits in schools, where kids grow up writing and reading books, will we start changing our attitude to paper." Likewise, she is not convinced by the home-working habit. "Right now, only 1% of the working population are formally contracted home-workers - it's hardly the mass market." Lees highlights instead the "homing at work" trend, where lengthening working hours encourage people to do home-shopping and internet surfing at the office. "In some companies, that's been actively encouraged, because if they're expecting people to work long hours it's a bit of a trade-off," says Lees. "Giving people that flexibility is kind of a treat, but since more than 52% of working adults say they do some kind of homing at work, it's reasonable to say that if you didn't offer that, people would just walk." One of the business benefits of flexible working, of course, is that the costs of equipment, phone calls and computer use are all lessened by the presence of fewer full-timers in the office. It's a trade-off Barbara Narkiewicz is willing to accept, having gained more from her job since she started her flexible three-day week contract with Kelly Services recruitment company. "Hooked to my ISDN line at home, I can be very productive over a short space of time," she says. "I don't get distracted and I don't have to commute every day." Her decision to work from home was taken because she felt she wanted more leisure time for other things: "I just wanted to fulfil other ambitions that weren't work related." In line with Leach's report, Narkiewicz is convinced that a growing appreciation of leisure time will see more workers following her initiative: "I feel a lot of people want to do a similar thing. More and more people will start to work like this." Lucy Cox, an office manager and receptionist with GCI Jane Howard, has been job-sharing for a year. As a single mother, the appeal of shorter working hours is that they allow her to spend more time with her son. "A lot of mothers I know are in a similar position. They don't want to be stuck in a domestic situation. They want to mix with adults and bring some money home, but they don't want to feel that they're constantly fighting a battle to meet their children at the correct time. I can see it happening more and more." Her desire to "mix with adults" is one that will ensure the office situation will survive in whatever form. Home-working can be a lonely business and one which not everyone would voluntarily embrace. As Leach himself admits: "There's a fear of being outside the loop, of being seen as not working. It's very difficult to imagine those pressures will disappear. Assuming they continue, then so will the office environment." "There will always be workplaces," says Myerson, "because you need a sort of intense interactive experience." Leach agrees that "the reason you'll go to an office in the future is not to process information or to do private considerative work, but to meet other people. The office of the future will be much more of a social landscape." Even dissenter Lees is ready to concede that we could end up in "the ridiculous situation where you're doing all your work at home but having to go into work to socialise." Leach is keen to stress that flexible working doesn't necessarily mean working from home. "Work will be done anywhere the laptop can be plugged in or connected to the office. We are still saying that the overwhelming majority of employees will work in an office environment but it will change. The key thing is that it will be a change the workforce generally feels positive about, as opposed to it being forced on us, and taken as the price of globalisation and economic competition." Cox is testament to that positivity and has no fears for what the future holds. "I think with what I do - running an office - even if people do work more from home or on the mobile, you've still got offices that need to be staffed. There's still a job there. It's definitely not the end to work as we know it."

webTitle: TV and radio: The stars before they were famous

fields.headline: Work experience
fields.standfirst: The stars before they were famous
fields.trailText: The stars before they were famous
fields.body:
Bette Midler in The Rose (Mark Rydell, 1979)

Who?
A foul-mouthed, obnoxious diva, Midler began her singing career in the 70s, playing in gay bathhouses accompanied by pianist Barry Manilow. Yes, that one. Her counter-cultural kudos was quickly abandoned in the 80s, with acting roles in Down And Out In Beverly Hills (1986) and Ruthless People (1986). She played foul-mouthed, obnoxious, spoilt wives in both. Midler continued an undistinguished film career with the likes of For The Boys (1991) and The First Wives Club (1996), but now, like that other fallen starlet Cybill Shepherd, Midler's got her own sitcom, Bette! (note the exclamation mark, an obvious guarantee of quality).

The role:
Janis Joplin. Oh, sorry, no, that's Rose - the foul-mouthed, obnoxious singer, whose life's a whirlwind of sex, drugs and rock'n'roll. And who therefore bears no resemblance to Janis Joplin at all.

Best Line:
On stage at a stadium show, she breaks between songs to tell the audience: "People say to me 'Rose, when was the first time you heard the blues?' And I tell them 'On the day I was born..."

Cringe factor:
Low. Her acting and singing are of a pretty high standard, and the rock-chick look is definitely a good one for her. In fact, the most striking thing is how much she resembles a pre-Versace Courtney Love.

Other wannabes:
A youthful (well, 53-year-old) Harry Dean Stanton.

Critical judgement:
Leonard Maltin says the film "equates showbiz with hell, then concentrates on giving the audience too much of the latter."

Also not starring in:
Scarecrow In A Garden Of Cucumbers, alongside Warhol superstar (and drag queen) Holly Woodlawn in 1971, and providing the voice for Woody The Spoon in the 1976 TV show Vegetable Soup.

The Rose, Carlton Cinema, Monday September 18, 1am.

webTitle: TV and radio: today's TV

fields.headline: Watch this
fields.trailText: Gregory's Girl | Two Girls And A Guy | Papillon | Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas
fields.body:
Gregory's Girl
(Bill Forsyth, 1981)
8pm, FilmFour

Forsyth's teenie romance about a young lad smitten by a soccer-playing new girl at his school. A beautifully crafted tale, poking tender fun at adolescent courtships and presenting a refreshing picture of Scotland that sent out the ripples which became the Scottish new wave (Trainspotting and all). Performances are brilliant: Dee Hepburn the team's gorgeous new striker; John Gordon Sinclair the awkward lovestruck youth; 10-year-old Allison Foster as little sister patiently instructing him in the ways of the world.

Two Girls And A Guy
(James Toback, 1997)
12.05am, Sky Premier

Mature and intelligent comedy about two women who suddenly discover they've been sharing the same lover for nearly a year. All the action - or rather the discussion - takes place on just one set, the actor-boyfriend's New York loft apartment, but the film never feels static.

Papillon
(Franklin J Schaffner, 1973)
12.40am, FilmFour

Based on Henri Charrière's allegedly autobiographical book about escaping the savage French prison regime on Devil's Island. Steve McQueen suffers beatings, starvation, solitary, and scurvy, and keeps coming back for more: a grittier version of his Cooler King. It's lushly photographed by Fred Koenekamp, and McQueen finds a touching foil in Dustin Hoffman's doddery Dega.

Fear And Loathing In Las Vegas
(Terry Gilliam, 1998)
3.35am, Sky Premier

Hunter S Thompson's drug-fuelled quest in a crimson convertible for the American Dream was labelled the novel that could never be filmed, but this is a defiantly faithful adaptation. Gilliam, creator of fantasies from Jabberwocky to Twelve Monkeys, conjures up astounding pharmaceutical hallucinations. And there are exceptional performances from Johnny Depp as the Thompson alter ego Raoul Duke and from Benicio Del Toro as his pal, Dr Gonzo.

webTitle: TV and radio : Question Time, BBC1

fields.headline: Own goal
fields.trailText: Question Time (Thursday, 10.30pm, BBC1) - returning this week for its 21st run, and the first since the death of founder chairman Sir Robin Day - has usually been regarded as a fixture: a series in which questions were asked, but which expected no questions to be raised about it.
fields.body:
When television programmes are commissioned, they fall into three categories: new proposals, previously broadcast shows seeking a further series and the "fixtures" which are written in to the next year's schedules without debate.

Question Time (Thursday, 10.30pm, BBC1) - returning this week for its 21st run, and the first since the death of founder chairman Sir Robin Day - has usually been regarded as a fixture: a series in which questions were asked, but which expected no questions to be raised about it.

However, the recent speech in which director general Greg Dyke raised the possibility of BBC1 becoming an entertainment channel has made Question Time the victim of the kind of reshuffle speculation which has affected so many of the politicians who have sat around its table.

The new Controller of BBC1, Lorraine Heggessy, has pledged that Question Time will remain on her channel, but keen viewers will nervously check its start-time and the identity of guests. The new series starts at 10.30pm, a decent slot, but one which clashes directly with Newsnight, a series surely courting the same audience.

More troubling is the strong rumour that Glen Hoddle has been approached as a guest in this series. The former England coach is a bright and thoughtful man, but you fear that an appearance on Question Time would be intended to provoke from him the kind of supernatural indiscretion which caused his downfall. His presence would also suggest a trend towards non-political guests.

The latter would be an unfortunate strategy. With Blairism apparently invulnerable - and a cautious administration low on policies - there was a strong case for restricting ministers and their shadows. But, fuelled by the petrol revolt, and with an election likely within a year, politics is interesting again - and Question Time is the best place for that debate. Having now apparently escaped relegation to BBC2, this great discussion club could still enrage season-ticket holders if Hoddle is on the team.

webTitle: TV and radio: Dirty Tricks (Sunday, 9pm, ITV)

fields.headline: Oxford blue
fields.standfirst: The Oxford setting of new crime serial Dirty Tricks is hardly groundbreaking. But its explicit primetime sex scenes - which, for once, aren't gratuitous - could be a first for TV drama, says  Mark Lawson
fields.trailText: The Oxford setting of new crime serial Dirty Tricks is hardly groundbreaking. But its explicit primetime sex scenes - which, for once, aren't gratuitous - could be a first for TV drama, says Mark Lawson
fields.body:
In 1991, two Faber novelists - Michael Dibdin and Nigel Williams - took part in a tour of bookshops. Their readings took advantage of the curious coincidence that both had just published books about men trying to murder their wives: Dibdin's Dirty Tricks and Williams' The Wimbledon Poisoner.

Now, almost a decade later, the tour has produced another coincidence. Williams has adapted Dibdin's novel for a two-part drama: Dirty Tricks (Sunday, 9pm, ITV). Martin Clunes plays an amoral schemer who kills his mistress's husband and then plans to murder her for the insurance money.

Until now, Dibdin - a 53-year-old Ulsterman now living in Seattle - has been unusually unlucky with television. Best known for his series of crime novels about the Italian policeman Aurelio Zen, he has watched as almost every other bestselling crimewriter - PD James, Ruth Rendell, Colin Dexter, Reginald Hill, Ian Rankin, Frances Fyfield, Minette Walters - has been given the sales and publicity push provided by television. Only Dibdin remained caged on the page.

The difficulty seems to have been that detective series on our television are regarded as an English or Scottish form. A Zen series calls for Italian filming (with the added difficulty that each novel is set in a different region) and the possibility of Italian actors - which, in British television, brings memories of the notorious Borgias - although, for a long time, the fine Anglo-Italian actor Alfred Molina was mooted. But the project seems always to have been halted by the Euro-scepticism of drama commissioners: British stories for British people.

So it's revealing that the first Dibdin to reach the screen comes from the fraction of his output set in contemporary England and, furthermore, is a novel set in the north Oxford of Inspector Morse. Dirty Tricks even contains an in-joke in which the uxoricidal character is investigated by an Inspector Moss of Thames Valley CID, who drives a vintage car and has an obsession with real beer and Donizetti. Perhaps it was this jokey shadow of television drama which allowed executives finally to see Dibdin's fiction as suitable for the screen.

The television Dirty Tricks is directed by Paul Seed, who previously visualised House Of Cards and To Play The King. Even viewers who never read credits will soon make the link, because Clunes as the would-be wife-killer delivers soliloquies directly to camera - narrating the story in flashbacks as he dashes to Heathrow to flee to South America - in the style pioneered by Ian Richardson as Francis Urquhart.

This trick is the weakest part of the drama, not only because it's now a second-hand device, but because it feels less logical than in the other series. Urquhart was a consciously Shakesperean figure - Richard III as PM - and politicians have a convention of speaking directly to the viewer in ministerial broadcasts. A poverty-stricken language teacher, Edward lacks either association. Seed does, though, bring other lovely touches. The murdered husband Dennis (Neil Dudgeon) was a wine bore and the coffin at his funeral is topped with bunches of grapes rather than flowers.

But the most intriguing parts of this dark yet jaunty drama are the sex scenes. As a novel, Dirty Tricks was not only sexually explicit but specific. Edward's affair begins when a north Oxford hostess he hardly knows gives him fellatio in the kitchen after a dinner party. She has signalled her interest to Edward by surreptitiously masturbating to orgasm on the sofa while her husband's back is turned. The lovers' desperation for each other is illustrated by couplings including sex in the shower and cunnilingus during menstruation. It later becomes significant that Edward is faking his orgasms.

Although you wouldn't have given the book to your aunt for Christmas, this level of erotic detail is conventional in post-Chatterley novels. But television drama - though sexually obsessed - is rarely sexually adventurous. Most sex on television is missionary position thrusting which leads rapidly to double coming, although female characters identified by the dialogue as feminists are usually allowed a spell on top. Since the 90s, oral sex has been alluded to in that now familiar scene in which one head suddenly slides south out of shot until the head still visible snaps back against the pillow. Detailed attention to who is doing what to who is usually found only in gay dramas such as Queer As Folk.

But, surprisingly, Dirty Tricks acts out most of the acts Dibdin describes - including Karen (Julie Graham) fingering herself on the settee, and even warning her lover that her period has come - and will have puritanical viewers staining their sheets of Basildon Bond with outraged ink. This must be the sauciest story ever screened in ITV peak-time.

The sex, though, is never gratuitous. The subject of the story is lust - for sex, money and power over others - and, in Dirty Tricks, for almost the first time in television drama, sex acts advance the story rather than punctuate it to pump up the ratings. I only hope that the low libido of Aurelio Zen does'not stop Michael Dibdin from going on to get the television exposure he and his detective deserve.

webTitle: Weekend TV

fields.headline: Double jeopardy
fields.trailText: My Fragile Heart | Casualty | Other People's Children
fields.body:
When Bernard the paedophile gets a toilet thrown through his front window in My Fragile Heart (ITV, Sunday), you know things are getting really nasty. Not that things weren't unpleasant before. Adultery on a bed of sofa cushions, burgeoning teenage sexuality in the woods and a shortage of ice in the home of Trina's alcoholic mum (she took to using frozen peas instead), these are not recognisable traits of cosy Sunday night drama. (Indeed, the closest Heartbeat got to anything as disturbing as this was when Charlotte Church pitched up at Yuletide, as welcome as the Grinch who stole Christmas).

The adultery and frozen peas were only tangentially linked to the toilet (unplumbed) in Bernard's living room, since its presence was due to the murder of a young girl. Shannon, as typical a 12-year-old as you'd find, was found dead, and perhaps sexually assaulted, in circumstances alarmingly similar to a crime of which Bernard was found guilty some 15 years ago. Only Bernard's conviction was a miscarriage of justice and he hadn't done it at all, but such a minor detail didn't stop most people leaping to the conclusion that he had struck again. Hence the toilet, a tense chase through battalions of pristine toilets fresh off the production line in the factory where he worked and, predictably, a crowd of banner-waving protestors outside the police station where he was being held. All of which made My Fragile Heart both topical and, more importantly, excellent drama. Only Trina wasn't convinced he had murdered Shannon, and that might have had something to do with the fact that Trina was played by Sarah Lancashire.

Leading this exemplary cast, which included Lorcan Cranitch as Bernard and a flurry of actors more famous for appearing in Brookside, Hollyoaks and Coronation Street, Lancashire was incandescent as ever. With every subtlety of Trina's emotions flickering across her wonderfully expressive face like candlelight dancing on fine china, she delivered a powerful, understated performance entirely in keeping with the pared down, grown-up nature of writer Abi Morgan's words. Morgan's grasp of the intricacies of how people, young and old, talk, and what they actually mean, her storytelling and her truthful vision of a world full of grey areas, not to mention her ability to glide effortlessly between humour and terrible tragedy, mark her out as an honest and talented writer. Her achievement is all the more impressive as she makes Stoke, surely the Aberdeen of England, seem so electric, so charged.

If you take the tube from Walford East, you eventually end up in Holby, a city that expands with every passing series of Casualty (BBC1, Saturday). Now in its 15th series, and with Charlie recuperating from his toilet escapade (not the same as Bernard's, or indeed George Michael's), he did a tour of Holby's boatyard, read its newspaper and visited its police station. This suggested we are being prepared for three new series - Holby Harbour, Holby News and Holby Beat, perhaps.

Charlie's travels only served one purpose however: to remind him where home was: his work. As two teenage burglars got what they deserved - steam burns and a big bit of glass stuck in the leg respectively - Chloe, who speaks as though she's got a hot chip in her mouth at the best of times, was particularly shrill after her room was robbed, and Duffy stated the obvious ("I wasn't born yesterday!") Down Holby, the more things change, the more they stay the same. Next week, as the accidents get more outlandish, someone will come in with injuries caused by a flying toilet. Perhaps.

Portentously, there was a petrol shortage in Other People's Children (BBC1, Sunday). Frazzled Nadine's Lada had ground to a halt on a country road and her husband had used all of his fuel running the children back to her in Herefordshire after a disastrous Christmas day. Only Dale, zooming about in her black Rover and weeping into her mobile phone, had plenty, but no surprise there. Dale, a Bette Davis with blonde highlights, is the kind of girl who thinks she deserves better and will do anything to get it. Her heart shot through with an icicle, her newsreader-esque stepmother-to-be Elizabeth got a frosty enough reception to suggest the woman should fasten her seatbelt. A bumpier ride awaits.

Leading this exemplary cast, which included Lorcan Cranitch as Bernard and a flurry of actors more famous for appearing in Brookside, Hollyoaks and Coronation Street, Lancashire was incandescent as ever. With every subtlety of Trina's emotions flickering across her wonderfully expressive face like candlelight dancing on fine china, she delivered a powerful, understated performance entirely in keeping with the pared down, grown-up nature of writer Abi Morgan's words. Morgan's grasp of the intricacies of how people, young and old, talk, and what they actually mean, her storytelling and her truthful vision of a world full of grey areas, not to mention her ability to glide effortlessly between humour and terrible tragedy, mark her out as an honest and talented writer. Her achievement is all the more impressive as she makes Stoke, surely the Aberdeen of England, seem so electric, so charged. If you take the tube from Walford East, you eventually end up in Holby, a city that expands with every passing series of Casualty (BBC1, Saturday). Now in its 15th series, and with Charlie recuperating from his toilet escapade (not the same as Bernard's, or indeed George Michael's), he did a tour of Holby's boatyard, read its newspaper and visited its police station. This suggested we are being prepared for three new series - Holby Harbour, Holby News and Holby Beat, perhaps. Charlie's travels only served one purpose however: to remind him where home was: his work. As two teenage burglars got what they deserved - steam burns and a big bit of glass stuck in the leg respectively - Chloe, who speaks as though she's got a hot chip in her mouth at the best of times, was particularly shrill after her room was robbed, and Duffy stated the obvious ("I wasn't born yesterday!") Down Holby, the more things change, the more they stay the same. Next week, as the accidents get more outlandish, someone will come in with injuries caused by a flying toilet. Perhaps. Portentously, there was a petrol shortage in Other People's Children (BBC1, Sunday). Frazzled Nadine's Lada had ground to a halt on a country road and her husband had used all of his fuel running the children back to her in Herefordshire after a disastrous Christmas day. Only Dale, zooming about in her black Rover and weeping into her mobile phone, had plenty, but no surprise there. Dale, a Bette Davis with blonde highlights, is the kind of girl who thinks she deserves better and will do anything to get it. Her heart shot through with an icicle, her newsreader-esque stepmother-to-be Elizabeth got a frosty enough reception to suggest the woman should fasten her seatbelt. A bumpier ride awaits.

webTitle: TV and radio

fields.headline: Hear this
fields.trailText: Forgers | It's My Story
fields.body:
If you think worries about the future of the pound are peculiar to the present, Allen Beswick has news for you. In Forgers (11.0am, Radio 4) he recalls the currency crisis George III faced when he succeeded in 1760. It didn't come from Europe but from a band of Yorkshire chancers. The Cragg Vale Coiners clipped enough gold off a guinea piece to squeeze 11 coins from 10. Restoring pubic confidence would have meant recasting every gold coin, a countermeasure that had previously sparked a serious recession.

In the second episode of It's My Story (8.0pm, Radio 4) Sheila Keegan unravels the extraordinary experiences of Rosie and Jessica, attractive, intelligent women bamboozled by two highly skilled Lotharios. Rosie's turned out to be involved with at least 15 other women. Jessica, on the eve of her wedding, discovered that her fiancé had committed 116 offences and spent much of the previous two decades in prison.

webTitle: Women: Anita Roddick

fields.headline: Natural woman
fields.standfirst: Say what you want about Anita Roddick (and people have) but there's one thing beyond dispute: her passion. And now she has poured her heart out in a how-to guide for those wanting to follow in her (peppermint-scented) footsteps.  Libby Brooks reports
fields.trailText: Say what you want about Anita Roddick (and people have) but there's one thing beyond dispute: her passion. And now she has poured her heart out in a how-to guide for those wanting to follow in her (peppermint-scented) footsteps.  Libby Brooks reports
fields.body:
She talks as she lives, without pause for breath. She exists IN CAPITAL LETTERS, with emphasis , high on aphorisms and Inspirational Quotations. "I do take the moral high ground. I take it because I prefer kindness over rapacity, public good over private greed. I don't give a toss. If you don't like someone because they're espousing a better way... fuck it, life's too short."

Mockable, inexorable Anita Roddick. Queen of Peppermint Foot Lotion, with her do-goody slogans, her till-side petitions, her estimated fortune (shared with husband Gordon) of £40m. The batty alma mater of the Body Shop behemoth, with more business than sense; the anti-entrepreneur who put principles before profit, didn't test on animals, recycled, traded fair, battled in Seattle.

The Artemis of green consumerism has now given up day-to-day running of the business she and Gordon set up 24 years ago in her home town of Littlehampton. Following an effortless trajectory in the eco-hungry 80s, the Body Shop stuttered under the demands of global expansion, sustaining heavy losses in the US and failing to adapt to the changing face of the beauty market. As the formula lost its freshness, so the Roddicks' familial approach lacked the tight professionalism demanded by a multinational.

"So you brought in new people, people who were strangers, then you had to let go. And that letting go was much easier than the media thought it would be. I don't do anything I don't want to do," she adds, believably.

Roddick's exhausting, exhaustive autobiography, Business as Unusual, published today, charts the company's uneasy transition in counterpoint to her own evolution. In print and in person, she refers to the Body Shop's corporate centre with indulgence and incomprehension: "The Board" is at once petulant toddler and piranha.

One chapter recounts an archetypal stand-off when the Gulf War broke out. Roddick put together an instant anti-war campaign, posting billboards and setting up petitions in every shop. A week later, the board voted to drop it, deeming it too political and bad for the company's image.

Undaunted, Roddick insisted on involving everyone in head office; the company closed for a day. "I'll never know what would have happened had the debate turned against me. I was saved by a couple of members of staff who had been to the Falklands and served in Northern Ireland. They explained what war was like, that war is never meant to save democracy, and I didn't have to say anything."

The joy in the past, she says, was when you didn't have to explain: "You instinctively knew it was a good idea and you had the resources to back it up. Now there's presentations, there's conflict, there's less bravery. That's not bad, it's probably how you survive, but it's less interesting for me. The minute you put an anti-ageing cream out, I'm out the door, the minute you stand for nothing, but they're not that..." She decides against "stupid". "They understand that this company was built on more than products."

Her gaze is even but her hands and feet are frantic: shoes off, shoes on, shoe lost under the chair; palm cupping, now a fist, now fingers spidering across the table. Roddick is small but everything about her feels big: the copper wire hair, the mouth etched with a particular set of lines from pursing in polemic. Her energy is abundant and heedless of boundary. She is the kind of woman who leaves the toilet door open so she can continue a conversation. The passion is personal, activism is everyday.

"You do become more radical as you get older. Men become more familial or collegiate, they play golf. [Golf is clearly the nadir of pointless activity.] But women have an amazing way of reinventing themselves."

She continues to devote most of her time to Body Shop business, she says, doing "the belly to belly stuff", going on delivery runs at 5am, visiting the company's community trade initiatives and working on a slew of projects from Easterhouse to Ogoniland. She is also developing a range called Wise Women "because nobody is dealing with products for my age group [she is 57]. Our face is looking after itself but our body is one sack of dead skin. They need products that make you feel less dry, a million more products for the feet. I listen to 80-year-olds and what offends them? Feet! It's an ignored area."

Does she balk at being synonymous with Peppermint Foot Lotion? "I bloody love it. I'd be depressed if it was a bloody bubble bath, there's nothing of value in that, but the lotion and the community trade project, I'm a happy bunny with that one."

The campaign fest could grate. Is it real? Is it naive? Is it embarrassing? "It's been a consistent pattern," she points out. "Take the money and turn it into something beyond profit for shareholders, shape a company's dynamics and the consciousness of people you employ. I'm too intelligent to think people I employ go home dreaming about moisture cream."

But what about those who simply work to support themselves? "Absolutely, that's 90% of what we have and you can't fire them for being boring, you can't fire someone if they're not political. What you do is say you will have the best working conditions, sabbatical time, a child development centre, a love programme that allows you to train for anything you want, but don't mess around with the values."

Born in a bomb shelter in 1942, Roddick was the product of an improbably romantic union between her mother and her father's cousin. Her nominal father died when Anita was 10, still believing her his daughter, and cousin Henry moved in. She delights in the tale. "The duplicity was incredible: the only Italians in town and she was conducting an affair with her husband's cousin! I loved that."

Her mother taught her to be uncynical about love and that love and work were seamless. As a child, she learnt the lot of the poor and the outsider. But she traces her sense of outrage to a specific. "It's a kick-start from the day I knew my dad died. The same week I picked up this book on the Holocaust. It was the first time photographs of the concentration camps came out in paperback. I really do connect that outrage with loss."

Do public events upset her more than private ones? "It's not about what affects you most, it's about what you can do to solve the problem. What you can do," she stresses. "When it becomes abysmal is when you have a sense of outrage and you do nothing. I take this stuff so bloody personally."

I ask her to place some self-descriptives in order of importance. ("Couldn't we have some better words? What about community organiser?") She puts activist first, businesswoman last, partner and mother second equal. And gladly acquiesces to the suggestion that her daughters, Justine and Sam, now mothers themselves, were at times secondary to her work. "If they were unhappy, if they were ill, everything dropped. If they were just being boring little kids, I was doing my life. They were never the pivot of my horizon and I never wanted to be theirs."

As for Gordon, her husband and partner for over three decades, famously the provider of "sympathetic sperm" for a broody Roddick, whom she later "learned to fall in love with": "It's been an amazing journey and it hasn't finished yet. What we've now got to work out is the pattern of life outside the company, how will we mould our interests into things that are really productive, what moral and political influence can we have."

It all sounds rather draining. Is Gordon as obsessive? "Probably not. He's much more behind the scenes. He has leisure, which I don't have. He plays golf, he balances his life better. But I don't want to be in his shadow.

"All my real passions, that's what gives me the joy. Like the journey I took last week with Leonard, this old Korean vet, sitting in the middle of the desert and he's been painting this mountain for 10 years. He's got quotes in the picture, he's got 'God is love'. I love the obsession, that notion of continuity. He's been there for years, doing the same thing, staying focused."

And what about the cynics who might venture that a decade is just too long to spend on one painting, that perhaps Leonard might benefit from psychiatric intervention, or that he might make a more beneficial contribution to society if he drove back into town and got a job?

"Up your bum."

 Business As Unusual is published today by Thorsons at £17.99. For details of Anita Roddick's bookshop talks, tel 020-8307 4563

webTitle: Women: Are women cautious

fields.headline: Risky business
fields.standfirst: New research suggests that we women are by nature a cautious lot.  Luisa Dillner gives the idea some careful thought
fields.trailText: New research suggests that we women are by nature a cautious lot.  Luisa Dillner gives the idea some careful thought
fields.body:
Women tend not to race their friends in Ford Cortinas at 90mph down dark country roads or have competitions setting fire to their pubic hair. In the game of truth or dare, they prefer the former. So it comes as no surprise that a survey by Eastern Energy finds three-quarters of women are risk avoiders. While researchers warn this goes against the great British entrepreneurial spirit, they also suggest women's risk avoidance spills over into other aspects of our lives.

"Risk avoiders want to protect themselves against making the wrong decision," says Dr David Lewis, a specialist in the psychology of decision-making, who was involved in the research. He warns: "Risk avoiders may try so hard to find the perfect partner that they are never satisfied and end up living alone. To succeed in any aspect of life, it is essential to take a few risks."

While ending up alone is obviously the biggest risk of all (ahem) for any woman, there's little evidence that our risk avoidance extends into relationships. "You could say women are much more risky than men in relationships," says psychologist Dr Janet Reibstein. "They are more prepared to enter into a relationship and put themselves out there more. Men may seem to take risks but their behaviour is more impulsive."

It is women who take more of the real risks because they are more ready to say the relationship is important. "Women are more aware of what they want and so take more risks than men do because they name what's going on emotionally."

Women may also take risks and go out with a man their friends think unsuitable. "Men may take a broadbrush approach to women - they may be clear who's for them and who is not," Reibstein says. "Women always see more shadow."

In sifting the biological from the environmental, it can be hard to determine what makes women more cautious in other areas. "If there is a risk gene, it is probably men who have it," says Professor Ben Fletcher, dean of the Business School at Hertfordshire University. "Scientific literature suggests men are more risk-taking, but it's women who are better able to cope with the problems it brings. They are psychologically more robust, they will discuss problems and agree a course of action."

It's not fear of failing that stops women taking risks, Fletcher says. "Women's self-esteem and confidence are as good as men's. But women have more coherence between how they feel and what they do. Men have greater unrealistic optimism."

Put simply and generalising wildly, women are just more sensible. "They are less interested in widening the gap between how they feel and how they behave," he adds. "Men will put up with a greater gulf, put themselves into positions where they feel fearful and think they may not cope."

Women still do take risks, traditionally with contraception (lack of), smoking and drinking, and we are starting to participate more in male areas of risk-taking, such as buying shares. Proshare, a share club lobby group, says 40% of investment clubs in the UK are now led by women compared with 15% three years ago.

"I base my share buying on what I can afford to lose," says Maggie Brown, a multimedia consultant. "Women tend to look at the pros and cons before trying anything and if you do that and then go along with what you find, by definition you are not risk-taking. Men probably don't even realise that they are taking a risk - they haven't thought about it first."

It wouldn't be the safest of bets they even think about it afterwards.
