webTitle: Arts: architecture

fields.headline: Glass act
fields.standfirst: The man who gave us the high-tech splendour of Waterloo International and the Eden Project has now got his hands on Battersea Power Station. Hannah Baldock reports
fields.trailText: The man who gave us the high-tech splendour of Waterloo International and the Eden Project has now got his hands on Battersea Power Station. Hannah Baldock reports
fields.body:
Nick Grimshaw leans back in his chair, afternoon sun glinting on his spectacles, admiring his new office. The architect has had the builders in for five months, extending his practice's headquarters in London's West End to accommodate a staff of 120. His desk now faces a 30ft glass wall, overlooking a floor packed end to end with architects.

"We are going to have a map of the world etched on the glass, with markers for all our projects," he says, unabashed. The highlights will include an art gallery in Spain, an extension to Zurich airport, a landmark bridge in the Netherlands and a £27m Plant Science Centre in St Louis, Missouri.

Grimshaw, 60, may be one of the leading high-tech architects, but he is not usually the flamboyant sort. "Some people want to have a high profile and involve themselves in public life," he says. 'That's up to them. I prefer to let my buildings speak for themselves."

Grimshaw is one of the four big architects of the 1960s generation, alongside Lords Rogers and Foster and Sir Michael Hopkins, and the only one still a plain Mr. That doesn't bother him, he says. "I don't think one could say it was central to one's operation as an architect. We are not one person; we are a firm. I think there is a sense of pride that one gets as a firm from being recognised, but I think it is neither here nor there, really."

He recently gained another kind of recognition when he won the contract to handle the £500m redevelopment of Battersea Power Station. Grimshaw's scheme, approved by Wandsworth council last month, will see the derelict power station converted into a complex of 650 luxury flats, offices, exhibition areas, theatre space, cinemas, a hotel and restaurants. Grimshaw is riveted by the scale of the project.

Nicholas Grimshaw & Partners has come a long way from the low-cost industrial enclosures that made its name, but Grimshaw has remained true to the principles of high tech. He concentrates on the intricacies of a building, combining architecture with product design to flaunt the structural components. "I am very keen on the industrial design side of life," he says.

A new exhibition of the practice's work between 1993 and 2000, called Equilibrium, has just opened at the Design Museum in London. The show's notes proclaim the group's emphasis on "structural finesse, sustainability and the employment of new technology". Grimshaw has an idiosyncratic image of his work. "I am very keen on boats. I want my buildings to have the feel of a fine yacht. It is to do with the longevity of the brand, quality of the detailing - never a nasty finish on anything."

Grimshaw's team has produced a number of elegant structures, as Equilibrium shows. There are the asymmetrical tubular steel arches of Waterloo International, the snaking elegance of the Ijburg Bridge between Ijmeer Lake and Amsterdam, and the Caixa Galicia gallery in La Coruna, Spain, whose sloping metal-clad facade has been described as "a wave rolled up on the harbour front".

Yet for all their beauty, Grimshaw's buildings have often been accused of harbouring technical flaws. The ship-shaped £33.5m Western Morning News headquarters in Plymouth, for example, completed in 1993, features south-facing window walls that cause glare on the journalists' screens. "We planted a row of trees," insists Grimshaw. "They just had to grow a bit. We had [also] designed sail-like blinds that the users could control, to create shade, but they had not wanted to buy them until they had seen how the building worked."

When Waterloo International was finished in 1992, it was feted as a symbol of 21st-century pan-European travel. But last year some panels in the glazed canopy started to crack and fall on to the platforms below. Critics claimed that it symbolised the risks inherent in pushing technology to its limits.

Grimshaw bristles at criticism of Waterloo, and insists that the problems were not in the design. "No one is suggesting that an architect in 1988 should not have specified toughened glass. There is not an architect in the country who hasn't specified toughened glass in some situation or another who would not be affected by nickel sulphide." What about reports of impact damage? Grimshaw confirms that there was some near a local pub, conjuring up images of bottles flying overhead. Reports of a deer leg hitting the roof are also true. The projects completed since have been well received, however, including the £40m first phase of the remodelling of Paddington Station, with its state-of-the-art flat-screen signage and furniture developed by the firm's product design arm. Then there is the £76m Eden Project, with its delicate geodesic domes encasing tropical foliage sited in a Cornish claypit, which has enchanted the public, and the £90m spa in Bath, with its rooftop pool. Now it seems that Parkview president Victor Hwang wants as much of Grimshaw as he can get. Hwang wants to reassemble the facade, solar shading and water wall of Grimshaw's British Pavilion for the Seville Expo 1992 in the Battersea complex. He is understood to have made an offer to the Asian businessman who has the pavilion stored in containers and plans to use it as a venue for weddings.

"But also I think there is a lot of potential socially in buildings - that they can be much more user-friendly places. And the whole home/work idea: I'm quite keen on the idea of designing buildings that can be either residential or offices. Offices might be much more like residential buildings, with nice places to eat and sit around in."

webTitle: Women: The age of dissent : Column

fields.headline: Poor kids
fields.standfirst: The age of dissent
fields.trailText: Michele Hanson: The age of dissent
fields.body:
Rosemary heard some depressing news last week. An 11-year-old boy had been named and shamed for disgraceful behaviour, placed under curfew and his mother sent to parenting classes. It reminded Rosemary of a tiny client of hers whom she met years ago when she worked as a hospital social worker.

This client was born in poor and unfortunate circumstances. Rosemary spotted his parents in the antenatal clinic of the hospital. They had a tremendous row over some cigarettes, the father kicked the mother in the stomach and she went into early labour. For the next 10 days she stayed in hospital, the father lurched in and out visiting and drunk, and eventually they took their baby home.

Feeling worried, Rosemary went to visit. There was baby, two weeks old, propped up in his carry- cot, grizzling feebly, little head wobbling, eyes squinting and cradle cap flourishing, in front of the telly. Rosemary asked brightly how things were going. They were going badly. Father had buzzed off, mother was sinking into despair and as they spoke, baby cried louder and louder. "Watch the telly, you little fucker," cried the mother. "It's your programme."

This baby hadn't ever had much of a chance. He was born too early, sent home with his battered, depressed mother, then into foster care, back to mother for a bit of bonding because everyone was keen on that idea, then back into care and most likely on to school exclusions, petty crime and prison.

But Rosemary couldn't help him much. Hospital social workers must step back after 10 weeks and hand mother and baby over to ordinary social workers, who are overworked and burdened by gargantuan caseloads, and sometimes a small baby can be overlooked. Possibly until he's 11, urinating on other people's washing and being a public nuisance, like last week's boy, who perhaps also had got off to a bad start.

Looking back, Rosemary wished she'd been able to whisk the baby away for adoption at once. Or help the mother intensively right from the beginning. But no one was quite sure what to do at the time. They diddled until it was too late. That is another advantage to being old. You can learn from all your ghastly mistakes and show the next generation how to get it right. But will they listen?

webTitle: Passnotes

fields.headline: No: 1722
fields.standfirst: Renée Zellweger
fields.trailText: Renée Zellweger
fields.body:
Is she another one of those exotic Dutch or Icelandic actresses?
Hardly. Renée was brought up in the decidedly prosaic town of Katy, Texas.

So has she done anything I might know?
Well, she was the girl in Jerry Maguire and can currently be seen with Morgan Freeman in Nurse Betty. This week she'll be gracing British screens in the latest Farrelly Brothers piece of slapstick, Me, Myself and Irene.

Tell me about it:
Cop Jim Carrey woos her with his sparklingly offensive jokes, by defecating on a neighbour's lawn and repeatedly threatening the poor girl with a dildo.

Charming!
Clearly Renée thought so. Soon after shooting ended, the two were spotted by People magazine "playing Twister" outside a New York restaurant. "He is a very handsome man," Renee insists. The National Alliance for the Mentally Ill was less flattering about Carrey and complained that his portrayal in the film of a person with multiple personalities "mocked the mentally ill".

You know, I think I may have recently spotted Renée hanging out in Kensington.
Yes. She was recently in London to film the adaptation of Bridget Jones. As preparation she did work experience at Picador, watched Coronation Street, shopped at Harvey Nicks and sank pints of Guinness and slices of pizza, putting on a stone in weight.

Heavens forfend!
Harper's Bazaar did. The American fash mag knocked her off their cover last week after objecting to her newly- aquired plumpness.

Still, with three films out this year, a Hollywood actor dangling on her arm and a $3m pay cheque for every movie, our Renée probably isn't too worried about the critics.
Ah, but our Renée would never gloat. She is a simple girl at heart. "I love my ignorance, I cherish it," she giggles. "It's like having a child's perspective on the world."

Not to be confused with:
Andie MacDowell, Julia Roberts, Gwyneth Paltrow, or any other pretty American imported into a British film.

webTitle: US warns against resuming flights to Baghdad

fields.headline: US warns against resuming flights to Baghdad
fields.standfirst: Special report: Iraq
fields.trailText: A campaign to restore civilian air travel to Baghdad gained pace yesterday when Jordan joined Russia in declaring that it was preparing to end 10 years of Iraqi isolation.
fields.body:
A campaign to restore civilian air travel to Baghdad gained pace yesterday when Jordan joined Russia in declaring that it was preparing to end 10 years of Iraqi isolation.

As Iraq continued to accuse Kuwait of stealing its oil and the US warned President Saddam Hussein against renewing hostilities in the Gulf, Jordan said it was consulting other countries about resuming civilian flights.

Moscow said last week that it might begin passenger flights to Baghdad next month, but no final decision has been taken. Russian and Iraqi officials are negotiating the arrangements.

While the US and Britain insist that non-humanitarian flights to Baghdad are proscribed by the UN sanctions resolution, Russia and France say that the resolution makes no explicit mention of passenger air traffic.

The US secretary of state, Madeleine Albright, said civilian flights into Saddam Hussein International Airport were not a good idea.

The Jordanian trade minister, Wasef Azar, was quoted by the Petra news agency yesterday as saying that Jordan was "coordinating with various international sides to resume air flights to Iraq".

Iraq has accused Kuwait of stealing hundreds of thousands of barrels of oil daily from two oilfields near the southern port of Basrah. Kuwait has replied that it is far readier to resist than it was 10 years ago when Iraq invaded its territory.

The US defence secretary, William Cohen, said yesterday: "We have made it very clear to Saddam Hussein that he should not seek to pose a threat to his neighbours or to his own people as he has done in the past."

Iraqi newspapers said it was "common knowledge" that Kuwait was stealing Iraqi oil.

Kuwait said yesterday that Iraq posed a real danger to the region, and called on the international community to take "serious steps" to end the threat.

Iraq would "pay dearly if it committed any military stupidity," it said.

webTitle: Neo-confederates want out of US

fields.headline: Neo-confederates want out of US
fields.standfirst: Special report: the US elections
fields.trailText: Tens of thousands of white southerners are reported to be joining organisations that seek independence from the rest of the US, claiming that the federal government no longer represents "southern values". Opponents say these neo-confederate groups are allowing militant and racist whites to organise politically under the guise of a heritage movement.
fields.body:
Tens of thousands of white southerners are reported to be joining organisations that seek independence from the rest of the US, claiming that the federal government no longer represents "southern values". Opponents say these neo-confederate groups are allowing militant and racist whites to organise politically under the guise of a heritage movement.

Last week the Southern party, which advocates secession, won its first mayoral victory, in a village in Alabama.

The party is an offshoot of a group called the League of the South, which says there has been a surge in its membership as white southerners become disillusioned with the "multiculturalism" of the main parties. The league is led by academics and cites as its inspiration such separatist movements as the Northern League in Italy.

Mark Potok of the Southern Poverty Law Centre, which has just completed a report on the growth of the southern movement, said it was "providing a veneer of moral legitimacy for people who would be embarrassed to join the [white supremacist Ku Klux] Klan".

"White supremacists do not always come wearing Klan hoods, shaved heads or storm trooper outfits. Sometimes they boast business suits and PhDs," he said.

The growth of the movement became apparent earlier this year when South Carolina bowed to national pressure and transferred the battle flag of the Confederacy from the dome of its statehouse to a nearby monument. Many see the flag as the symbol of a civil war fought to preserve slavery.

"[The new-confederates] were bitterly angry about that," Mr Potok said. "That was a big loss." But flag issue gave them the chance to recruit whites who felt increasingly estranged from mainstream politics.

The League of the South is led by a former history professor, Michael Hill, whose office is in Tuscoloosa, Alabama. Formed in 1994, it has about 9,000 members.

It and other neo-confederate groups point to the break-up of the Soviet Union, the separatist Québécois movement in Canada, and the Northern League in Italy as examples of what is possible.

As the League of the South is not a political party, some of its members formed the Southern party, which now has 2,000 members. Last week Wayne Willingham, 37, became its first successful candidate in a mayoral election, in the village of West Point, Alabama, where he beat the incumbent by a single vote. Mr Willingham described himself as "just an old country boy who's tired of things being done the way they are".

The other main body in the southern movement is the Council of Conservative Citizens, which has about 15,000 members. It recently deplored on its website a music festival in Charleston, South Carolina, as a "multicultural mudbath [which] attracts mostly queers and weirdos".

The Southern Poverty Law Centre's report, Rebels with a Cause, lists 14 different groups which it says operate in 25 states, mainly in the south, to promote the confederate cause. They include the Heritage Preservation Association which has declared "total war" on those who attack southern values and culture, and the Confederate States of America, a group which would like to repeal laws that gave citizenship to blacks and votes to women.

The main theoretical journal of the movement is called American Renaissance. It is edited by a white separatist, Jared Taylor, a board member of the Council of Conservative Citizens. The magazine promotes such notions as blacks having smaller brains and the dangers of non-white immigration.

The Edgefield Journal, "the only true southern nationalist newspaper", is the other main publication; a recent piece suggested that "many slaves were willing to be slaves".

The groups are represented in court by Kirk Lyons, a lawyer who shows his affection for the "Anglo-Celtic" roots of the movement by dressing up periodically in a top hat and kilt. He has described Hitler as "probably the most misunderstood man in German history" and is now the chief lawyer acting on behalf of the Southern Legal Resource Centre, which is the movement's legal arm.

Mr Potok says he accepts that not all who have joined the heritage movement are racists. "But a scene once dominated by civil war re-enactors and those who maintain Confederate monuments is turning increasingly ugly."

Michael Hill is dismissive of Mr Potok's centre and its report, seeing the centre as a "snooping organisation for the federal government" out to "feather its own nest".

The league was mainly interested in preserving the "symbols, language, cuisine and music" of the south.

"We are seeking to preserve a distinct regional culture," Mr Hill told the Guardian, "and we believe in political independence". While he agreed that independence might be unrealistic now, he said that "in five, 10, 50 or 100 years" it could happen.

Mainstream politics did not address the League's concerns. "The Democrats and Republicans are two sides of the same coin. There's not a dime's worth of difference between them."

"The US government ... interferes in virtually every aspect of everyday life. Rather than "sitting around wringing our hands", he said, they were getting organised.

fields.headline: Crucial poll panics Trimble's party
fields.standfirst:
His colleagues have put on a show of unity but the Ulster Unionist leader faces a lose-lose scenario at this week's South Antrim byelection
Special report: Northern Ireland
fields.trailText: They stood shoulder to shoulder in Antrim shopping centre on Saturday. Just as well, because it cut out any chance of back stabbing. There were Lord Molyneaux, ex-Ulster Unionist party leader, consistently against the Good Friday agreement, the incumbent, David Trimble, still an avowed supporter, and Jeffrey Donaldson, long tipped as likely successor, and the most vociferous of all opponents of the deal. Add in the sceptics, and all hues of party opinion were there.
fields.body:
They stood shoulder to shoulder in Antrim shopping centre on Saturday. Just as well, because it cut out any chance of back stabbing. There were Lord Molyneaux, ex-Ulster Unionist party leader, consistently against the Good Friday agreement, the incumbent, David Trimble, still an avowed supporter, and Jeffrey Donaldson, long tipped as likely successor, and the most vociferous of all opponents of the deal. Add in the sceptics, and all hues of party opinion were there.

It was a rare display of Ulster Unionist unity, as they posed in support of David Burnside, one of the party's more impressive performers. He is fighting to defend what should be a rock solid 16,500 majority in the South Antrim byelection on Thursday.

Curtis Watson, five, rather spoiled the moment, savaging public relations guru Mr Burnside, 48, with his plastic claw. The laughs rang somewhat hollow.

Critical

For the result, due early on Friday, could scarcely be more critical. Aside from the small matter of Northern Ireland's future, Ulster Unionists' survival is at stake. The party is in panic.

Mr Burnside is tough, British Airways' director of communications during its dirty tricks war with Virgin, and a former leading light, with Mr Trimble, of Vanguard, the hardline loyalist group. This, though, is his toughest fight, and he says the outcome is knife edge.

For Mr Trimble, it is a lose-lose scenario. Defeat for Mr Burnside could spark a domino effect, come the general election, for how many of the party's seats, currently at 10, would be safe? Four, maybe, according to one of Mr Trimble's own assembly members.

While victory for Mr Burnside might stave off an immediate challenge to Mr Trimble's leadership, it would shift the balance of opinion within the party even further away from the agreement, now 30 months old. Many insiders predict the new MP would be a more serious threat in the medium term to Mr Trimble than Mr Donaldson, and that, in turn, impacts on the new political system.

Mr Burnside, one-time Trimble ally, reflects the shifting mood of party members. He backed the agreement with fingers crossed, but was opposed to returning to devolution in May after suspension.

"If Tony Blair had told me 30 months ago that all paramilitary prisoners would have been out without decommissioning; that political parties still linked to those capable of terrorist violence would be in government; and that the reform of policing did not, as the agreement says, require the support of the wider community, then I would have voted No.

"But there is no referendum tomorrow. What I will be working for is against those concessions, and the only party that is capable of representing Unionism is the Ulster Unionist party. This is more than a fight between supporters and opponents of the agreement, as the range of opinion backing me proves."

Popular

In other times, Mr Burnside would be a shoo-in: the mainly agricultural area has long been an Ulster Unionist stronghold, and Clifford Forsythe, while invisible on a wider stage, was a popular constituency MP, cantering home at every shout since 1983. His sudden death in April sparked Mr Trimble's byelection headache, despite bequeathing a 16,611 majority.

But the Democratic Unionist party, a vociferous critic of the agreement, is no longer allowing Ulster Unionists a free-run. It is instead turning an otherwise meaningless poll into a referendum of the agreement, and Mr Trimble's stewardship of it.

The DUP stands a fine chance. Votes for Unionist candidates opposed to the agreement at the referendum in May 1998 were evenly split, and the erosion of backing for it among the silent majority - middle class, moderate Protestants - is, it seems, stunning.

The DUP's candidate is assembly member Willie McCrea, MP for Mid-Ulster until Sinn Fein's Martin McGuinness humiliated him in May 1997, and the preacher and gospel singer is an adept doorstep campaigner. He shrugs off continuing controversy over his links to late loyalist leader Billy Wright, at whose funeral he officiated.

His team, much more active on the doorsteps, is taking a populist approach. It is oozing confidence. There is traditionally a low turnout in South Antrim, and disenchanted Ulster Unionists are more disinclined to vote. That will benefit Mr McCrea, 52, with apathy Mr Burnside's greatest enemy. But the Ulster Unionist's message, too, is confused.

Mr Burnside wants those who backed the agreement wholeheatedly to support him because Mr McCrea offers them nothing; those who voted for it and who are now sceptics, to look to him as he will best represent those worries; and he appeals to those who voted No "honourably" to place their X against his name. Hardly clear cut.

Mr Burnside and Mr McCrea both believe they are battling for the soul of Unionism. Each says it is lost if the other wins.

Mr Burnside says: "Opposition politics is easy. You throw insults and blame somebody else for everything, from the morning rain to the housing crisis. Try and list me what the other party has ever done to protect and promote Unionism."

But Mr McCrea, knocking on doors in Templepatrick, where the late MP lived, says: "I want to galvanise the Unionist family. To vote for me is to vote to ditch the discredited agreement and to call a halt to the continual drip-drip feed of concessions to republicans."

Other candidates are assembly member Donovan McClelland, 51, for the SDLP; ex-IRA man Martin Meehan, representing Sinn Fein, and David Ford, who sits in the assembly for the Alliance party.

webTitle: On the beach; ferry's unscheduled port of call

fields.headline: On the beach; ferry's unscheduled port of call
fields.trailText: A cargo ferry was refloated yesterday after running aground on sandbanks directly in front of the Liverpool coastguard station at Crosby, Merseyside. The P&O vessel European Leader, sailing from Dublin to Liverpool with 65 passengers and 35 crew, was freed by the rising tide after four hours.
fields.body:
A cargo ferry was refloated yesterday after running aground on sandbanks directly in front of the Liverpool coastguard station at Crosby, Merseyside. The P&O vessel European Leader, sailing from Dublin to Liverpool with 65 passengers and 35 crew, was freed by the rising tide after four hours.

After engine repairs, the ferry headed for Liverpool under its own steam and berthed at Gladstone dock.

The inshore lifeboat was called from New Brighton to check for damage to the 13,000-tonne vessel and for signs of possible pollution in the sea.

Most of the lorry drivers on board were asleep when the ship was stranded less than a mile from the shore. No passengers or crew members were injured.

A spokesman for P&0 Ferries said the company would launch an investigation into the grounding. Divers are expected to be brought in to check for damage to the ship's hull. While the vessel waited for high water, crowds gathered to watch developments.

webTitle: Beer guide suggests pints for the ladies to put fizz back into real ale industry

fields.headline: Beer guide suggests pints for the ladies to put fizz back into real ale industry
fields.trailText: The rules of drinking, according to Al Murray in his show The Pub Landlord, are clear: only men should drink pints and ladies should stick to "fruit-based drinks".
fields.body:
The rules of drinking, according to Al Murray in his show The Pub Landlord, are clear: only men should drink pints and ladies should stick to "fruit-based drinks".

So the comedian would be alarmed to learn that unless women take to sinking pints of beer, some of men's favourite ales could be under threat.

A leading beer writer has claimed that Britain's declining real ale industry could be in trouble unless it tempts women drinkers away from white wine and gin and tonic and encourages them to try traditional cask beer.

Writing in the 2001 Good Beer Guide, published today, Lynne Pearce argues that the majority of brewers persist in making and marketing beers with male consumers in mind.

While increasing numbers of women are going to pubs, she argues, "the local is still perceived as a predominantly male domain, where the female of the species is tolerated only if she is pulling your pint".

In the face of aggressive competition from designer bottled beers, draught lagers and alcopops, Ms Pearce believes it is time that the declining ale industry finds new drinkers beyond its traditional markets.

"Women are definitely being sidelined by brewers," she said yesterday. "But by continually marketing at men they are targeting a group that has essentially peaked."

More than half of women visit bars regularly, compared to 23% in 1994, and the proportion drinking more than 14 units of alcohol a week has risen from 10% to 15%.

But it is the makers of lagers and bottled spirit mixers that are reaping the rewards. Bacardi Breezer, a chilled rum and fruit mixer cocktail, now outsells many bottled beers - 60% of its drinkers are female. This is the market, Ms Pearce believes, that the real ale industry must capture if it is to arrest its steady decline.

Much of the problem lies with presentation, according to David Spencer, brands manager at the London brewery, Fuller's, which recently commissioned research into the way cask beers were perceived. "There is a credibility gap for real ale," he said yesterday.

"Premium lagers and Guinness are carving out the territory of sophistication and appealing to discerning drinkers.

"If you look at a lot of real ale advertising, it tends to talk about the ingredients and the process. There was nothing aspirational about the way real ale has been marketed."

webTitle: Shock in Peru as strongman quits

fields.headline: Shock in Peru as strongman quits
fields.trailText: After years of authoritarian leadership, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru has capitulated to pressure at home and abroad with the announcement that he will stand down and call new elections.
fields.body:
After years of authoritarian leadership, President Alberto Fujimori of Peru has capitulated to pressure at home and abroad with the announcement that he will stand down and call new elections.

Mr Fujimori, South America's longest-serving leader, delivered the bombshell during a televised speech to the nation on Saturday night.

The news took everyone by surprise, coming only four months after a hard-fought presidential election in which he used dictatorial methods to keep his grip on power.

"Despite having been elected by a majority of the population, I do not want to become a disturbing factor, and much less, an obstacle to the strengthening of the democratic system," Mr Fujimori said.

Immediately after the announcement, thousands of jubilant Peruvians celebrated outside the presidential palace in Lima. In other cities drivers waved flags and honked their car horns late into the night.

Mr Fujimori, 62, indicated that his decision was linked to a deepening bribery scandal sparked by video footage of his head of intelligence handing over cash to a rival politician.

"After deep reflection, I have decided, first, to deactivate the national intelligence system and, second, to call general elections as soon as possible. In these general elections, it goes without saying, I will not participate. I am sure the people will be able, with prudence, to choose the best destiny."

Despite the corruption scandal, the announcement by Mr Fujimori astonished Peruvians and foreign observers alike. After 10 years in office, he was a regional paradigm of an authoritarian but effective populist who governs in tandem with the security forces.

Opposition Congressman Carlos Ferrero said Mr Fujimori was forced to step down because the armed forces, especially the army, had withdrawn support."If Fujimori had continued to have the support of the armed forces, he never would have said what he said tonight," Mr Ferrero said.

Mr Fujimori was elected to an unprecedented third five-year term in voting that ended with a second round in May. His opponent in the runoff, Alejandro Toledo, dropped out because of allegations of vote-fixing.

Mr Fujimori's victory brought strong criticism from the US and other countries, and isolated Peru from its South American neighbours.

He had appeared to have survived the storm until the video was released on Thursday, apparently showing Vladimiro Montesinos, his closest advisor, offering cash to opposition Congressman Alberto Kouri for his support of the government.

Hours before Mr Fujimori's announcement, the Organisation of American States issued a demand that he suspend Mr Montesinos and other officials linked to the scandal. In recent months, Mr Montesinos has been accused of illicit enrichment and of engineering smear campaigns against Mr Fujimori's opponents in this year's presidential elections.

During his rule, Mr Fujimori has successfully combated a bloody leftist insurgency and tamed hyperinflation.

"I have governed Peru for the last 10 years. Not even my detractors would fail to recognise fundamental achievements which I will not enumerate. You know what they are.


A decade of Fujimori:

1990 Wins presidential election. A political unknown until weeks before the vote, Fujimori surprisingly defeats author Mario Vargas Llosa.

1992 Dissolves Congress and seizes authoritarian powers. Argues that move is necessary to defeat leftwing rebel group Shining Path.

1993 Introduces rewritten constitution.

1995 Elected for second presidential term. Congress dominated by his supporters.

2000 April Receives 49.9% of vote in first round of presidential election, forcing a run-off against opposition candidate Alejandro Toledo.

May Toledo withdraws from race, alleging corruption, handing Fujimori his third term in office.

July Huge demonstrations in Lima against Fujimori s inauguration.

September Video of Fujimori s top advisor allegedly bribing an opposition congressman scandalises Peru. Fujimori says he will call new elections and will not be a candidate.

webTitle: BA pilot sacked after 'air rage' incident

fields.headline: BA pilot sacked after 'air rage' incident
fields.trailText: A British Airways captain has been sacked after being firm with a disruptive passenger who wrongly accused another passenger of having a bomb on board.
fields.body:
A British Airways captain has been sacked after being firm with a disruptive passenger who wrongly accused another passenger of having a bomb on board.

Captain Stuart Clapson, 52, who has 30 years' experience, was dismissed after an incident this year in which he ordered a woman from a jumbo jet while waiting to take off for Barbados from Gatwick.

Captain Clapson's union, the British Airline Pilots' Association, said last night that the woman had insisted that the man in front of her had a bomb in his case. No bomb was found, and the woman became "increasingly disruptive, distressing other passengers".

The cabin crew tried to calm her, but the disruption grew worse. The crew advised Captain Clapson that take-off should be abandoned, and he took the plane back to the stand. He then tried but failed to reason with the woman.

He ordered her off the plane, having called the police. The aircraft took off without her.

Balpa said no complaint was received from the other passengers, but BA managers ruled that Captain Clapson had been "rude and abusive". He was initially demoted, but when Balpa took up his case he was dismissed.

Mike Sparham, Balpa's assistant general secretary, said: "Captain Clapson had to be firm with the passenger. He needed to act to discover that her accusations were groundless and to calm the situation. He did his best for the company and for the passengers. BA should be supporting him, not sacking him.

"We are deeply concerned at the way the appeals procedure is being ignored. If you appeal, your punishment will be increased. We can't have that."

This is the first time that a pilot has been dismissed for acting to curb an "air rage" incident. Balpa has referred the issue to an employment tribunal, which is to hear the case this week.

BA last night confirmed that an incident had taken place but said it could not comment further because it might prejudice the tribunal's findings.

webTitle: Philippine army says rebels are fleeing

fields.headline: Philippine army says rebels are fleeing
fields.trailText: The Philippine army's fierce attack on Muslim separatist guerrillas on the southern island of Jolo continued for a second day yesterday but there was no word of the fate of the 19 hostages, including six foreigners, the rebels are holding.
fields.body:
The Philippine army's fierce attack on Muslim separatist guerrillas on the southern island of Jolo continued for a second day yesterday but there was no word of the fate of the 19 hostages, including six foreigners, the rebels are holding.

The army chief of staff, General Angelo Reyes, said that - contrary to reports on Saturday that many of the captives had been killed - he believed they were still alive and well.

But he admitted that his troops were making slow progress against the Abu Sayyaf rebels and added that the operation, which was ordered by President Joseph Estrada in the early hours of Saturday, might last a week.

"All the hostages, based on reports, are alive," he said in Zamboanga City, the headquarters for the assault, after briefing Mr Estrada and members of his cabinet who had flown from Manila, 600 miles to the north.

"There have been no reports from the field to indicate that any have been casualties."

Gen Reyes said six rebels were killed and 20 captured. Four soldiers were wounded. His officers had told him that the gang members were in "escape mode".

"The fact is that [the rebels] are fleeing and they have not left any hostages as casualties."

President Estrada ordered the attack after successive kidnappings in the past five months by the Abu Sayyaf group, whose members style themselves Islamic fighters but seem chiefly interested in making ransom money.

Their hostages are 13 Filipinos, three Malaysians, a US citizen and two French television journalists.

Another military source was reported as saying that the army was not attacking camps where it believed the hostages might be.

"We are being very precise in our target selection. If we just bomb the place to pieces we would definitely kill the hostages. We don't want that; their safety is our main concern, " the officer said.

The official version of events cannot be corroborated because Jolo has been cut off.

webTitle: War of words puts ceasefire in doubt

fields.headline: War of words puts ceasefire in doubt
fields.trailText: A propaganda war over the internment of Ethiopian citizens in Eritrea is threatening to revive the conflict in the Horn of Africa. As more than 500,000 troops maintaining the 10th ceasefire between the two countries, the Ethiopian prime minister, Meles Zenawi, is accusing Eritrea of holding 30,000 Ethiopians in slave labour camps.

In response to his accusation, the Guardian was allowed to go to Ala camp, where 2,500 Ethiopian civilian men have been interned since a civilian repatriation agreement between the two countries broke down in July.

It is a miserable place, a rocky, sun-roasted hillside half an hour's walk from the only trickle of water for miles; but the rations are the same as those given to war-displaced Eritreans, the internees seem on friendly terms with their guards, and there is no labour of any kind.

The Eritrean government says that 14,000 of its 80,000 Ethiopian residents were interned after Ethiopia's incursion into the country in May, in order, it says, to protect them from an irate population.

There are no walls round the camp and only a handful of guards: it is 30 miles of semi-desert from the nearest road, and a forbidding place to run from.

The camp offers almost no protection against the scorching sun and chilly nights. Plastic sheeting was brought in by the Red Cross last week after most of the internees had spent more than three months seeking shade under miserable cactus shelters and huddling together in their sleep.

"When can we leave this place?" Getachew Tecle asked me. "There is no medicine and many people have sunstroke and diarrhoea. I am frightened that when the malaria season comes next month many of us could die."

Mr Tecle, 26, a telephone engineer, was born in Eritrea and has an Eritrean wife and child. He has never been to Ethiopia.

But now, he said:"If I can't be free in Eritrea I will go to Ethiopia.

"I cannot return to my wife after this."

Fisshaye Massa Tesfu, on the other hand, wants only to see his family again. He found himself trapped on the wrong side on the way home from his seminary in Asmara.

"The food is sufficient," he said. "We have five pieces of bread, two cups of beans and a cup of oil each per day. But my parents are old and do not know where I am. I am terrified that they think I am dead."

The internment issue became contentious in part because the International Committee of the Red Cross (ICRC) was given access to the camps when Eritrea signed the Geneva convention on July 29.

John-Paul Jacquod, head of the ICRC delegation in Asmara, said: "There are two Ethiopian internment camps in Eritrea and we have full access to them both.

"Eritrea's signing of the convention was an important historical step which is allowing the ICRC to carry out its responsibilities."

He believed that Eritrea was reluctant to give access to the camps in part because, at a time when more than a million of its people were displaced by the Ethiopian offensive, it was unable to provide the basic food and shelter international law demands.

"The ICRC can understand that it may be difficult for a government to provide internees with food and shelter that are unavailable to its own displaced nationals, but it must realise that these are things which we will supply," he said.

The ICRC's presence should reassure the international community and deflate some of the propaganda coming from both sides of the conflict - the Eritrean president, Issais Afworki, accuses Ethiopia of "detaining and torturing thousands of innocent Eritrean civilians in concentration camps in Ethiopia".

But the issue will linger on until both governments agree to resume the repatriation programme.

As the UN's first military ob servers are deployed along the 600-mile frontline, resuming repatriation would be a big boost to the peace process.

The continuing accusations about the internment camps looks to many analysts like a possible pretext for war.

webTitle: International news in brief

fields.headline: In brief
fields.trailText: Iran's leader sacks hardliner
fields.body:
Iran's leader sacks hardliner

Iran's supreme leader, Ayatollah Ali Khamenei, yesterday sacked a hardline security police chief who is involved in a court case that has convicted some of his subordinates of torture.

The official news agency, Irna, said Mr Khamenei had ordered the removal of Brigadier-General Mohammad Reza Naqdi, an Islamic hardliner, who has been a controversial figure known for his acerbic attacks on reformers allied with President Mohammad Khatami.
Reuters, Tehran 13 separatists die in Kashmir

Indian security forces have shot dead 13 separatist guerrillas in a series of gun battles in Kashmir since Saturday, police said yesterday. Ten militants were killed in Poonch district, 300 miles south-west of the capital, Srinagar, and three separatists were killed on Saturday evening in gun battles with Indian forces in the region.
Reuters, Srinagar

Videos not quite chocolate box
Videos tucked inside promotional chocolate boxes offered by a popular retail store in UAE contained pornography, not the cartoons parents were expecting, newspapers reported.

"After we enjoyed the chocolate, my children sat down to watch the video. But instead of the cartoon show, it was a disaster," a reader said in a letter.

The father said he rushed to turn off the video player when he realised it was showing "obscene scenes that encouraged homosexuality". The newspapers said that Dubai police had seized some 400 tapes.
Reuters, Dubai

webTitle: Suu Kyi to draw up new Burmese constitution

fields.headline: Suu Kyi to draw up new Burmese constitution
fields.trailText: The Burmese National League for Democracy announced yesterday that it is to risk its future by drafting a new constitution for the country, in defiance of the military junta.
fields.body:
The Burmese National League for Democracy announced yesterday that it is to risk its future by drafting a new constitution for the country, in defiance of the military junta.

The NDL's decision, taken at a meeting of 200 members on Saturday, comes as the authorities increase the pressure on the party and its leader, Aung San Suu Kyi.

A former party member wrote in a government-backed newspaper yesterday that the party should be dissolved immediately before it and Ms Suu Kyi "get too daring".

At the meeting, held to commemorate the second anniversary of the NLD's proxy parliament, delegates agreed to ask a committee to draw up a new constitution.

The parliament was formed for those who won seats in the 1990 general election. The NLD won th election by a landslide, but has never been allowed to govern.

The meeting called on the military authorities to convene a parliament immediately and release all Burma's political prisoners. Many of the people who won seats in 1990 are detained.

Burma's generals seized power in 1962. The current junta annulled the constitution when it took control in 1998. Four years ago it passed a law stipulating the imprisonment of anyone attempting to write a new constitution, and the banning of his or her organisation.

The NLD decision was taken two days after Ms Suu Kyi, who won the Nobel Peace Prize in 1991, and eight party colleagues were released from two weeks' house arrest.

They were restrained after Ms Suu Kyi and several party members were forcibly returned to the capital, Rangoon, after a nine-day stand-off with the authorities on a road out of the city.

They had been trying to go to a party meeting in the provinces.

Senior party members said that 11 more members had been placed under house arrest on Friday, a sign that the government is not going to ease its oppression of democratic forces.

This was confirmed yesterday when the newspaper Myanma Ahlin printed an attack on the NLD by one of its former members, Hla Soe.

"There is almost no political party in Myanmar [the generals' name for Burma] history which is as mean and evil as the NLD and Suu Kyi," he wrote. "The government has tolerated the NLD for so many years, but it is time the party is completely eliminated."

He added: "It is time the government takes care of the problem according to the law. If the problem is taken lightly, the Americans, the British and Suu Kyi will become more daring and the country will suffer more."

webTitle: Ugly Betty woos Colombian viewers night after night

fields.headline: Ugly Betty woos Colombian viewers night after night
fields.trailText: She has greasy hair, horn-rimmed glasses and braces on her teeth, but throughout Latin America, Beatriz Pinzon is the undisputed queen of prime-time television.
fields.body:
She has greasy hair, horn-rimmed glasses and braces on her teeth, but throughout Latin America, Beatriz Pinzon is the undisputed queen of prime-time television.

The protagonist of the Colombian soap opera, I am Betty, The Ugly One, is an unlikely heroine in a culture obsessed with Barbie-like beauty queens.

But the story of the dowdy secretary who outsmarts her superiors and rescues her boss from bankruptcy has become a Latin TV phenomenon.

Every night some 28m Colombians - 70% of the population - tune in to the show, which also dominates ratings in Mexico, Chile, Peru, Ecuador, Panama, El Salvador, the Dominican Republic, El Salvador, and on Spanish-language TV in the US.

In Colombia, each twist in the storyline makes front-page news. In Ecuador last month, Congress members suspended a late-night debate for half an hour to watch the programme.

The show's success seems at odds with its simple premise: a comic story about an over-qualified yet unprepossessing secretary who loses in love, but makes a fortune on the stock market.

But where most telenovelas depict aspirational fantasies about the rich and famous, I am Betty, The Ugly One reflects the reality of Latin America's growing urban middle classes.

"Normally, the heroine is a blonde babe. She's beautiful and rolling in money, or she's a poor orphan but she discovers that she's been left a fortune by her mother. Betty is like an ordinary person - she works in an office just like mine," said secretary Gitsy Martinez, a fan.

In a society which fractures along social and ethnic lines, the story taps a nerve, said Betty's creator, Fernando Gaitan. "The poor in Latin America have Indian features, while the rich look more like Europeans. The rich are considered beautiful but the poor are ugly and rejected."

The plot centres on an ailing fashion house, which is rescued from the liquidators by the efforts of Betty.

"Latin American soaps are all about the class struggle. They're made for poor people in countries where it's hard to get ahead in life. Usually the characters succeed through love. In mine they get ahead through work," said Mr Gaitan.

None of which quite explains why the producers chose a beautiful actress to portray Betty. Make-up artists spend at least 40 minutes each day making Ana Maria Orozco sufficiently plain for her part.

"We had to have a good-looking woman playing The Ugly One, because only she could show what it's like to be ugly. Somebody who's born like that would be too close to her own character. And besides, she had to be pretty, just in case Betty gets a makeover at the end of the series," said Mr Gaitan.

"All soaps are fairy tales - this one is a cross between Cinderella and the Ugly Duckling," said director Mario Ribero.

webTitle: Airboards trailblaze new craze

fields.headline: Airboards trailblaze new craze
fields.trailText: Fold away your little silver scooter, the hot new toy on the block is the airboard, as seen skimming around Stadium Australia during the Olympic Games opening ceremony.
fields.body:
Fold away your little silver scooter, the hot new toy on the block is the airboard, as seen skimming around Stadium Australia during the Olympic Games opening ceremony.

The personal hovercraft's petrol engine propels its rider along 10cm above the pavement at up to 15mph and its Australian inventor, Kevin Inkster, said last night that it could be in Sydney's shops by Christmas.

While it enthralled the billions watching the Olympic ceremony on television, at A$13,500 (£5,300) it is likely to be only the wealthiest kidults - that growing demographic group of adults who refuse to abandon childhood - who treat themselves to a new way of getting to work.

But Mr Inkster prophesied that his "totally new and exciting kind of vehicle" would give rise to a new sport.

He said he was driven to design it by his disappointment that the contemporary world had failed to realise so many of the sci-fi dreams of his infancy.

webTitle: Crossing the last bridge

fields.headline: Crossing the last bridge
fields.standfirst: Selma, Alabama, focus of much attention during civil-rights marches in 1965, has finally elected a black mayor.
fields.trailText: Selma, Alabama, focus of much attention during civil-rights marches in 1965, has finally elected a black mayor.
fields.body:
Lannie's Bar-B-Q Spot in Selma is said to serve the finest ribs this side of the Alabama river and it is a pleasure to discover finally what the phrase "finger-lickin' good" really means. Lannie's occupies a strange place in the history of the civil-rights movement. It was the favoured eating place of both the marchers who descended on this small Alabama town in 1965 as part of the long battle for voting rights for all and of the local police force who, with the state troopers and the National Guard, also found themselves needing to refuel during the long stand-offs.

But over the past few days in Lannie's the talk has been of another historic occasion, the election of the city's first black mayor, James Perkins Jr. Now the city where black and white marchers were clubbed and teargassed by sneering state troopers has a black mayor and a black chief of police. No wonder there were celebrations in the streets this week and the mood on both sides of the counter in Lannie's was so cheery. Joe Smitherman, the man who was mayor all those years ago and had remained in office ever since, has gone.

Perkins's slogan was "one more river to cross" which could hardly have been more apposite. It was on the Pettus bridge over the muddy Alabama river that the marchers faced down the state troopers in 1965 and the bridge has become symbolic of the attempts to move on beyond the days of segregation.

The church still plays a large part in politics in the south. It was, of course, a reverend - Dr Martin Luther King - who led the final march from Selma to Montgomery after the first bloody clashes. It was another reverend, Fred Shuttlesworth, one of the unsung heroes of those days, who, the night before this week's election, addressed the congregation in the same Tabernacle Baptist church where the marchers rallied 35 years earlier. The nearby Brown chapel acted as a command post for the marchers. The man who was fatally beaten by white racists near the Silver Moon cafe in Selma was James Reeb, a Unitarian minister from Boston.

God was asked repeatedly for his blessing on the Perkins campaign. Smitherman, for his part, was described by one of his (black) supporters as a "God-fearing man" as though there could be no higher praise. The victory was greeted by Perkins's supporters with cries of "Glory, Hallelujah!"

Much segregation remains, despite all the blood shed to fight it. "They go to their bars, we go to ours," said Sam Walker, a black activist. "The only public school is now 95% black. Integration was never achieved. Segregation is still there."

Joanne Bland works at the Voting Rights Museum she helped to found on the premises of the former White Citizens' Council, to which Smitherman belonged. She said segregation remained in housing and business. "Food, hair and death" - grocery stores, hairdressing salons and funeral parlours - were the only real black businesses in what has become a reasonably prosperous area.

Selma was the last of some 10 cities in the area to elect a black mayor, so it has been a historic few days for the residents. Thirty-five years ago it was the likes of Harry Belafonte, Johnny Mathis, Sammy Davis Jr, and Joan Baez who entertained and supported the marchers. This time around, the visitors have included Queen Latifah, Sean Penn, Martin Luther King III and local hip-hop stars.

So that final river has been crossed. This week a native of Selma is likely to be in the news again. Mia Hamm is a star of the US women's soccer team, favourites to win gold in Sydney. She is white and her godfather is black. Which of those brave souls who stood on the bridge in 1965 believed that one day Selma's citizens would be glued to their TVs in a city run by a black mayor, a black city clerk and a black police chief cheering on a white woman playing a strange game in a foreign country?

webTitle: Gossip about the gossipers

fields.headline: Tatler to tittle-tattle.com
fields.standfirst:
Everyone loves to gossip, right? Even PeopleNews.com, a new website for celebrity gossip, has been on the receiving end. Well, those that live by the sword die by the sword

Special report: Net News
fields.trailText: Everyone loves to gossip, right? Even PeopleNews.com, a new website for celebrity gossip, has been on the receiving end. Well, those that live by the sword die by the sword
fields.body:
If ever you need convincing that a quiet gossip is just a bit of fun, a glance at Jane Procter's career should tell you all you need to know. After her abrupt departure from the Cond* Nast group, the former editor of Tatler not only fell victim to that old "did-she-jump-or-was-she-pushed?" whispering campaign, but also suffered a series of articles documenting her abrasive professional style, including one so harsh it prompted her to take legal action against the Mail on Sunday.

It would be enough to make any high-profile editor skulk in the shadows before contemplating her next move. But not Proctor. She turned around and gave the chatterboxes something to talk about by masterminding a website largely dedicated to - you guessed it - gossiping. Procter is now editorial director of PeopleNews.com, a project that also has the support of ex-Sunday Times editor Andrew Neil and goes live on the web today.

Celebrity gossip is the shorthand description, but the behind-the-scenes brains will have you know it's more that that. There's gossip, news, views, pictures, lists and games. There's information on how to achieve that look, make that meal, buy that dress. And there are parties. Lots of parties. Last night's parties, parties of the year, last week in London, this week with Vivienne Westwood and all the juice about Herm*s at Shoreditch.

A visit to their offices is enough to confirm that this is the most well-connected website staff on the net. As soon as I arrive, in walks Simon Walker, director of business development, grumbling about the sudden outburst of rain: "Just my luck the weather turns now. I'm supposed to be going to a party at Babington House in the country tonight."

With Procter at its helm and all this socialising documented between its walls, it is tempting to label PeopleNews.com as the online Tatler. Catherine Ostler, UK editor of the site, also had a stint at the magazine, but is keen to ensure this new project is not seen as society gossip going cyber. "Everyone knows it would be suicidal to go down that route on the net," says Ostler. "We're absolutely not for the old-fashioned Tatler and Harpers & Queen-type people. These parties aren't Lord and Lady Posh. They're people on telly and we all want to know what they're up to." Walker will have you believe that with our insatiable desire for gossip, PeopleNews.com is onto a winner. "We're creating a new genre," he says, boldly, "the genre of people news. This is the really interesting media story of our time, the fact that people just love this kind of stuff. We reckon that with all the TV, magazines, newspapers and chatting, people spend over an hour a day doing stuff that is people news. It's gossip, it's people-based lifestyle news, it's entertainment news and it's fun."

So far, so non-society. But aren't we now venturing into the realms of tabloid journalism, with all this talk of who wore what where? "All the newspapers are putting those sorts of things on front pages now," says Walker, "they used to be diary columns at the back but now they're all over the cover of the Daily Telegraph." Yet this is no broadsheet dumb-down exercise either. The People News brand is a specific one: avoiding the hagiography of Hello! and OK!, whilst sidestepping the "people are cannon-fodder" attitude of the tabloid world. "We'll have a sort of meritocratic coverage. Society magazines are elite in the wrong way. We're elitist in that we want the best people on our site. For example, we'll be working with Julian MacDonald around fashion week. He's a PeopleNews person. Totally on-brand."

What is and what isn't "on-brand" for PeopleNews is fundamental to the success of the site. Not only is the class of the content essential for attracting the right audience, but it also holds the financial key to the entire project. Walker argues there is a whole group of advertisers out there who have yet to get started on the net because they can't find the right site to spend their money on. "These people don't want banner buys on Yahoo! They've been coming to us saying 'Thank God you've started this. We know we have to get involved with the internet but we couldn't find anywhere we wanted to do it!"

Rather than clumps of different advertising, the intention is to have different luxury brands, boutiques or high-quality department stores sponsor specific areas of the PeopleNews site. Put like that it all sounds so simple: Step 1: Find the advertising loophole. Step 2: Fill it. Step 3: Sit back and watch the money roll in. But the brief history of the internet will tell you that this get-rich-quick attitude to the web is not as easy as it sounds. Walker assures me that those at PeopleNews don't care: it was the excitement not the money that enticed them there.

It's a familiar tune to hear from start-up staff, but it's easier to give credence to it when the majority of the 20-odd editorial staff left jobs on national newspapers and magazines. "There are a lot of old media people here with new media experience who want to build an audience and engage with consumers. Were we nervous to leave established companies? We'd be mad not to be. But this is what we all wanted to do." Whether Procter's fierce reputation added to those first day nerves is something her former colleagues are sure to start speculating. But as documented as that temper was, it didn't deter Walker from accepting his position, even though he admits "doing a bit of research into all the people involved" beforehand.

A further 18 of the 40-odd PeopleNews staff had also worked with Procter before, which Ostler insists "tells you all you need to know" about Procter's office ambience. "I don't think she would have been subject to that if she hadn't been editor of Tatler. I mean, it suits everybody to gossip about a gossip magazine." Procter's libel trial against the Mail On Sunday is proof that the rumour-mongering felt more like acid on bare skin than water off a duck's back. Yet with PeopleNews she is apparently willing to inflict that pain on others.

Not so, says Ostler, who insists that kind of "bitchiness" is not what PeopleNews is aiming for. "That's the classic example of a story that interests journalists more than Joe Bloggs on the street. I don't think most people give a monkey's about the editor of glossy magazine that sells 80,000 copies. It's not a story. Who cares?"

Of course, those audacious blabbermouths won't be put to bed so easily. Already they've been at work, spreading the word that a rift has sprung up between Neil and Procter and their working relationship is in tatters as a result. Neil has come out from behind his non-executive chairman seat to deny the rumour - "I have been working in complete harmony with her and her very talented team" - but it is unlikely to do much good. As the site goes live, Procter is destined to set tongues wagging again. The real question is whether this time it will be gossip she actually wants people to hear.

webTitle: City revisit the bad old days

fields.headline: City revisit the bad old days
fields.standfirst: Maine Road stalemate puts emphasis on the stale
fields.trailText: Man City 1 - 1 Middlesbrough
fields.body:
Second Division football returned to Maine Road yesterday, only this time with two Premiership teams involved.

Between them Manchester City and Middlesbrough created the type of thud-and-blunder that must have been seen on craggy park pitches all over the country yesterday.

Both emerged from the scrum with a point after a goal apiece in the second half, Gianluca Festa putting Middlesbrough ahead in the 55th minute and Paulo Wanchope equalising with his fourth of the season.

But such was the impoverished standard of the football that Sky might well brace itself for a flurry of cancelled subscriptions this morning. The first half, in particular, was a wretched affair, degenerating so drastically that a pot-bellied City fan took it on himself to liven up proceedings by wobbling on to the pitch and performing a strange kind of rain dance. As he was led away by fluorescent-jacketed officials, it was tempting to believe he had wanted to be thrown out.

Thankfully, the temptation to reach for the anti-depressants dissipated after the break with two goals in the space of 12 minutes.

City have yet to keep a clean sheet this season and when Middlesbrough took the lead it was as straightforward as they come, Andy Campbell swinging a corner into a congested penalty area and Festa stealing ahead of Wanchope to beat the goalkeeper Nicky Weaver with a stooping header.

Wanchope made amends when he stretched out a telescopic leg to meet Danny Tiatto's flick and prod the ball beyond Middlesbrough's on-loan goalkeeper Gary Walsh. But even that was aided and abetted by a visiting player, the opportunity stemming from a free-kick that the referee Stephen Lodge had moved 10 yards forward because of Hamilton Ricard's protests.

"Hamilton opened his mouth when he shouldn't have done," said Viv Anderson, Boro's assistant manager. "It was his own fault and he was told so after the game." Had Ricard apologised? "He didn't get the chance. The fine for dissent has gone up considerably already in Bryan's eyes after that. He'll lose his draw bonus and a lot more."

Thereafter, City began for the first time to play somewhere near their capabilities, George Weah having a header tipped over by Walsh and Jeff Whitley ramming a snap-shot against the angle of post and crossbar. But their attacking forays were born from perspiration rather than inspiration. "I'm not kidding myself it was the prettiest game," said the City manager Joe Royle.

"The first half was a total non-event. I suspect there were people asleep at the interval, but we improved as the game went on and on the overall balance we should have won. Our goalkeeper hasn't had a shot to save but c'est la vie ."

There is a fair bit of history between these sides and some sparks of indiscipline livened up the more dreary fare. Wanchope was fortunate to avoid a red card after slapping Jason Gavin round the back of his head, before Middlesbrough's Colin Cooper took his own retribution by halting the Costa Rican with what would be classed in rugby as a high tackle.

For both incidents Lodge needed to consult his linesman, though they were not the only occasions that the referee failed to keep up with play. Royle was aggrieved that City had not won a penalty when Cooper impeded Weah late in the first half, although his argument that Tiatto should also have been awarded a spot-kick from Gavin's challenge carried less weight.

Deprived of the services of Alen Boksic and Christian Karembeu, not to mention their three first-choice goalkeepers, Middlesbrough had at least the vague semblance of an excuse for their feeble efforts.

"We had a lot of injuries so I suppose you could say this was a good result," observed the midfielder Paul Ince. A good result, maybe, but an alehouse team's performance.

webTitle: Rangers ride their luck to break Hearts

fields.headline: Rangers ride their luck to break Hearts
fields.standfirst: Putting Europe on hold, Rangers' still to find their rhythm at home
fields.trailText: Rangers 1 - 0 Hearts
fields.body:
Rangers, supposedly the untouchables, needed these points after skittish behaviour in the Premier League. Last Wednesday the Ibrox machine crushed Sturm Graz in the Champions League, but domestically Rangers have lurched like an old tractor. This was their first league win in three attempts.

Only now are the stakes truly becoming high for Dick Advocaat's side. On Wednesday they travel to Monaco in their second Champions League match, a night which will measure their mettle in the bigger environment. Advocaat will already be plotting.

Poor Antti Niemi, the brave and agile Hearts goalkeeper, must wonder what he could have done to keep them out. He made a series of blocks and catches only to see Rangers score from a rebound after yet another fine save. It did not require someone of Ronald de Boer's calibre to score from five yards.

One had some sympathy for Hearts. They turned up at Ibrox with all the eagerness of errant schoolboys arriving for the cane. Having pulled off late-night heroics in Germany on Thursday, holding Stuttgart to 1-0 in the Uefa Cup, the Edinburgh club, claiming exhaustion, had requested the postponement of this match. Rangers haughtily said no.

The Hearts manager Jim Jefferies has received a few skelpings in this arena. Three years ago, in a farcical match, he watched as three of his players were red-carded. On at least two other occasions he has seen a point or points stolen in the dying seconds. He did not need this latest row to know that Ibrox is the cruellest place.

Even worse, the Hearts coffers seem to be perennially empty. When Jefferies won the Scottish Cup by beating Rangers in one of the Scottish game's great post-war achievements in 1998 he had needed at least one or two financial injections. This season all we've heard from Tynecastle, supposedly the home of one of Scotland's big clubs, is that monthly losses are killing the club.

In a typically gutsy performance, Hearts were made to rue their missed chances. In their first attack Gary McSwegan headed tamely at Stefan Klos, then Juanjo, their precocious Spanish youngster, dribbled this way and that past a posse of Rangers defenders before meekly allowing Klos to save again.

De Boer sealed it for Rangers in the 58th minute, prodding home the rebound after Billy Dodds' shot. Rangers savoured this test but real scrutiny awaits in three days' time.

webTitle: Round-up

fields.headline: Round-up
fields.trailText: Millwall reacted to Saturday's 1-1 draw at Brentford by sacking their joint managers Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary.
fields.body:
Millwall reacted to Saturday's 1-1 draw at Brentford by sacking their joint managers Keith Stevens and Alan McLeary.

A statement issued yesterday said: "The board were unanimous in the decision to dispense with their services. While acknowledging the progress made since their appointment in 1998, the board felt that they would not be able to meet the club's aspirations this season, which is considered to be a crucial one in the world of football."

Ray Harford takes over team affairs on an interim basis, with a permanent appointment to be made in due course. Millwall face Ipswich in the Worthington Cup tomorrow.

They are the latest club to experiment unsuccessfully with joint managers. Charlton, whose current manager Alan Curbishley originally shared the post with Steve Gritt, and Liverpool, who originally appointed Gérard Houllier to work with Roy Evans, both sacked one of the pair but found success with the other.

Fulham set a club record by winning their seventh successive league game at Nottingham Forest.

Goals from Louis Saha - his 10th already this season - Fabrice Fernandes and Barry Hayles condemned David Platt's side to a second home defeat.

"It's all down to Jean Tigana, there can be no argument about that," said the captain, Chris Coleman. "He has instilled belief and confidence in us. He has got us doing things on and off the pitch that I've never been asked to do before, and it's working. He's great to work for."

A 2-0 win over Portsmouth ensured that Bolton stay two points adrift in third, behind Watford only on goal difference. The goals came from Dean Holdsworth and Michael Ricketts.

Sheffield Wednesday 's miserable start to the season continued against Tranmere as two goals from Scott Taylor left them one off the bottom of the table. John Aldridge, whose team are now fifth, said: "It is nice to be in the top six but it is no good getting carried away.We missed a fair few chances but overall I am delighted with the result."

Huddersfield are the only side below Wednesday in the table, and their cause was not helped when they turned a 1-0 lead into a 2-1 defeat at promoted Gillingham .

In the Second Division, Walsall remain three points clear at the top despite a 1-1 home draw with Bournemouth , and in the Third Chesterfield maintained their lead by beating Mansfield 4-0, with two goals from Ryan Williams. Halifax remain bottom after a 1-0 home defeat by Southend .

webTitle: Nordic gods lost in Potteries derby

fields.headline: Nordic gods lost in Potteries derby
fields.trailText: Port Vale 1 - 1 Stoke City
fields.body:
All the relevant action in the first Potteries derby for three seasons was crammed into five hectic minutes in the first half.

Marc Bridge-Wilkinson raised home supporters' expectations when he headed in Matt Carragher's cross after 10 minutes. But five minutes later parity was restored when Kyle Lightbourne fired home the equaliser, though Stoke claimed a moral victory after Lightbourne and Marvin Robinson both hit the underside of the bar with headers in the second half.

It was bad luck for the City boss Gudjon Thordarson, who was denied a victory in his first English derby. The former national coach of Iceland, who took over last season, felt his side deserved to win.

According to Scandinavian superstition, Sunday should be a lucky day but on this occasion the Nordic gods failed to smile on Thordarson and he was left to wonder what he had done to upset them.

"It was nice to get a point but we should have had all three," he said. "They never outplayed us and we created the better chances. We needed that bit of luck in the second half and perhaps Robinson should have put his header away. But I always knew this was going to be a difficult game for us."

While admitting to being slightly disappointed with his players, Thordarson reserved all his venom for the referee William Burns. The Scarborough official showed Tony Naylor a yellow card after he appeared to raise his arm at Brynjar Gunnarsson.

"That was a red card offence," said Thordarson, "and the player should have gone off. We have to play from the same rule book and we can't tolerate things like that in the game. We are being asked to instil discipline into our teams and I'm trying to do that with my players. But referees are not consistent."

Stoke, after their slow start, were the better side but still needed Nicky Mohan to clear off the line from Dave Brammer in the second half.

Vale's manager Brian Horton said: "The fans will be happy with a draw; no one goes home disappointed. Bridge-Wilkinson was the pick of our players. He took his goal well and is going to be a very good player."

The game attracted the lowest ever Potteries derby attendance of 8,948 after police refused Stoke's request for more tickets.

We are being asked to instil discipline into our teams and I'm trying to do that with my players. But referees are not consistent." Stoke, after their slow start, were the better side but still needed Nicky Mohan to clear off the line from Dave Brammer in the second half. Vale's manager Brian Horton said: "The fans will be happy with a draw; no one goes home disappointed. Bridge-Wilkinson was the pick of our players. He took his goal well and is going to be a very good player." The game attracted the lowest ever Potteries derby attendance of 8,948 after police refused Stoke's request for more tickets.

webTitle: Clever Trevor gets his timing right

fields.headline: Clever Trevor gets his timing right
fields.trailText: West Brom 1 - 1 Birmingham City
fields.body:
The attritional nature of this very watchable second-city skirmish would surely have had some foreign footballing imports scurrying for the next EuroStar. Had they stayed, however, they would surely have appreciated the very European deployment of substitutes that helped rescue the second game in a row for City.

The introduction of Andrew Johnson in Tuesday's meeting with Preston resulted in City turning a 1-0 deficit into a 3-1 win. Yesterday it was the turn of a player with no apparent job security, Dele Adebola, to extricate them from another pickle after efforts from David Holdsworth, Peter Ndlovu and Martin O'Connor had all rattled the Albion woodwork.

Yet the transfer-listed striker should not have been within miles of the Hawthorns let alone on its pitch.

"There was no logical reason for Dele Adebola to be on the bench today," the City manager Trevor Francis said. "His recent performances in the reserves have not merited his inclusion.

"But the team has good memories of coming here. They have won the last two games easily and Dele played a big part in both. I guess it's part of the art of management to know when to bring players in."

Another case of clever Trevor then? Well, almost . . . The fact that only James Chambers of Albion's back three played in either of the two previous meetings is a minor detail.

Even so, Adebola's reputation obviously goes before him as his introduction in the 59th minute had the same effect as a fox released in a chicken coup. Within two minutes his barely challenged run across the front of the Albion 18-yard line resulted in a pass to Geoff Horsfield, the equaliser and an angry Gary Megson.

"I told my defenders the way to play Adebola is to force him on to his right foot but it didn't take them long to forget," the Albion manager lamented.

That forgetfulness could have been academic had Richard Sneekes and Taylor been more accurate with headers and added to the tally in a dominant opening half-hour.

Nevertheless, Megson was not displeased with the result. "They are among the favourites to get promotion and have been trying to achieve that for four years," he added.

"We're at the start of that process now so a draw is very encouraging."
