webTitle: Redknapp: you've never had it so good

fields.headline: Redknapp: you've never had it so good
fields.standfirst: Harry (and Houllier) happy with win-less Hammers
fields.trailText: West Ham 1 - 1 Liverpool
fields.body:
Harry Redknapp sounds like a man without a care in the world. He joyfully announces he has petrol in his car, bread and beans in the larder and the best West Ham team in 20 years. Unfortunately the only thing he cannot provide is what the fans want most: a win.

Despite this deserved point West Ham remain bottom of the Premiership without a victory. They dominated much of this match, yet it was as easy to see why they are struggling as it was to understand why Liverpool will not give Sir Alex Ferguson sleepless nights just yet.

A win would have brought Gérard Houllier's team to within a point of Manchester United. Instead, after taking the lead through Steven Gerrard, they succumbed to a Paolo di Canio equaliser from the penalty spot. Solid but unspectacular was the story of their afternoon.

West Ham belong at the other end of the spectrum. Redknapp can talk about the talent in his squad until he is blue in the face but until his team have the penetration to match their possession they will not realise their undoubted potential.

For all the fantasy Joe Cole and Di Canio provided, too often West Ham were guilty of over-elaboration and wastefulness. There is much to admire in their attacking philosophy but the substance does not match the style. They might benefit from being a little less clever and touch more direct.

In West Ham's defence, Liverpool were impressively organised. Criticised for shipping goals in recent weeks, Markus Babbel and Stéphane Henchoz provided a stern centre and were well supported by those around.

Not for the first time Redknapp heard from an opposing manager that West Ham's position is a travesty and a mystery. His team will surely not go down, but sooner or later results must turn as he promises. Having faced a tough start, the next three games against Coventry, Bradford and Ipswich look crucial. Not that Redknapp is worried.

"The character and the football is still first class," he said. "It's not the slightest concern to me. I have been in the job 20 years so I know when I have a good team. We keep creating chances and we will score.

"Gérard Houllier said 'How are you bottom when you play like that?' It's the same every game, and there's no shortage of confidence in this club, especially from me. This is the best team they have had here in 20 years since Devonshire and Brooking. And that will be proved, don't worry."

It was West Ham's good fortune that they faced a Liverpool side missing Michael Owen, who was feeling the back strain he picked up in Bucharest on Thursday, but should return at the weekend.

Without his pace and eye for goal, Liverpool created little. Emile Heskey never imposed himself alone up front and Shaka Hislop did not make a notable save all match, though Houllier was far from disheartened.

"It's a good result," he said. "We didn't play our best game but we looked more solid and that's one of my No1 priorities. On the break we could have played better football and finished better. We could have taken the initiative more."

Things had begun in fine fashion for Liverpool. Gerrard, who later limped off with what Houllier described as a minor injury, scored after 12 minutes, finishing impressively at the far post from Danny Murphy's cross after Nick Barmby had robbed Steve Lomas in midfield.

Yet that was to be Liverpool's only clear opportunity until Dietmar Hamann shot over from long range near the end. As hard as West Ham pressed they struggled to create good openings of their own.

However, their equaliser finally arrived in the 68th minute from a high Di Canio pass. Frédéric Kanouté seemed to have delayed his shot too long but was fouled by Henchoz with his back to goal and Di Canio easily converted before the game petered out.

"It's tough at the top," Redknapp remarked, "but it's even tougher at the bottom. We won't be there for long, mind." Upton Park will hope he is right.

webTitle: Frontmen tussle for attention at the Stadium of Light

fields.headline: Frontmen tussle for attention at the Stadium of Light
fields.standfirst: Malcolm Christie is hot on Phillips' heels
fields.trailText: Sunderland 2 - 1 Derby
fields.byline: John Wardle at the Stadium of Light
fields.body:
Sunderland's Kevin Phillips has successfully negotiated the difficult passage from non-league football into the England set-up. Now he must start looking over his shoulder. When he does so he will spot Derby's Malcolm Christie, accelerating along the same route at a speed which may soon place him among Phillips' international rivals.

If Phillips harboured any doubts about the eventual threat to his England status from the 21-year-old, they were banished by the way Christie unsettled Sunderland's defence with his quick feet and sure touch. One turn on the byline following a short corner was quite astonishing and evoked memories of how Phillips bemused so many Premiership defences when they first came across him.

Christie, who scored Derby's consolation goal, is still far from the finished article, as shown when he and Deon Burton were unable to apply the decisive final touch to their team's first-half pressure.

But manager Jim Smith said: "He's an exciting young prospect without a shadow of a doubt. Malcolm's always a threat because he's a natural goalscorer with pace. He has the ability to go all the way, although England are hardly short of strikers at the moment."

Phillips is still one of them, although he has yet to rediscover last season's form and the Wearside rumour factory will have you believe he would be happier at a club with genuine title ambitions. Even manager Peter Reid admits: "He has not been playing all that well. Kevin didn't have a pre-season because of injury, so imagine what he will do when he is fit again."

Better still, imagine what Phillips would do if Sunderland provided him with better openings than the handful generated by their policy of punting long balls in the direction of Niall Quinn's head.

They need to inject more variety into their approach work to test better teams than Derby, but at least Reid's team are out of a relegation position and believe they can build on this victory.

Reid said: "It's a massive result for us. "It has really raised the confidence levels."

webTitle: Charlton expose Graham's lack of ideas

fields.headline: Charlton expose Graham's lack of ideas
fields.standfirst: George's reign is plainly on the wane
fields.trailText: Charlton 1 - 0 Tottenham
fields.body:
Tottenham fans woke up this morning to discover that it was a dream after all. Two wins in a row, their team fifth in the table, only one point behind Manchester United. Another victory might have taken them top. George Graham's magic appeared to be working at last.

Alas, it was an illusion, a trip to the Valley confirming the size of the mountain Tottenham must climb to become true top-five contenders.

Graham's method had been forecast. He would turn Tottenham's side into a replica of his Arsenal team of the late 80s: functional but uninspired, the very dread of the White Hart Lane faithful.

Their palliative on his appointment was the promise of success. But on Saturday Spurs looked like a team caught in a time warp. They attacked with the free spirit of someone who paints by numbers, the flourish of invention conspicuous by its absence - or his absence, having been sold to Aston Villa.

That Tottenham still created enough chances to have won easily is a red herring. Their opponents were Charlton, a well meaning but limited side destined to struggle again this season despite moving up to eighth in the table with this win.

Invention is in at the moment. Indeed essential. But Graham appears not to have spotted that. He seems to think that because his ideas worked 10 years ago they should work now. Hence the diet of hard work, organisation and long balls into the box, hoping for knockdowns. But the world has moved on.

With David Ginola gone and Darren Anderton injured again, Tottenham's ideas cupboard looked as understocked as a supermarket shelf during the fuel crisis. A midfield quartet of Steffen Freund, Tim Sherwood, Oyvind Leonhardsen and Steffen Iversen, pushed forward as a third striker, says it all.

Even in defence, Graham's reputation as a solid bricklayer is threatening to crumble. Neil Sullivan, Mauricio Taricco, Chris Perry and Ben Thatcher have all been signed. But the number of times that Charlton were waved through on Saturday, and West Ham last Monday, suggests a suitable case for the local buildings inspector.

In the end Charlton won thanks to a combination of luck, an indefatigable team spirit, poor Spurs finishing and a series of crucial saves from Dean Kiely.

Oh, and their goal. Paul Konchesky played a forward pass to Graham Stuart. Ramon Vega, marking Jonatan Johansson, pushed up anticipating a Stuart flick-on which would have left Johansson offside. But Stuart let the ball run, Johansson was well onside, ran at goal and calmly slotted the ball through Sullivan's legs.

Spurs were totally deceived. Their fans are beginning to recognise the feeling.

webTitle: Hornets sting as Sodje blunders

fields.headline: Hornets sting as Sodje blunders
fields.trailText: Watford 3 - 0 Crewe
fields.body:
Watford have of late been rewarding their fans' loyalty with gifts - in recent weeks they have been met at the turnstiles with fridge magnets and all sorts of stickers. Crewe obviously picked up on this spirit of generosity, as little else could explain the three goals they gave away on Saturday.

Dario Gradi's side, still goalless and pointless on their league travels, looked good in possession but, with Peter Smith alone up front, created little. When David Wright's early header did threaten Watford's goal Espen Baardsen, who was later withdrawn with an ankle injury, reacted superbly to turn the ball away.

"We weren't, in the end, good enough to beat Watford but we might have done," said Gradi. "It wasn't as though we weren't in with a chance at any stage of the game. In fact, we were in with a chance at every stage of the game until they scored their third goal."

Had Crewe really wanted to score, they should have pushed Efe Sodje up front. The Nigerian international defender had a hand in all of Watford's goals, and would have scored one of them himself had Gifton Noel-Williams not been on hand to spare his blushes.

In the 21st minute Tommy Mooney beat him to Neil Cox's free-kick, setting up Noel-Williams for a header that Jason Kearton reacted well to tip over. From the corner the ball fell again to Mooney, whose centre was turned in by Tommy Smith. No prizes for guessing was supposed to be marking him.

It is impossible to know what was going through Sodje's mind as he reacted to Smith's 57th-minute cross. He chested the ball towards his own net but, just as it seemed that he was to get the own-goal his performance deserved, Noel-Williams arrived to steal the credit.

Sodje capped a nightmare display with another assist in the 89th minute, when his headed clearance travelled approximately four yards before falling at the feet of Micah Hyde, who struck the ball sweetly into the top corner.

"You can't complain with 3-0," said Graham Taylor. "I think we won easily and I don't mean to be disrespectful to Crewe. Last season was hard for all of us but we've learned from it and I think some of our play this year has been very good." It always helps, though, when the opposition are as generous as Crewe.

webTitle: Chelsea continue decline and fall

fields.headline: Chelsea continue decline and fall
fields.standfirst: Ranieri handed the pieces after brittle Chelsea are outfoxed
fields.trailText: Chelsea 0 - 2 Leicester City
fields.body:
Whether or not Chelsea are about to be managed by the greatest Roman of them all will only be discovered when Claudio Ranieri takes charge of them for Saturday's visit to Manchester United. All that can be said for the moment is that to judge from yesterday's home defeat by Leicester City the spirit at the club owes more to Edward Gibbon, who knew a Latin decline when he saw one.

Even if Gianluca Vialli had not been sacked as Chelsea manager last Tuesday it was always going to be a bad time for Chelsea to encounter Leicester, who under Peter Taylor have retained the passionate approach of Martin O'Neill and found fresh enterprise besides.

Once Muzzy Izzet had nodded them in front after eight minutes Leicester's swift,simple hard-working approach dominated the match. For a time in the second half Chelsea discovered a greater sense of urgency, but their recovery fell away once Jimmy Floyd Hasselbaink had headed against the bar, whereupon Stan Collymore came off the bench to complete Leicester's first league victory at Stamford Bridge since 1965, a win which has brought them level on points with Manchester United at the top of the Premier League.

Chelsea are now last but three and the reaction of their supporters, who three nights earlier had voiced their initial disapproval of Vialli's abrupt departure, was predictable. Frank Leboeuf was not around to be booed - he had a stomach strain, a gut reaction perhaps - but the generally listless approach of the team still had the fans chanting the name of Vialli.

Ranieri watched the game from the directors' box. According to Ray Wilkins, left in joint charge of the side along with Graham Rix, he was not displeased with what he saw. This seemed unlikely but was, on second thoughts, a logical reaction. After yesterday, under Ranieri, Chelsea can only get better.

Certainly the new man is an optimist. "Mr Ranieri popped in before the game and explained how he liked the team to perform," said Wilkins," that is with the maximum spirit and to give 150 per cent effort every time they step on to a football field."

Presumably something was lost in translation. Ranieri got what he wanted all right - but from Leicester rather than Chelsea, who were inclined to argue among themselves.

Throughout the game Taylor's five-man midfield worked assiduously to exploit the advantage in numbers that the opposition's decision to use Gianfranco Zola between a middle three and a front two provided.

Izzet and Neil Lennon remain one of the most consistent midfield partnerships in the Premier League and were solidly supported by Robbie Savage. His pass led to Leicester's early goal. Lennon, found in space on the right, provided the centre from which Izzet, timing his run astutely, surprised the Chelsea defence as he headed past the keeper Carlo Cudicini.

Leicester always did the simple things well, Chelsea even complicated throw-ins, but had Hasselbaink's header from Graeme Le Saux's cross been a fraction lower the scores would have been level after 65 minutes.

With eight minutes remaining Collymore, who had replaced Darren Eadie, nipped in to drive Leicester's second goal past Cudicini from Guppy's cross.

"Mr Ranieri felt that from what he saw today there was something he could work with" said Wilkins. "I think he'll kick a few backsides but only in a very pleasant manner."

Just now, though, Chelsea would appear to need a touch of Julius Caesar, not Syd Caesar.

Leicester always did the simple things well, Chelsea even complicated throw-ins, but had Hasselbaink's header from Graeme Le Saux's cross been a fraction lower the scores would have been level after 65 minutes. With eight minutes remaining Collymore, who had replaced Darren Eadie, nipped in to drive Leicester's second goal past Cudicini from Guppy's cross. "Mr Ranieri felt that from what he saw today there was something he could work with" said Wilkins. "I think he'll kick a few backsides but only in a very pleasant manner." Just now, though, Chelsea would appear to need a touch of Julius Caesar, not Syd Caesar.

webTitle: Gunners lack finishing touch to make life easy

fields.headline: Gunners lack finishing touch to make life easy
fields.standfirst: Wenger makes do with a goal each from the new boys
fields.trailText: Arsenal 2 - 1 Coventry
fields.body:
For the moment Arsenal are making their points with a blunt nib. In most places their script is admirable but near goal it becomes an untidy scrawl.

"We should be top of the league," the Arsenal manager declared on Saturday, but the reality was that only a combination in stoppage time of the crossbar and a fortuitous ricochet off David Seaman preserved a victory over Coventry City which should have been assured much earlier.

This game marked the fourth anniversary of Wenger's arrival at Highbury. "Manchester United are flying at the moment and they're not giving me any birthday presents," he conceded. "We must try to keep as close to them as we can."

Wenger, like Sir Alex Ferguson, must also strive to keep the balance between picking up Premiership points and keeping his squad fresh for the Champions League, in which Shaktar Donetsk visit Highbury on Wednesday, and Thierry Henry and Nwankwo Kanu were initially rested.

Had Arsenal failed to win, some of the credit would have gone to Magnus Hedman, the Coventry goalkeeper, whose saves twice denied Dennis Bergkamp a goal and later thwarted Fredrik Ljungberg. At the same time much of the blame would have lain with the collective inability of Arsenal's attack to take some simple chances. "At the moment," said Wenger, "we're missing opportunities to kill off opponents when we get inside the box. We don't score enough, so we don't relax enough."

That may be so but part of their trouble was that, given the ease with which Robert Pires and Sylvain Wiltord were taking it in turns to destroy Coventry's cover and confidence on the left flank, there was a tendency on Arsenal's part to relax too soon.

Nevertheless, both of Wenger's latest French signings had impressive games. Wenger agreed that there might be a bit of Ian Wright, watching from the stands, in Wiltord - the right bit presumably - and felt that Pires might be able to do for Arsenal what Zinedine Zidane has been doing for France.

There appeared to be little doubt about the outcome once Arsenal had gone ahead midway through the first half. The offside flag stayed down as Oleg Luzhny's long pass on the right sent Wiltord clear to cut inside before beating Hedman at the near post.

And when Paolo Vernazza, a 20-year-old from exotic Islington, pounced on a rebound to score his first senior goal for the club in the 72nd minute the rest looked a formality.

With 10 minutes remaining, however, Mustapha Hadji curled a free-kick over the wall and beyond a flat-footed Seaman. Then in the third and final minute of stoppage time Marcus Hall's thunderous left-footed shot beat Seaman and shook the bar before glancing to safety off the Arsenal goalkeeper's shoulder.

"I thought that was going in,' said Wenger. "We were very lucky." But by then luck, so far as Arsenal were concerned, should not have had anything to do with it.

webTitle: Gregory bangs the drum in air of discord

fields.headline: Gregory bangs the drum in air of discord
fields.standfirst: Villa profit from their own discontent
fields.trailText: Aston Villa 2 - 0 Bradford
fields.body:
"Hard hats must be worn at all times in this area." With Doug Ellis as chairman, the instruction is good advice for Villa managers even when the Trinity Road stand does not resemble a building site. It is especially so when Ken Bates at Chelsea is threatening to be deadlier than the Ellis. If a reputation is worth having, it is worth defending.

This was Villa's first home game since the chairman waved his wad of shares and survived a vote of no confidence. Player unrest has been discomfiting John Gregory. The manager needed this win and owed it to two of his disaffected men, Gareth Southgate flashing in an early striker's goal when a corner was half cleared and Julian Joachim, newly on for David Ginola, winning a generous penalty converted by Dion Dublin.

Gregory, bare-headed, was full of praise for Southgate, who wants to play for a club that wins things. "He has a lot of pride in himself" with every sign of "passion when he pulls on a Villa shirt. He had an assured game." In another sense, Bates's axe may have worked in Gregory's favour. "If Luca [Vialli] was the man behind it [Southgate's unrest], this could be the end of it," he added.

Ginola was playing his first home game, Benito Carbone returning after his escape from Villa. But this was no game of hair and hounds. The Frenchman was short of fitness, the Italian's flair flickered and faded for all his white boots and matching headband. The hounds were called off early.

Bradford need stronger or more acute support up front but they were the better unit, more composed than last season, their neat play matching the intricate trellis of shadows formed on the pitch by the sun behind the girders of the uncovered stand. They made shift with Stuart McCall at the back in an unaccustomed 3-5-2 line-up and were so determined not to hump the ball that they got themselves into more trouble than Villa's greater individual talents induced.

Disruption and distribution problems have been the talk of the week. Here only Paul Merson and Gareth Barry introduced special powers of wit, accuracy and penetration to overcome them for Villa.

Gregory said of Ginola's substitution: "He was treading water." He was virtually doing that before the long cycle phase down the temporary tunnel and the running that followed. Ginola, plugging his autobiography Le Magnifique before the match, used another metaphor when questioned about his commitment, perhaps forgetting the nickname of Tchaikovsky's sixth symphony. "We are all musicians," he said. "If the concert is bad, no money."

Villa are currently a bunch of soloists and Ginola ran out of puff in the first movement. Gregory, who thinks he needs money to satisfy Southgate's ambitions, may be pleased to remember that quote.

webTitle: Pahars rings a warning Dell for Robson

fields.headline: Pahars rings a warning Dell for Robson
fields.standfirst: Newcastle's start put in perspective by Hoddle's chief craftsman
fields.trailText: Southampton 2 - 0 Newcastle
fields.body:
For all the buoyancy on the Tyne, Newcastle were badly holed here by the Solent. The presence of the venerable Bobby Robson at the helm may be reassuring but has the tide truly turned for this club?

Southampton emphasised the question, showing a healthy disrespect for Newcastle's lofty position and beating them soundly. So comfortable were the Saints in their first win of the season that their fans taunted Alan Shearer and Co with chants of "what a waste of petrol". There was still half an hour to go.

Newcastle travelled by air, of course, but the Dell remains a distinctly unhappy destination. Their players were glad to fly home without a good old- fashioned rollicking from the 67-year-old Robson. The manager was speechless after this display if only because, as his No2 Mick Wadsworth explained: "He's got a bad throat and he's lost his voice."

Newcastle are a highly creditable sixth and no one can dispute Wadsworth's claim that "irrespective of today's result we've made damn good progress" in the past year. But this is progress from poverty to mediocrity, despite what the table says, because Robson's team typify the vast majority of the Premiership. They were distinctly poor defensively, which also reveals something else about opponents who had failed to breach their goal in almost 5 hours.

In the frenzy of English football a little organisation and a touch of imagination go a long, long way. In the contest of former England brains, Glenn Hoddle outwitted Robson by deploying a 4-3-2-1 formation from which sprang a host of early chances falling to midfielders. Southampton should have been three goals ahead midway through the first half.

It helps Saints, of course, to have such an instinctive finisher as Marian Pahars, who has now struck five times in four full appearances despite a variety of injuries. He has had knee trouble and complained of a hamstring problem at half-time. Hoddle gambled, sent him back on and saw the little Latvian maintain his positional knack to score twice and then limp off to a resounding ovation.

Newcastle had their chances, the restored Paul Jones making the save of the afternoon in somehow parrying Shearer's close-range header, but they never came to terms with Hoddle's tactics. Both goals flowed through the imaginative Matthew Oakley and Hassan Kachloul; both were finished at close range and had Newcastle's defenders looking at one another and at the linesman.

Southampton deserved any luck accompanying their opening win - and first clean sheet - and Hoddle deserves an improved contract when his one-year deal expires in January. Given the high chance of further managerial upheavals by the turn of the year Saints may be hard pressed to hold him. But he shows no signs of defecting from the Dell.

"I've approached the job in the same way as if I'd signed for five years," he said. "The players will tell you that. It's great to be back, and back in the Premiership. It's a big challenge."

webTitle: Majestic United in league of their own

fields.headline: Majestic United in league of their own
fields.standfirst: Smith voices fears of Scottish-style single-club dominance
fields.trailText: Everton 1 - 3 Man Utd
fields.body:
As criticisms go, "too Scottish" might sound slightly unlikely coming from the mouth of Walter Smith. However, on Saturday evening the Everton manager seemed genuinely worried that the Premiership has acquired something of a tartan hue - and he was not alluding to the coincidence that he and his counterpart yesterday are Scots.

Rather it was the possible ramifications of what the game's purists refer to as the single-club domination theory. It is something he is well placed to comment on, having been a key player in the construction of the modern Rangers - a highly successful process which laid waste to the dreams and aspirations of a whole generation of Scottish football-lovers. Smith is now presumably discovering what it feels like to manage Kilmarnock.

"People used to look at Scotland and say that there was only one team in it, namely Rangers," said Smith. "That was fine, it never really bothered me. The thing is, Manchester United are now matching down here what Rangers did up there.

"It is competitive in the Premiership but at what sort of level is it competitive if one team has won the title in six out of the last eight seasons and has finished in second place on the two occasions they did not finish first?

"Arsenal managed to get up to United's level once and have maintained a challenge but it is getting very difficult to do that. There is a challenge there for us all to meet, to rise up to," he added.

Smith has led Everton back from the brink to, depending on your level of expectation, either acceptable safety or unacceptable mediocrity, but he feels that clubs such as Everton are now so far behind United that they realistically no longer share the same targets.

Unwittingly backing up Smith's theory was Sir Alex Ferguson, who explained away the absence of Jaap Stam by saying he had simply been given the weekend off. Now that's what you call a managerial luxury.

Despite the majesty of United's first-half football, Everton were little short of a disgrace until, as Ferguson pointed out, their pride intervened, prompting them to resolve belatedly that no visiting team should be permitted to hold sway from first whistle to last.

Curiously, Ferguson insisted that after Thomas Gravesen had eaten into his side's advantage with a nicely worked goal on 54 minutes, things were "hairy" for a quarter of an hour, suggesting that the outcome was fleetingly in some doubt.

It was nonsense, of course. Ferguson was simply trying to provide a spoonful of solace for his old friend Smith.

For Smith there was little to mitigate the shabbiness and generosity of his own makeshift defence. With Richard Dunne perfecting his carthorse impression at right- back, David Weir lost without his buddy Richard Gough in the centre and Michael Hughes out of position and out of touch at left-back, United ran amok, the wonder being that they logged only three goals in an opening half when Everton's collective madness was at its most pronounced.

After Nicky Butt had sauntered through the decaying remains of the Everton rearguard to chest home an Ole Gunnar Solskjaer cross, Ryan Giggs steered home after Paul Gerrard had saved - but not held - Teddy Sheringham's drive.

Solskjaer added a third shortly before the interval, climaxing a sublime move engineered by the marvellous David Beckham, but by that point United were already reducing the level of their input in readiness for tomorrow night's Champions League spat with Dynamo Kiev.

"Our first-half football was the best we have produced all season," said Ferguson. " Other teams will come here and drop points so I'm happy."

Rather happier than United's goalkeeper Fabien Barthez who, despite spending the afternoon doing nothing more taxing than pondering where his next gallon of petrol would come from, somehow managed to pull a muscle which will probably leave him inactive for 10 days.

"I'll have no problems with including Raimond van der Gouw because he doesn't let me down," said Ferguson.

As Smith hinted, the problem for everyone outside of Old Trafford is that no one ever seems to let Manchester United down.

webTitle: Paula Yates

fields.headline: Paula Yates
fields.standfirst: Derided as a vacuous icon of modern society, her indomitable spirit celebrated love, life and fun
fields.trailText: "Do I really care? I feel lucky that I'm a member of a generation that doesn't give a fuck about 40. To be honest, it's a miracle I've made it at all."
fields.body:
"Do I really care? I feel lucky that I'm a member of a generation that doesn't give a fuck about 40. To be honest, it's a miracle I've made it at all."

Writing in the women's magazine Aura earlier this year, Paula Yates, who has apparently committed suicide aged 40, approached her impending birthday with characteristic bravado and defiance. But behind the bold words lay the wreckage of her recently, incorrigibly luckless life: the apparent suicide of her lover Michael Hutchence in a Sydney hotel room, the revelation that former Opportunity Knocks presenter Hughie Green was her father, a vicious and protracted custody battle with her ex-husband Bob Geldof.

The woman once described as "a smart girl who made a career out of pretending to be an airhead" was said to have spiralled into despair; lonely, afraid of the future, and nursing an increasingly fractured sense of self.

Yates was born in Colwyn Bay, and brought up in the north Wales village of Rowen, near Llandudno. It was not a happy experience. In her autobiography, she described her mother, the former Bluebell dancer and actress Hélène Thornton-Bosment, as being "absent" for large portions of her childhood.

An only child, Yates wrote that, as a girl, she would sleep outside her mother's door in case she left in the night. The man she believed to be her father, the one-time presenter of Yorkshire Television's religious programme, Stars On Sunday, Jess Yates, left the family when Paula was eight, and her mother later admitted to a string of affairs.

After an itinerant childhood, overshadowed by abandonment and infidelity, Yates claimed to have experimented with sex and heroin at an early age. She left school at 16, and moved to London, where she became involved in the emerging punk scene. Besotted with Bob Geldof, then the lead singer of the Boomtown Rats, after meeting him at a party, she followed the band around on tour before beginning a relationship with him. The pair eventually married in Las Vegas in 1986, having been together for 10 years.

By now nicknamed "the princess of punk" by tabloid newspapers, and "the limpet" by Geldof's friends, Yates appeared to revel in the outrageous and the exhibitionist. She posed naked in London's Reform Club for Penthouse magazine, and published a book of photographs under the title Rock Stars In Their Underpants, which was described by Andy Warhol as "the greatest work of art in the last decade". Later, she was to write other books, including three works for children - A Tale Of Two Kitties, and Paula Yates's Little Boy Book and Little Girl Book - and Blondes: A History From Their Earliest Roots.

After a brief foray into music journalism, in 1982 she began co-presenting Channel 4's cutting-edge music show The Tube, with pianist Jools Holland. Two years later, she wrote and presented another Channel 4 series, Baby, Baby, which involved interviews with mothers.

Renowned for her dizzy, flirtatious television persona, Yates seldom received credit for the qualities that made her a more substantial person. Widely read, with a quick wit and sharp intelligence, she was also a devoted partner and mother to her and Geldof's extravagantly-named daughters, Fifi Trixibelle, Peaches and Pixie.

In 1992, she moved from night to daytime television, and began presenting Channel 4's Big Breakfast show, made by Geldof's production company, Planet 24. It was her speciality to conduct celebrity interviews from a bed, and it was there that she met the Australian musician Michael Hutchence, then lead singer with the band INXS, whom she described as "God's gift to women". In a blaze of tabloid publicity, she left Geldof for Hutchence a year later, and in 1996, amidst an even bigger blaze of tabloid publicity, the couple were divorced.

Yates and Hutchence's daughter, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily was born in August 1996. Yates was said to be gloriously happy with her new life, but her relationship with Geldof remained acrimonious and, following her arrest for alleged drug offences two months later, he won temporary custody of their three children. Yates said later that she felt like the victim of a witch hunt: "Bob is still perceived as St Bob, and me as his wayward wife."

She was devastated when Hutchence was found hanged by his belt in a hotel room in Sydney in November 1997. She refused to accept the inquest verdict of suicide, insisting that Hutchence must have died when a sexual game of autoerotic asphyxiation went wrong. Meanwhile, following the startling public revelation of Yates's true paternity in May 1997, DNA tests confirmed that Hughie Green was her real father, although she had been conceived within weeks of her mother's marriage to Jess. As one friend observed at the time: "In the space of a month, Paula has lost her future, and her past."

A year later, she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital with depression. She lost custody of Fifi, Peaches and Pixie, and two weeks later apparently tried to hang herself. She was then admitted to a rehabilitation clinic. Legal wrangling over her lover's estate continued, and Hutchence's father, Kelland, made an abortive attempt to win custody of his grand-daughter. Yates embarked on a series of ill-advised affairs, including one with a former heroin addict, who later sold his story to the newspapers, claiming that she slept with Hutchence's ashes.

Yates's lippy, ludicrous public image made her an easy target for derision. She loved the spotlight, and her fame by association. Anonymity never suited her. She was vulgar, irrepressible and eccentric, and, in many ways, represented all that is silly and vacuous about modern celebrity.

But it is her indomitable spirit that people remember, and her wholeheartedness in life and love. Paula Yates was a survivor. In a magazine interview last year, she said: "It's only the mothering instinct that makes you willing to suffer every day. I know it sounds like a Victorian novel, but it's true. Right now, I still think living is a noble gesture."

 Paula Yates, broadcaster and writer, born April 24 1960; died September 17 2000

Writing in the women's magazine Aura earlier this year, Paula Yates, who has apparently committed suicide aged 40, approached her impending birthday with characteristic bravado and defiance. The woman once described as "a smart girl who made a career out of pretending to be an airhead" was said to have spiralled into despair; lonely, afraid of the future, and nursing an increasingly fractured sense of self. Yates was born in Colwyn Bay, and brought up in the north Wales village of Rowen, near Llandudno. It was not a happy experience. In her autobiography, she described her mother, the former Bluebell dancer and actress Hélène Thornton-Bosment, as being "absent" for large portions of her childhood. An only child, Yates wrote that, as a girl, she would sleep outside her mother's door in case she left in the night. The man she believed to be her father, the one-time presenter of Yorkshire Television's religious programme, Stars On Sunday, Jess Yates, left the family when Paula was eight, and her mother later admitted to a string of affairs. After an itinerant childhood, overshadowed by abandonment and infidelity, Yates claimed to have experimented with sex and heroin at an early age. She left school at 16, and moved to London, where she became involved in the emerging punk scene. Besotted with Bob Geldof, then the lead singer of the Boomtown Rats, after meeting him at a party, she followed the band around on tour before beginning a relationship with him. The pair eventually married in Las Vegas in 1986, having been together for 10 years. By now nicknamed "the princess of punk" by tabloid newspapers, and "the limpet" by Geldof's friends, Yates appeared to revel in the outrageous and the exhibitionist. She posed naked in London's Reform Club for Penthouse magazine, and published a book of photographs under the title Rock Stars In Their Underpants, which was described by Andy Warhol as "the greatest work of art in the last decade". Later, she was to write other books, including three works for children - A Tale Of Two Kitties, and Paula Yates's Little Boy Book and Little Girl Book - and Blondes: A History From Their Earliest Roots. After a brief foray into music journalism, in 1982 she began co-presenting Channel 4's cutting-edge music show The Tube, with pianist Jools Holland. Two years later, she wrote and presented another Channel 4 series, Baby, Baby, which involved interviews with mothers. Renowned for her dizzy, flirtatious television persona, Yates seldom received credit for the qualities that made her a more substantial person. Widely read, with a quick wit and sharp intelligence, she was also a devoted partner and mother to her and Geldof's extravagantly-named daughters, Fifi Trixibelle, Peaches and Pixie. In 1992, she moved from night to daytime television, and began presenting Channel 4's Big Breakfast show, made by Geldof's production company, Planet 24. It was her speciality to conduct celebrity interviews from a bed, and it was there that she met the Australian musician Michael Hutchence, then lead singer with the band INXS, whom she described as "God's gift to women". In a blaze of tabloid publicity, she left Geldof for Hutchence a year later, and in 1996, amidst an even bigger blaze of tabloid publicity, the couple were divorced. Yates and Hutchence's daughter, Heavenly Hiraani Tiger Lily was born in August 1996. Yates was said to be gloriously happy with her new life, but her relationship with Geldof remained acrimonious and, following her arrest for alleged drug offences two months later, he won temporary custody of their three children. Yates said later that she felt like the victim of a witch hunt: "Bob is still perceived as St Bob, and me as his wayward wife." She was devastated when Hutchence was found hanged by his belt in a hotel room in Sydney in November 1997. She refused to accept the inquest verdict of suicide, insisting that Hutchence must have died when a sexual game of autoerotic asphyxiation went wrong. Meanwhile, following the startling public revelation of Yates's true paternity in May 1997, DNA tests confirmed that Hughie Green was her real father, although she had been conceived within weeks of her mother's marriage to Jess. As one friend observed at the time: "In the space of a month, Paula has lost her future, and her past." A year later, she was admitted to a psychiatric hospital with depression. She lost custody of Fifi, Peaches and Pixie, and two weeks later apparently tried to hang herself. She was then admitted to a rehabilitation clinic. Legal wrangling over her lover's estate continued, and Hutchence's father, Kelland, made an abortive attempt to win custody of his grand-daughter. Yates embarked on a series of ill-advised affairs, including one with a former heroin addict, who later sold his story to the newspapers, claiming that she slept with Hutchence's ashes. Yates's lippy, ludicrous public image made her an easy target for derision. She loved the spotlight, and her fame by association. Anonymity never suited her. She was vulgar, irrepressible and eccentric, and, in many ways, represented all that is silly and vacuous about modern celebrity. But it is her indomitable spirit that people remember, and her wholeheartedness in life and love. Paula Yates was a survivor. In a magazine interview last year, she said: "It's only the mothering instinct that makes you willing to suffer every day. I know it sounds like a Victorian novel, but it's true. Right now, I still think living is a noble gesture."  Paula Yates, broadcaster and writer, born April 24 1960; died September 17 2000

webTitle: Penberthy takes five to poop the party

fields.headline: Penberthy takes five to poop the party
fields.standfirst:
Northants Steelbacks 129
Gloucs Gladiators 101
Northamptonshire win by 27 runs (D/L method)
fields.trailText:
Northants Steelbacks 129
Gloucs Gladiators 101
Northamptonshire win by 27 runs (D/L method)
fields.body:
It was the day that Gloucestershire inexplicably fluffed their punch-line. The most clinical, proficient and best-rehearsed one-day side in the country were bowled out for 101 in fewer than 34 overs, to lose by 27 runs.

In a season of triple triumphs they drank champagne in front of the pavilion last night as they were crowned National League champions. But the nectar had lost just a little of its sparkle. Sky TV had recorded the presentation before the game, and there was a similar hint of pretence about Gloucestershire's anti-climactic defeat, though it made no difference to the positions.

This should have been a leisurely walk to victory. But Tony Penberthy bowled excellently to take five for 27; the off-spinner Jason Brown gave away only 12 runs in his nine overs. The light, which deteriorated during Gloucestershire's innings, was no more than a partial excuse. It revealed weariness, wariness and few of the buoyant signs that have been such a feature of the summer.

It has still been a fine season for them, though not financially. The county's chief executive Colin Sextone fears they may lose £50,000 on the year, partly the result of ticket allocations at Lord's. "The whole question of incentives needs to be urgently reviewed. A far larger percentage should go to the teams taking part."

It had not looked as though Northamptonshire had scored enough; one reason for this was Ian Harvey's superb five for 19. Assuming he is not in the full Australian squad, he will be signing a new two-year contract. He went on to hit 43 off 27 balls as his team-mates collapsed around him.

Northants had rustled up only four boundaries in their own apprehensive innings, one hardly attuned to the carnival mood. The portents were bad when Jeffrey Cook went first ball. They had lost their top five batsmen for 32.

Matthew Hayden, making his final appearance for them, was transfixed in disbelief when caught behind, remaining stationary for so long that he seemed to be already stuck in an airport queue. Penberthy and Kevin Innes produced the sole stand of importance: significant, as it turned out, in the course of a game that stunned a crowd of 3,500.

webTitle: Round up

fields.headline: Round up
fields.trailText: Ronnie Irani would doubtless concur with Richie Benaud's belief that captaincy is 90 per cent about luck. As Essex gained promotion to the championship's First Division in the dying hours of the first- class summer, with a six-wicket win over Warwickshire at Chelmsford, Irani must have wondered which of his blessings to count first.
fields.body:
Ronnie Irani would doubtless concur with Richie Benaud's belief that captaincy is 90 per cent about luck. As Essex gained promotion to the championship's First Division in the dying hours of the first- class summer, with a six-wicket win over Warwickshire at Chelmsford, Irani must have wondered which of his blessings to count first.

Rain had forced Warwickshire - who until that stage had dominated the match - to declare three balls into their second innings. Essex reached their target of 201 against an attack bereft of Allan Donald, Ed Giddins and Ashley Giles. And then there was the mathematical injustice: Essex, with five wins, went up; Gloucestershire, with six, stayed down.

But few could question that Irani was also rich in the 10 per cent of skill required. Appropriately, he was at the crease on 64 when the winning runs were hit, capping a debut season as captain which has seen him rack up 1,196 runs at 54 and take 42 wickets at 24. Nasser Hussain, at the ground but on central contract sabbatical, must have been tempted to seek a word of advice.

This, of course, was the Saturday climax the England and Wales Cricket Board had dreamed of. One day to go, two promotion slots vacant, six teams in the running. The other riser was Glamorgan , who drew with Middlesex , but only after Justin Langer's 213 had saved the Londoners from their first wooden spoon. All embarrassment was heaped on Sussex instead.

Gloucestershire were the unluckiest side, their three-wicket defeat of Nottinghamshire leaving them two points short of promotion. Still, the most fortuitous winners in NatWest Trophy history - remember Kabir Ali? - could hardly grumble that they had been hard done by.

With the focus on the promotion race there was little fanfare for Mark Butcher's first five-wicket haul, as Surrey drew with Lancashire , nor for Glenn McGrath's eight for 41, as Worcestershire 's promotion push petered out against Northamptonshire.

And there was time only for a flicker of sorrow as Hampshire lost to Yorkshire by 72 runs on the final ball at Northlands Road. The bulldozers are imminent and Hampshire's home of 115 years will soon be a housing estate. It has been a season of change, not all of it desirable.

Worcestershire were the big National League losers yesterday, too, when they clinched relegation from the First Division with an eight-wicket defeat at home to Kent. They were eight points clear at the top on June 24 but have since gone nine games without a win.

Worcestershire made only 98 against a Kent seam attack led by Martin Saggers (three for 25). The Spitfires remain in the top flight after reaching their target with 18.1 overs to spare.
